Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 


Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated 
the "Code of Ordinances, City of Oakland Park, Florida," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1960, § 1-1) 
Charter reference— City authorized to adopt codification of its ordinances, Art. I, § 14(jj). 


Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless 
the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    City . The words "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of Oakland Park" followed 
the word "city," and shall extend to and include its several officers, agents and employees. 
    City commission. Whenever the words "city commission" are used, they shall be construed to mean 
the city commission of the City of Oakland Park. 
    City officials or officers . Whenever reference is made to officials, boards, commissions, 
departments, etc., by title only, i.e., "city clerk," "chief of police," etc., they shall be deemed to refer to the 
officials, boards, commissions and departments of the City of Oakland Park. 
    Computation of time . Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, a certain 
length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given or such act is 
done shall be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall not 
be counted. 
    County . The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Broward. 
    Fire and emergency medical services . "Fire and emergency medical services" shall mean the 
services provided to the City of Oakland Park by the County of Broward Health and Public Safety 
Department under the terms of the "agreement" between the City of Oakland Park and Broward County 
Board of County Commissioners. 
    Fire service employees . "Fire service employees" shall mean the employees of the City of Oakland 
Park transferred to the County of Broward on August 1, 1991, under the terms of the "agreement" 
between the City of Oakland Park and the Broward County Board of County Commissioners. 
    Fla. Stats . The Statutes of the State of Florida as officially adopted by the state legislature. 
    Gender . A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend to and be applied to females and 
to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Interpretation . In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to 
be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, 
convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the 
subject matter than the general provisions imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater 
restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    Number . A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons 
and things as well as to one (1) person and thing. 
    Oath . The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an 
affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be 
equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Or, and . "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner . The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, 
tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of 
such building or land. 
    Person . The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, 
partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property includes every species of property except real property. 
    Public safety . "Public safety" shall mean the police department of the City of Oakland Park, Florida. 
    Public safety director . "Public safety director" shall mean the police chief of the City of Oakland 
Park, Florida. 
    Shall, May . Wherever "shall" is used, it shall be mandatory; "may" is permissive. 
    State . The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Florida. 
    Tense . Words used in the present or past tense include the future as well as the present or past. 
(Code 1960, § 1-2; Ord. No. O-92-8, § 2, 4-15-92) 
State Law reference— For state law definitions, see § 1.01, Florida Statutes. 


Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere 
catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such 
sections, nor as any part of the sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed 
when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1960, § 1-3) 


Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance 
repealed took effect. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred 
before the repeal took effect, or any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for 
an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1960, § 1-4) 


Sec. 1-5. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city commission that the sections, paragraphs, 
sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, 
paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a 
court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, 
clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 1-5) 


Sec. 1-6. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
    All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances which amend, repeal or in any way 
affect this Code of Ordinances may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code 
and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection 
or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from said Code by omission from 
reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, 
shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code of Ordinances 
and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the city 
commission. 
    Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code should be made by amending such provisions by 
specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section …of the 
Code of Ordinances, City of Oakland Park, Florida, is hereby amended to read as follows: …" The new 
provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
    In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language 
shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Oakland Park, Florida, is hereby amended by adding 
a section to be numbered …, which said section reads as follows: …" The section shall then be set out in 
full as desired. 
    All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by 
section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1960, § 1-6) 


Sec. 1-7. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of 
this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any 
manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City of Oakland Park to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1960, § 1-7) 


Sec. 1-8. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
    Whenever, in any ordinance of the city, or by any provision of this Code of Ordinances, any act is 
prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever, in such ordinance or 
provision, the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no 
specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such ordinance or provision shall be punished by 
a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding ninety (90) 
days, or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. Each day any violation of any 
ordinance or provision of this Code shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
    In addition to the penalties hereinabove provided, any condition caused or permitted to exist in 
violation of any ordinance or provision of this Code shall be deemed a public nuisance, and may be, by 
the city, abated as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a 
new and separate offense. 
(Code 1960, § 1-8) 
Charter reference— Authority to impose above penalty, Art. I, § 14(kk). 


Sec. 1-9. - Principal in first degree. 
    Whoever commits any offense against this city, or aids, abets, counsels, hires or otherwise procures 
such offense to be committed, is a principal in the first degree and may be charged, convicted and 
punished as such, whether he is or is not actually or constructively present at the commission of such 
offense. 
(Code 1960, § 1-9) 


Sec. 1-10. - Costs in municipal court. 
(a) ?In all cases before the municipal court, there shall be assessed a flat fee of seven dollars ($7.00) for 
costs in such cases. Any individual, except authorized police officers or the head of any city 
department, instituting a suit in the municipal court shall pay the costs in advance. 
    In the event that, in the final disposition of any case, the court assesses the costs against the 
defendant and the same are paid, it shall be the duty of the clerk of the court to return the costs to 
the person who paid them in advance. 
(b) ?The City of Oakland Park shall assess an additional two dollars ($2.00) as court costs to those 
individuals convicted of the violations as set out in Florida Statutes 943.25(3) which shall be returned 
to the City of Oakland Park to be used by the City of Oakland Park pursuant to Florida Statutes, 
Section 943.25(13)(a). 
(c) ?In addition to the court costs set forth above, there shall be assessed such costs as required by 
Section 943.25(3), Florida Statutes. 
(Code 1960, § 2-11.1; Ord. No. O-76-27, § 1, 12-15-76; Ord. No. O-82-6, § 1, 3-17-82) 


Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Fire department, § 6-1 et seq.; service fee dishonored check, § 8-37; pensions and 
retirement, Ch. 9; police, Ch. 10; public works contracts and specifications, Ch. 11; stormwater utility 
system, Ch. 12; taxation, Ch. 20; administrative hearing board for municipal parking violations, § 21-47; 
land development code, Ch. 24; review boards, § 24-232 et seq. 


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 2-1. - Establishment and general powers and duties of department of sanitation. 
    There is hereby created and established a department of sanitation of the city, which department 
shall have supervision of all matters of public health, garbage collection and other matters of sanitation 
pertaining to the city and its citizens and shall be vested with such powers as may be necessary to insure 
the sanitary disposal of garbage and to enforce any other health or sanitary ordinances, rules or 
regulations passed, created or established by the city. 
(Code 1960, § 8-3) 
Cross reference— Waste tire collection permit, § 7-6; solid waste, Ch. 13. 


Sec. 2-2. - Fiscal year. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Florida Statutes, section 166.241(2), the fiscal year for the city shall 
begin October 1 of each year and end September 30 of the following year. 


Sec. 2-3. - Educational assistance for employees. 
(a) ?Subject to annual appropriation, all full-time, regular employees who have completed twelve (12) 
months of continuous service with the city shall be eligible for educational assistance. Educational 
courses must be from a fully accredited college, university, or other training facility, which is 
approved by the city manager or designee, This includes language courses that will add to the city's 
ability to work and provide customer service in a culturally diverse environment. 
(b) ?The city shall pay for such approved courses, tuition and registration fees, and laboratory fees; 
provided, however, that such assistance shall be limited to three (3) courses per semester, per 
employee, not to exceed a maximum of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per year, as outlined in 
the city's education assistance policy. 
(c) ?Remain in the city employment for at least two (2) years after receiving educational assistance. 
(d) ?The city shall recover from any employee any moneys expended on his behalf pursuant to this 
section, if the employee fails to comply with any requirement of subsection (c) above, by deducting 
the same from any funds to which the employee may be entitled. 
(e) ?Conferences/certifications and required training will be paid for by the city only upon the written 
recommendation of the department head and the approval of the city manager. This form of 
education will be paid out of the corresponding departmental budget from the line item entitled 
"training." The city shall pay for required training necessary for recertification. However, the cost for 
the recertification will be paid by the employee. 
(f) ?For purposes of this section, required training is defined as training required by the state to maintain 
certification for fire and other certifications required by the state and/or classification. 
(Code 1960, § 2-12; Ord. No. 609, § 1, 9-19-73; Ord. No. O-94-10, § 1, 9-21-94; Ord. No. O-98-
3, § 1, 2-4-98; Ord. No. O-2011-022, § 1, 9-21-11) 


Sec. 2-4. - Liability insurance for city-owned vehicles. 
    The city shall either be self-insured or maintain liability insurance to cover the City of Oakland Park 
fleet of vehicles. 
(Code 1960, § 2-15; Ord. No. 523, § 1, 12-2-70; Ord. No. O-75-14, § 1, 11-19-75; Ord. No. O-
92-14, § 2, 5-20-92) 


Sec. 2-5. - Public and quasipublic organizations; financial books and records. 
(a) ?Public and quasipublic organizations are defined as: 
(1) ?All advisory boards as set forth in the charter; 
(2) ?All boards of public or semipublic purpose or function, any or all of whose members are 
appointed by the city commission; 
(3) ?All organizations whose membership is composed exclusively of city employees or officers. 
(b) ?Each organization mentioned in subsection (a), whose function includes the handling of money, is 
required to keep proper books and records of all financial matters, on a fiscal year basis, 
commencing October 1st and ending September 30th of each year, and to keep such books 
available for inspection by the proper city officials at all times. The city commission may, at its own 
expense, at any time, audit such books and records. 
(Code 1960, § 2-5) 


Sec. 2-6. - Personnel rules saved from repeal. 
    Nothing contained in this Code or in the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or 
otherwise affect the personnel rules of the city. 
Cross reference— Civil service rules and regulations, § 2-81 et seq. 


Sec. 2-7. - Travel allowances for mayor, commissioners and employees when traveling on city business. 
    Whenever it is deemed necessary for the mayor, commissioners and employees of the City of 
Oakland Park and such travel is approved either by the city commission or by the city manager, 
allowances for travel shall be limited to those expenses necessarily incurred by them in the performance 
of a public purpose and must be within the limitations prescribed under the city's travel policy adopted by 
the city commission from time to time. Any changes to the travel policy require the approval of the city 
commission. 
(Ord. No. O-74-25, § 1, 12-4-74; Ord. No. O-79-26, § 1, 9-19-79; Ord. No. O-85-14, §§ 1, 2, 6-
19-85; Ord. No. O-89-28, §§ 2, 3, 12-20-89; Ord. No. O-91-6, § 2, 6-19-91; Ord. No. O-96-14, § 
2, 9-18-96; Ord. No. O-2008-026, § 2, 7-2-08) 


Sec. 2-8. - Employment screening. 
(a) ?As authorized by Section 166.0442, Florida Statutes, any individual who is currently being 
employed, is seeking employment, or is to be appointed to a position of municipal employment or 
appointment which the city finds is critical to security or public safety shall be subject to employment 
screening. The employment screening process shall require that each person applying for, or 
continuing employment in any such position, or having access to any such facility, be fingerprinted. 
The city shall submit the fingerprints to the Florida Department of Law Enforcement for a state 
criminal history record check and to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history 
record check. The information obtained from the criminal history record checks conducted pursuant 
to this section may be used to determine an applicant's eligibility for employment or appointment and 
to determine an employee's eligibility for continued employment. The fingerprinting and associated 
criminal history record checks shall be in addition to any other background screening which the city 
may lawfully undertake. 
(b) ?As authorized by Section 166.0442, Florida Statutes, any private contractor, any employee of a 
private contractor, vendor, repair person, or delivery person who has access to any public facility or 
publicly operated facility that the city commission finds is critical to security or public safety shall be 
subject to employment screening as described in subsection (a) above. The employment screening 
process shall require that each person having access to any such facility, be fingerprinted. The costs 
of such employment screening pursuant to this section shall be borne by the contractor, vendor, 
repair person, or delivery person. 
(c) ?The positions of municipal employment and appointment, and the public facilities and publicly 
operated facilities that are critical to security or public safety are listed in city Ordinance No. O-2003-
005, a copy of which may be obtained from the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-005, § 2, 5-21-03) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2003-005, adopted May 21, 2003, amended the Code by adding 
provisions designated as § 2-14. In order to avoid conflicts in the numbering of provisions the 
editor has designated the provisions of Ord. No. O-2003-005 as § 2-8. 


Sec. 2-9. - Exemption from Broward County Ordinance No. 75-7 granting franchise to American Video 
Corporation. 
(a) ?The City of Oakland Park, Florida, shall be exempt from the terms and conditions of Broward 
County Ordinance No. 75-7 which creates a nonexclusive right, privilege and franchise to American 
Video Corporation to construct, operate and maintain a cable television system in Broward County 
east of the Florida Turnpike and north of Oakland Park Boulevard. 
(b) ?The City of Oakland Park reserves the right to determine the holder of any CATV franchise within 
the boundaries of the city. 
(Ord. No. O-75-4, §§ 1, 2, 7-2-75) 
Editor's note— Section 2-9 is derived from §§ 1 and 2 of Ord. No. O-75-4 which ordinance did 
not expressly amend this Code. 


Sec. 2-10. - Open space and recreational trust fund created; term; assets; disbursal. 
(a) ?Establishment of trust . There is hereby created an Oakland Park Open Space and Recreational 
Trust Fund and Account for the purpose of accepting and disbursing fees, gifts, grants and awards of 
money made to Oakland Park for parks, open space and recreational lands. 
(b) ?Term of existence . The Oakland Park Open Space, Park and Recreational Trust Fund and Account 
shall be self-perpetuating and sustaining from year to year unless specifically terminated by the city 
commission. 
(c) ?Trust assets . All trust assets shall be expended, utilized and disbursed only for parks, open space 
and recreational needs within the areas of the city in order to provide additional community and 
neighborhood parks necessary to meet the need for local level parks created by additional residential 
development within the City of Oakland Park as provided by Section 4.05 of Broward County 
Ordinance No. 77-43. 
(d) ?Disbursal of assets. 
(1) ?No funds shall be disbursed from the Oakland Park Open Space, Park and Recreational Trust 
Fund unless approved by the city commission. 
(2) ?Funds of the Oakland Park Open Space, Park and Recreational Trust Fund shall only be 
utilized in accordance with the provisions of Broward County Ordinances No. 77-43 and No. 77-
66. 
(3) ?Funds of the Oakland Park Open Space, Park and Recreational Trust Fund shall only be 
utilized in accordance with the provisions of Section 4.05 of Broward County Ordinance No. 77-
43 which provides, among other things, that such funds shall be expended within a reasonable 
period of time for the sole purpose of acquiring and developing land necessary to meet the need 
for local level parks created by the development, in order to provide a system of local level 
parks which will be available and substantially beneficial to the residents of the platted areas. 
(Ord. No. O-79-2, §§ 1—4, 2-21-79) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-79-2, §§ 1—4, adopted Feb. 21, 1979, did not specifically amend 
the Code. Codification herein as § 2-10 was, therefore, at the discretion of the editor. 


Sec. 2-11. - Restrictions on employment of relatives and cohabitants. 
(a) ?In this section, unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the following words and phrases shall 
have the meanings herein ascribed to them: 
(1) ?City official or employee: Any officer or employee of the City of Oakland Park and specifically 
including every person engaged in any employment relationship with the City of Oakland Park 
under any appointment or contract of hire, whether express or implied, oral or written, for 
remuneration and including all full, part-time, seasonal, permanent and temporary employees. 
(2) ?Appointing authority: Any officer or employee of the City of Oakland Park in whom is vested the 
authority by law, rule or regulation, or to whom the authority has been delegated, to appoint, 
employ, promote or advance individuals or to recommend individuals for appointment, 
employment, promotion or advancement in connection with employment by the city. 
(3) ?Relative: Any individual related to a city official or employee of the City of Oakland Park as 
listed below: 
Father 
Mother 
Son 
Daughter 
Sister 
Brother 
Uncle 
Husband 
Wife 
Father-in-law 
Mother-in-law 
Son-in-law 
Daughter-in-law 
Brother-in-law 
Aunt 
Nephew 
Niece 
First cousin 
Half-brother 
Half-sister 
Sister-in-law 
Stepfather 
Stepmother 
Stepson 
Stepdaughter 
Stepsister 
Stepbrother 
(4) ?Cohabitation: Two (2) or more persons living together in a communal fashion sharing the same 
place of residence. 
(5) ?Cohabitant: One who engages in cohabitation with a city official or employee of the city. 
(b) ?An appointing authority may not appoint, employ, promote or advance or advocate for appointment, 
employment, promotion or advancement in or to a position in a department or agency of the city in 
which such appointing authority is serving or over which such appointing authority exercises 
jurisdiction or control [over] any individual who is a relative or cohabitant of the appointing authority. 
An individual may not be appointed, employed, promoted or advanced in or to a position in a 
department or agency of the city if such appointment, employment, promotion or advancement has 
been advocated by an appointing authority serving in or exercising jurisdiction or control over the 
department or agency, who is a relative or cohabitant of the individual. 
(c) ?Mere approval of budgets shall not be sufficient to constitute "jurisdiction or control" for the purposes 
of this section. 
(d) ?Except as provided herein, an individual appointed, employed, promoted or advanced in violation of 
this section is not entitled to pay, and money may not be paid to an individual so appointed, 
employed, promoted or advanced. 
(e) ?After the effective date of this section, no employee who is related to or cohabits with another city 
employee within any degree of relationship as set forth in section 2-11(a)(3)—(5), shall be 
transferred into the department in which the related or cohabiting employee is assigned or in which 
he or she holds an appointive position. 
(f) ?The City of Oakland Park may prescribe, in its personnel rules, regulations authorizing the temporary 
employment, in the event of emergencies resulting from natural disasters or similar unforeseen 
events or circumstances, of individuals whose employment would otherwise be prohibited by this 
section. 
(Ord. No. O-86-11, § 1, 4-2-86) 
Editor's note— For purposes of classification, § 2-170, as enacted by Ord. No. O-86-11, § 1, 
adopted April 2, 1986, has been redesignated as 2-11 herein, at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— Civil service rules and regulations, § 2-81 et seq. 


Sec. 2-12. - Filing fee for elective office established. 
    The city commission hereby establishes a filing fee of forty dollars ($40.00) to be paid by each 
candidate seeking an elective office for the city. 
(Ord. No. O-89-25, § 1, 12-20-89) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-89-25, § 1, adopted Dec. 20, 1989, being not specifically 
amendatory of this Code, has been codified as § 2-12 at the discretion of the editor. 
Charter reference— Candidates, affidavits and filing fee, Art. IX, § 9.05. 


Sec. 2-13. - Fees and charges. 
(a) ?City liens, assessments, fees, and permit history reports.

the rate of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per hour shall be charged if the request requires more than

Research time to compile documents:

Each fifteen (15) minutes thereafter ..... 3.50 
Computer systems including operator time:

(1) ?Whenever the city receives a request to produce, provide or compile any of the above records,

department head.

(d) ?The finance director shall institute the necessary rules to effectively control this process. The 
finance director or department may refuse any request for the cost to be billed versus payment in full 
at the time of service based upon the customer's past payment record with the city. All monies 
collected under this article shall be deposited and credited as a revenue to the fund providing the 
service or copies. 
(e) ?It shall be the policy of the city, with regard to requests of other cities or other governmental 
agencies for public records from the city, that said records shall be provided at no cost by the city. 
(Ord. No. O-94-11, § 2, 9-21-94; Ord. No. O-97-7, § 1, 9-17-97; Ord. No. O-2000-009, § 1, 5-
17-00; Ord. No. O-2002-013, § 2, 6-5-02) 


Sec. 2-14. - Parks and recreation department. 
(a) ?The city commission hereby creates a new and separate department known as parks and 
recreation. 
(b) ?The department of parks and recreation shall be responsible for the operation and maintenance of 
the city's parks and recreational facilities. Furthermore, it is charged with fostering partnerships with 
neighborhood schools and expanding weekend activities; providing the addition of new special 
events; and enhancing existing events; and increased planning efforts in the new facilities acquired 
as part of the city's redevelopment efforts. 
(Ord. No. O-2001-028, §§ 2, 3, 9-19-01) 
Charter reference— Creation of administrative departments, Art. V, § 1. 


Sec. 2-15. - City commission compensation. 
(a) ?The annual compensation of the mayor of the City of Oakland Park, pursuant to section 2.08 of the 
Charter of the city of Oakland Park, shall be the sum of ten thousand two hundred dollars 
($10,200.00). Compensation shall be paid in monthly increments of eight hundred fifty dollars 
($850.00). 
(b) ?The annual compensation of the members of the city commission of the City of Oakland Park, 
pursuant to Section 2.08 of the Charter of the city, shall be the sum of nine thousand dollars 
($9,000.00). Compensation shall be paid in monthly increments of seven hundred fifty dollars 
($750.00). 
(c) ?The city commission hereby determines that all compensation received by members of the city 
commission shall be adjusted annually to provide for Cost of Living Adjustments (COLA). Such 
adjustments shall be deemed effective on April 1st of each year, and will be in accordance with the 
Consumer Price Index for Urban Consumers (CPI-U) established rate of inflation for the preceding 
calendar year 
(Ord. No. O-2002-020, § 2, 9-4-02) 


Sec. 2-15.5. - Prohibition of the acceptance of gifts and gratuities from known paid lobbyists by elected 
officers, city officers, and board members. 
    Definitions: 
    Gift or gratuity is defined as a gift, (defined to be real or personal property), any entertainment, any 
food or beverage, lodging, travel, or any other item or service to elected officials, board, committee, city 
officers. 
(a) ?Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, no one shall take, directly or 
indirectly, and no member of the city commission or employee of the city, board members or city 
officers shall knowingly accept, directly or indirectly, any gifts from paid lobbyists. 
(b) ?"Lobbyist" means a person who is retained, with or without compensation, for the purpose of 
lobbying; or a person who is employed by another person or entity, on a full-time or part-time 
basis, principally to lobby on behalf of that other person or entity who seeks any action, 
decision, recommendation of the elected officials, city advisory board or committee members, or 
city staff during the time of the entire decision making process. "Lobbyist" does not include a 
person who is: 
(i) ?An elected official, employee, or appointee of Broward County or of any municipality within 
Broward County communicating in his or her official capacity; 
(ii) ?An individual who communicates on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of a person or 
entity employing the individual on a full-time or part-time basis, unless the individual is 
principally employed by that person or entity to lobby; 
(iii) ?An employee, officer, or board member of a homeowners' association, condominium 
association, or neighborhood association when addressing, in his or her capacity as an 
employee, officer, or board member of such association, an issue impacting the 
association or its members; or 
(iv) ?An employee, officer, or board member of a nonprofit public interest entity (e.g., Sierra 
Club, NAACP, ACLU) when addressing an issue impacting a constituent of that entity. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-012, §§ 2, 3, 3-17-10; Ord. No. O-2012-003, § 2, 2-1-12) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2010-012, §§ 2, 3, adopted March 17, 2010, did not specifically 
amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as § 2-15.5, was at the discretion of the editor. See also 
the Code Comparative Table. 


Secs. 2-16. - Campaign contributions. 
(a) ?Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following terms, phrases, words, and their 
derivations shall have the meaning given herein. Words not defined herein shall be defined in 
accordance with state and federal law or otherwise shall be given their common and ordinary 
meaning, unless the context clearly provides otherwise. 
(1) ?Candidate shall have the meaning given to such term in F.S. Ch. 106, as amended from time to 
time. 
(2) ?Contribution shall have the meaning given to such term in F.S. Ch. 106, as amended from time 
to time. An independent expenditure, as that term is defined in F.S. Ch. 106, is not included 
within the meaning of contribution. 
(3) ?Person shall have the meaning given to such term in F.S. Ch. 106, as amended from time to 
time. 
(4) ?Political committee shall have the meaning given to such term in F.S. Ch. 106, as amended 
from time to time. 
(5) ?Unopposed candidate shall have the meaning given to such term in F.S. § 106.011(15), as 
amended from time to time. 
(b) ?Limitation on contributions. 
(1) ?It shall be unlawful for any person or political committee, either directly or indirectly, to make 
contributions to any candidate with respect to any election for the office of city commissioner, 
which, in the aggregate, exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(2) ?It shall be unlawful for any candidate or other person to knowingly accept or receive any 
campaign contribution prohibited by this section. 
(3) ?The contribution limitations of this section apply to each election conducted to fill a particular 
office. Each primary, special, and general election are separate elections provided a candidate 
is not an unopposed candidate. 
(c) ?Penalties. Any person who violates, permits to be violated, or causes to be violated any provision of 
this section shall, upon such a finding by a court of competent jurisdiction, be assessed a civil fine in 
an amount not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-032, § 2, 12-4-02) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2002-032, § 2, adopted Dec. 4, 2002, amended the Code by adding 
provisions designated as section 2-14. In order to avoid conflicts in section numbering the editor 
has redesignated the provisions of Ord. No. O-2002-032 as section 2-16. 


Sec. 2-16.5. - Registration of lobbyists. 
(a) ?Definitions: 
    "Lobbyist" means a person who is retained, with or without compensation, for the purpose of 
lobbying; or a person who is employed by another person or entity, on a full-time or part-time basis, 
principally to lobby on behalf of that other person or entity who seeks any action, decision, 
recommendation of the elected officials, city advisory board or committee members, or city staff during 
the time of the entire decision making process. "Lobbyist" does not include a person who is: 
(i) ?An elected official, employee, or appointee of Broward County or of any municipality within 
Broward County communicating in his or her official capacity; 
(ii) ?An individual who communicates on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of a person or 
entity employing the individual on a full-time or part-time basis, unless the individual is 
principally employed by that person or entity to lobby; 
(iii) ?An employee, officer, or board member of a homeowners' association, condominium 
association, or neighborhood association when addressing, in his or her capacity as an 
employee, officer, or board member of such association, an issue impacting the 
association or its members; or 
(iv) ?An employee, officer, or board member of a nonprofit public interest entity (e.g., Sierra 
Club, NAACP, ACLU) when addressing an issue impacting a constituent of that entity. 
(b) ?Prior to engaging in each specific lobbying activity, a lobbyist, as defined herein, shall sign a 
registration form maintained by the city at designated locations and file with the city clerk or the 
designee of the city clerk, the registration form which shall require the following information: 
(1) ?The name, address, a telephone number and email address of the lobbyist. The "address" 
must be physical address (e.g. not a post office box) where the lobbyist either resides or 
customarily does business. 
(2) ?The nature and extent of any involvement, activity or assistance, whether paid or voluntary, by 
any lobbyist, or any member of the lobbyist's immediate family, with current or the most recent 
campaign of any current elect city official, or current candidate. 
(3) ?Name, address, and phone number of the lobbyist's principal(s), if known at the time of 
registration. The "address" must be a physical address (e.g. a post office box) where the 
principal either resides or customarily does business. 
(4) ?The general and specific matters upon which the lobbyist intends to lobby, if known at the time 
of registration. 
(c) ?There shall be no fee charged by the city to any lobbyist or lobbyist's principal for registration or 
lobbying pursuant to this section. 
(d) ?The lobbyist registration forms shall be maintained in the city clerk's office. The registration form 
must be signed by the lobbyist and required of each lobbyist for each separate lobby activity 
undertaken by a lobbyist. 
(e) ?Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary in this section, no lobbyist shall be required to register 
when attending any public hearing or public meeting of the city commission or a city board in the City 
of Oakland Park, Florida. 
(Ord. No. O-2007-007, § 2, 2-21-07; Ord. No. O-2012-002, § 2, 2-1-12) 


ARTICLE II. - CONTINUITY OF GOVERNMENT 


Sec. 2-17. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Continuity of Government Ordinance of the City 
of Oakland Park, Florida." 
(Code 1960, § 2-21) 


Sec. 2-18. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context otherwise clearly indicates: 
    Attack: Any attack or series of attacks by an enemy of the United States causing, or which may 
cause, substantial damage or injury to civilian property or persons in the United States in any manner, by 
sabotage or by the use of bombs, missiles, shellfire or atomic, radiological, chemical, bacteriological or 
biological means or other weapons or processes. 
    Duly authorized deputy: A person who is presently authorized to perform all of the functions, exercise 
all of the powers and discharge all of the duties of an office in the event the office is vacant or at such 
times as it lacks administration due to the death, absence or disability of the incumbent officer. 
    Emergency interim successor: A person designated pursuant to this article for possible temporary 
succession to the powers and duties, but not the office, of a city officer in the event that such officer or 
any duly authorized deputy is unavailable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office. 
    Unavailable: Either that a vacancy in office exists and there is no deputy authorized to exercise all of 
the powers and discharge the duties of the office, or that the lawful incumbent of the office (including any 
deputy exercising the powers and discharging the duties of an office because of a vacancy) and his duly 
authorized deputy are absent or unable, for physical, mental or legal reasons, to exercise the powers and 
discharge the duties of the office. 
(Code 1960, § 2-22) 


Sec. 2-19. - Designation of emergency interim successors. 
(a) ?Within thirty (30) days after first entering upon the duties of his office, the mayor and each member 
of the city commission shall, in addition to any duly authorized deputy, designate such number of 
emergency interim successors to his office, and specify their rank in order of succession after any 
duly authorized deputy, so that there will not be less than three (3) duly authorized deputies or 
emergency interim successors, or combination thereof, for the office. 
(b) ?The city commission shall, in addition to any duly authorized deputy, designate for officers 
appointed by it such number of emergency interim successors to such officers, and specify their rank 
in order of succession after any duly authorized deputy, so that there will not be less than three (3) 
duly authorized deputies or emergency interim successors, or combination thereof, for each such 
officer. 
(c) ?The city manager shall, in addition to any duly authorized deputy, designate for officers appointed 
by him such number of emergency interim successors to such officers, and specify their rank in order 
of succession after any duly authorized deputies, so that there will not be less than three (3) duly 
authorized deputies or emergency interim successors, or combination thereof, for each such officer. 
(Code 1960, § 2-23) 


Sec. 2-20. - Qualifications of emergency interim successors. 
    No person shall be designated or serve as an emergency interim successor under this article, unless 
he may, under the constitution and statutes of this state and the charter or ordinances of this city, hold the 
office of the person to whose powers and duties he is designated to succeed, but no provision of any 
ordinance prohibiting an officer or employee of this city from holding another office shall be applicable to 
an emergency interim successor. 
(Code 1960, § 2-23) 


Sec. 2-21. - Oath, etc., of emergency interim successors. 
    At the time of their designation, emergency interim successors shall take such oath and do such 
other things, if any, as may be required to qualify them to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of 
the office to which they may succeed. 
(Code 1960, § 2-26) 


Sec. 2-22. - Terms of emergency interim successors. 
    A person designated as an emergency interim successor under this article shall hold that designation 
at the pleasure of the designator; provided, that he must be replaced if removed. Such person shall retain 
the designation as emergency interim successor until replaced by another appointed by the authorized 
designator. 
(Code 1960, § 2-23) 


Sec. 2-23. - Powers and duties of emergency interim successors. 
    If, in the event of an attack, any city officer and his duly authorized deputy are unavailable, the 
emergency interim successor highest in rank in order of succession who is not unavailable shall, except 
for the power and duty to appoint emergency interim successors, exercise the powers and discharge the 
duties of such officer. An emergency interim successor shall exercise such powers and discharge such 
duties only until such time as the lawful incumbent officer or any duly authorized deputy or an emergency 
interim successor higher in rank in order of succession exercises, or resumes the exercise of, the powers 
and discharge of the duties of the office, or until, where an actual vacancy exists, a successor is 
appointed to fill such vacancy or is elected and qualified as provided by law. 
(Code 1960, § 2-24) 


Sec. 2-24. - Review and revision of emergency interim successor designations. 
    The officers who designate emergency interim successors pursuant to section 2-19 shall review and, 
as necessary, promptly revise such designations to insure that, at all times, there are at least three (3) 
qualified emergency interim successors or duly authorized deputies, or any combination thereof, for each 
officer specified. 
(Code 1960, § 2-23) 


Sec. 2-25. - Information relative to deputies and emergency interim successors to be filed with city clerk. 
    The name, address and rank in order of succession of each duly authorized deputy shall be filed with 
the city clerk and each designation, replacement or change in order of succession of an emergency 
interim successor shall become effective when the designator files with the city clerk the successor's 
name, address and rank in order of succession. The city clerk shall keep on file all such data regarding 
duly authorized deputies and emergency interim successors, which data shall be open to public 
inspection. 
(Code 1960, § 2-25) 


Sec. 2-26. - Quorum and vote requirements for city commission in event of attack. 
    In the event of an attack, quorum requirements for the city commission shall be suspended, and 
where the affirmative vote of a specified proportion of members for approval of an ordinance, resolution or 
other action would otherwise be required, the same proportion of those voting thereon shall be sufficient. 
(Code 1960, § 2-27) 


Secs. 2-27—2-37. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - INDEMNIFICATION OF CITY OFFICIALS 


Sec. 2-38. - Definition. 
    In this article, the word "official" includes every mayor, city commissioner, officer, agent or employee 
of the city, masculine or feminine, whether elected, appointed or employed, with or without compensation, 
including all advisory board members. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 1, 9-1-71) 


Sec. 2-39. - Preliminary hearing and determinations by commission. 
(a) ?Whenever, in the performance of, or in connection with the performance of, official duties in behalf 
of the city, an official is involved in a dispute, proceeding or litigation, either in a representative or 
personal capacity, with or without the city as a coparty in the matter, the city commission shall 
promptly call a hearing to determine whether the city should undertake his defense. The official shall 
be given ten (10) days' notice before the hearing and shall appear before the commission to present 
his sworn testimony. If the commission, in its sole discretion, concludes that the official acted in good 
faith, the city shall promptly preserve, protect, defend, aid and assist such official. Nothing contained 
in this section shall preclude the city from having a hearing after judgment has been imposed to 
determine whether the city shall be liable for any expenses or judgments. 
(b) ?The decision of the city commission to defend the official, or not to defend the official, shall be 
subject to review by the city commission at any time from the inception of the dispute, proceeding or 
litigation until the determination of the past judgment hearing provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 2(A), 9-1-71) 


Sec. 2-40. - Past judgment hearing and determinations by commission. 
(a) ?At the conclusion of any dispute, proceeding or litigation which has been the subject of a hearing 
under section 2-39, the city commission shall hold another hearing on the matter. The official 
involved shall be given a written notice, at least twenty (20) days before such hearing. Upon 
determination by the commission that the official acted in good faith, the city shall exonerate, 
indemnify and hold harmless such official from and against any and all expenses, liabilities, claims, 
demands, proceedings, damages, losses, charges, advances, disbursements, payments, expenses, 
costs, including reasonable counsel fees, awards, settlements, judgments, decrees and mandates, 
paid, incurred by or imposed upon such official in all disputes, proceedings, trials and appeals, by 
reason of the official being or having been a city official, even though he is no longer an official at the 
time the expenses are incurred or the claims are made against him. The city commission may, for 
good cause, refuse to pay any judgment or decree entered against any official by following such 
procedure after a final judgment or decree, including any appellate proceeding. 
(b) ?If there is a complaint that the official did not act in good faith, such complaint must be in writing and 
a copy thereof served on the official at least twenty (20) days prior to the hearing provided for in this 
section, and it must show that the official did not act in good faith and was guilty of a flagrant, willful 
and intentional violation of a city ordinance or a law of Florida. The notice shall state the particulars 
of the complaint with enough detail so that the official may prepare his defense. 
(c) ?At the hearing provided for in this section, the city and the official shall produce witnesses who shall 
give sworn testimony. 
(d) ?At the conclusion of a hearing under this section, the commission shall make its findings of fact and 
conclusions from the evidence. If the commission shall conclude that the official did not act in good 
faith and was guilty of a flagrant, willful and intentional violation of a city ordinance or a law of 
Florida, then the commission may refuse to pay all or a part of the judgment or decree. 
(e) ?If the official shall willfully fail or refuse to cooperate in his defense, the commission may, to the 
extent that the city was damaged thereby, reduce the protection and indemnification provided under 
this article. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 2, 9-1-71) 


Sec. 2-41. - Duties and authority of city attorney, finance department, etc. 
    All officials of the city are hereby authorized, required and directed to promptly perform any and all 
acts necessary, expedient or proper to carry out the purposes of this article, including, but not limited to, 
the following: 
(1) ?The city attorney or his assistants shall appear in all disputes, proceedings, litigation and 
appellate proceedings, and conduct the same in behalf of the officials involved and are 
authorized to incur costs and expenses. 
(2) ?The finance department shall promptly pay, disburse and reimburse the necessary funds 
required for such costs, expenses and indemnification, and shall, after final hearing and 
determination by the city commission, satisfy any awards, settlements, judgments, mandates or 
decrees recovered or entered against officials. 
(3) ?The city officials shall execute as principal or surety any and all judicial or other bonds, 
including supersedeas or appeal bonds, or post cash or securities in lieu of surety bonds. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 3, 9-1-71) 


Sec. 2-42. - Duties of indemnified official. 
    Each official protected by this article shall promptly cooperate in his own defense and shall: 
(1) ?Attend hearings, trials and depositions and furnish such evidence as shall be needed. 
(2) ?Grant the city full rights of subrogation and the right to recover under any claims, offsets or 
counterclaims of the protected official arising in connection with the controversy involved; 
provided, that if the protected official shall recover any sum, then the city shall deduct all 
disbursements, costs and expenses of litigation including attorneys' fees and any award against 
the city, and the remainder shall belong to the protected official. 
(3) ?Execute and deliver to the city all assignments, papers and documents needed to carry out the 
purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 4, 9-1-71) 


Sec. 2-43. - Payments under article declared to be for municipal purpose; appropriation of funds. 
    The payment of all sums authorized by this article is hereby declared to be for a proper municipal 
purpose and expense, and the appropriation of all funds necessary for such payment is hereby 
authorized and made. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 3, 9-1-71) 


Sec. 2-44. - Application of article when official protected by insurance carried by city. 
    The provisions of this article will only be effective when the official is not fully protected under 
applicable liability insurance carried by the city, or in those instances when the liability carrier defends 
under a reservation of rights clause. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 6, 9-1-71) 


Sec. 2-45. - Application of article after term of office or employment. 
    The protection guaranteed by this article shall exist during and after the term of office or employment 
for liabilities incurred during the term of office or employment. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 6, 9-1-71) 


Sec. 2-46. - Article does not affect liability to general public. 
    The obligation of the city under this article shall extend only to officials, and nothing in this article 
shall extend the liability of the city to the general public, and no act or omission under this article shall 
constitute any waiver of defenses or any admission of liability to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 5, 9-1-71) 


Sec. 2-47. - Political activities. 
(a) ?No employee or elected official of the city shall directly or indirectly coerce or attempt to coerce or 
command any other elected official or employee to pay, lend or contribute any part of his or her 
salary or kick-back any sum of money or anything else of value to any party, committee, 
organization, agency or person for political purposes. 
(b) ?No individual shall use or promise to use, directly or indirectly, any official authority or influence, 
whether possessed or anticipated, to secure or attempt to secure, for any individual an appointment 
to a position in the classified service, or an increase in or other advantage in employment in any 
position, for the purpose of influencing the vote or political action of any person, or for any 
consideration. 
(c) ?No individual elected to public office in the oakland Park shall, during the period of time he or she 
holds such office, be appointed to any position in the classified service in the City of Oakland Park. 
(d) ?The political activities of any officer or employee of the City of Oakland Park, whether in the 
classified or nonclassified service, shall be in accord with and regulated by section 104.31 of the 
Florida Statutes as it may be amended from time to time. Nothing contained in this section shall 
prohibit an employee of the City of Oakland Park from suggesting to another employee in a 
noncoercive manner that he or she may voluntarily contribute to a fund which is administered by a 
party, committee, organization, agency, person, labor union or other employee organization for 
political purposes. Furthermore, nothing contained in this section shall affect the right of the 
employee to hold membership in and support a political party, vote as the employee chooses, 
express opinions on all political subjects and candidates, maintain political neutrality and attend 
political meetings during the employee's off duty hours, provided that no employee in a classified 
service shall represent his or her opinion on political subjects or candidates to be the opinion of or 
the endorsement by the City of Oakland Park. 
(Ord. No. O-93-9, § 2, 9-2-93) 


Sec. 2-48. - Violations. 
    Violation of any provisions of this section of the Code should raise conscientious questions for 
elected officials or any other official or employee of the city as to whether voluntary resignation or other is 
indicated to promote the best interests of the city. Violations may constitute a cause for suspension, 
removal from office or employment or other disciplinary action. 
(Ord. No. O-93-9, § 3, 9-2-93) 


Secs. 2-49—2-56. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IV. - QUASIJUDICIAL PROCEEDINGS 


Sec. 2-57. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of the city to provide an equitable and efficient manner for the city to hear matters 
which are considered quasijudicial in nature. Notwithstanding other provisions in the City Code, sections 
2-57 through 2-60 set forth the city's procedures to be utilized for quasijudicial proceedings. These 
procedures shall be utilized by the city commission in regards to hearings on quasijudicial matters. 
(Ord. No. O-95-8, § 1, 5-17-95) 


Sec. 2-58. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the terms listed below shall be defined as follows: 
    Affected person means an individual (or individuals), business entity or trustee, natural or corporate, 
having title to the subject property or who has title to property within seven hundred fifty (750) feet of the 
subject property as listed in the records of the Broward County property appraiser, or who resides or 
operates a business within seven hundred fifty (750) feet of the subject property. When the subject 
property is developed or proposed to be developed with a single-family home or duplex structure, the 
affected person, as defined above, shall reside or operate a business within three hundred (300) feet of 
the subject property. 
    City commission means the city commission of the City of Oakland Park. 
    Party or parties means the petitioner, city, and any affected person who has requested to be heard at 
the proceeding. 
    Quasijudicial in nature means the application of a general rule or policy to specific individuals, 
interests or activities. 
    Quasijudicial proceeding means hearing held by the city commission to adjudicate private rights of a 
particular person after a hearing which comports with due process requirements, and makes findings of 
fact and conclusions of law on the issue. 
    Site specific means an individual piece of real estate which can be clearly defined by street address, 
legal description or similar means at a single identifiable location. 
(Ord. No. O-95-8, § 1, 5-17-95; Ord. No. O-2009-014, § 2, 7-15-09; Ord. No. O-2016-007, § 2, 7-
20-16 ) 


Sec. 2-59. - Quasijudicial matters. 
(a) ?For the purposes of this article, the following matters, regardless of whether the final determination 
is made by the city commission, shall be considered to be quasijudicial: 
(1) ?Site specific rezoning and site plan; 
(2) ?Conditional use approval; 
(3) ?Variances, including, but not limited to trees, signs, setbacks, distance requirements between 
buildings or other variances permitted by the City Code; 
(4) ?Plat approval; 
(5) ?Special exceptions which relate to the use of land; 
(6) ?Unlisted uses; 
(7) ?Use approval for a restaurant bar, or hotel or motel bar. 
(Ord. No. O-95-8, § 1, 5-17-95; Ord. No. O-96-17, § 2, 10-16-96; Ord. No. O-2008-011, § 2, 3-
5-08) 


Sec. 2-60. - Procedures for quasijudicial proceedings. 
(a) ?Ex parte (oral) communications. City commission members shall avoid ex parte communications 
where they are identifiable. However, it is recognized that in reality, commissioners are elected 
officials and therefore may unavoidably be recipients of unsolicited ex parte communications 
regarding quasijudicial matters for which the city commission will be required to decide. The city 
commissioner shall report the substance of any ex parte (oral) communications which are made to 
them with regard to any quasijudicial matter by any person who has a direct or indirect interest in the 
proceeding, or by any authorized representative or counsel. The ex parte communication shall be 
reported to the city commission at the beginning of the proceedings and such report shall become 
part of the record of the proceedings. The report of the incident shall include the identification of the 
person(s) involved in any ex parte communication. At the proceeding, the party(ies) responsible for 
the ex parte communication shall have the opportunity to contest the accuracy of the communication. 
(b) ?Notification and required forms to be completed by affected persons, the petitioner and the city. 
(1) ?At least ten (10) calendar days prior to the scheduled meeting of the city commission, the city 
clerk shall provide a legal advertisement to be published in a newspaper of general paid 
circulation in Broward County and of general interest and readership in the community, not one 
of limited subject matter. Said notice shall state the name of the petitioner for the requested 
action, the date, time and location of the proceeding, and the location and times where and 
when the petition and any backup information may be reviewed. In addition the notice shall 
inform all affected persons that they will be allowed to present evidence at the hearing, bring 
forth witnesses, and cross examine witnesses provided they notify and file the required forms 
provided by the city clerk's office, the substance of which is described in subsection (d) below, 
at least seven (7) calendar days prior to the proceeding. 
(2) ?No later than ten (10) calendar days prior to the city commission meeting, a mail notice 
containing the same information as the legal advertisement shall be sent to each real property 
owner within seven hundred fifty (750) feet of the subject property as each is listed in the 
records of the county property appraiser. When the subject property is developed or proposed 
to be developed with a single-family home or duplex structure the advertisement radius shall be 
three hundred (300) feet according to the methods described in this section. Mail notice may be 
provided by bulk mail, first class mail or certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(3) ?All cost for notification shall be paid by the petitioner. 
(4) ?Any affected person or individual desiring to testify, present evidence, bring forth witnesses, or 
cross examine witnesses at the proceeding shall complete the required forms provided by the 
city clerk's office which forms shall at a minimum (1) set forth the affected person's name, 
address and telephone number which shall serve as notice to the petitioner and city of the 
affected person's intent to appear at the proceeding to testify, present evidence, bring forth 
witnesses, or cross examine witnesses; (2) set forth the names, addresses and telephone 
numbers of all witnesses including consultants or experts to testify on their behalf; (3) indicate 
whether the affected person is for or against the petition; and (4) indicate how the affected 
person qualifies as an affected person. The required form must be completed and returned to 
the city clerk's office at least two (2) calendar days before the city commission meeting. 
(5) ?The petitioner and the city shall also complete the required forms, provided by the city clerk's 
office, described in subsection (4) above. The completed form shall be returned to the city 
clerk's office within the time frame set forth in subsection (4) above. 
(c) ?Presentation of evidence. 
(1) ?All persons testifying before the city commission must be sworn in. The petitioner or the city 
commission and any affected person who has provided notice with the intention of appearing at 
the city commission meeting shall be given the opportunity to present evidence, bring forth 
witnesses, and cross examine any witnesses. 
(2) ?All evidence relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their business shall 
be admissible, whether or not such evidence would be admissible in a court of law. However, 
immaterial or unduly repetitious evidence shall be excluded. 
(3) ?Heresay evidence may be used for the purpose of supplementing or explaining other evidence, 
but it shall not be sufficient by itself to support a finding. 
(4) ?Documentary evidence may be presented in the form of a copy or the original, if available. 
Upon request, parties shall be given an opportunity to compare the copy with the original. 
(5) ?A party shall be entitled to conduct cross examination when testimony is provided or 
documents are made a part of the record. 
(6) ?The office of the city attorney shall represent the city commission. Any questions as to the 
propriety and admissibility of evidence shall be presented to the city attorney's office in a timely 
fashion. 
(d) ?Procedures for quasijudicial proceedings . The proceedings shall be conducted in an informal 
manner. Each party shall have the right to do the following: 
(1) ?To call and examine witnesses; 
(2) ?To introduce exhibits; 
(3) ?To cross examine opposing witnesses on any relevant matter; and 
(4) ?To rebut evidence. 
(e) ?Conduct of quasijudicial proceedings . To the extent possible, the following shall be the order of the 
proceedings: 
(1) ?Call the proceeding to order and announce the beginning of the proceeding. City 
commissioners must be continuously present during the proceeding. 
(2) ?The matter to be heard and the rules concerning the admissibility of evidence should be 
announced. 
(3) ?Statements of counsel shall only be considered as argument and not be considered as 
testimony. Counsel for parties shall not be subject to cross examination. The city commission 
shall have the authority to refuse to hear any testimony which is irrelevant or repetitive. 
(4) ?The mayor or commissioner presiding at the commission meeting shall have the option of 
determining the order of presentation of the parties in order to expedite the proceeding. During 
its presentation the city shall present any staff, or other reports on the matter as well as any 
comments. These reports shall include, but not be limited to, a description of the request of the 
petitioner; a description/background related to the petition; an analysis which includes the 
consistency with the city's comprehensive plan, if applicable, and how the petition does or does 
not meet the requirements of the City Code; a listing of the exhibits to be presented; a listing of 
potential witnesses; a summarization of the issues; and the staff and board(s) 
recommendations. These reports shall include specific findings in support of justifying a 
recommendation for approval or denial of the petition. 
(5) ?Petitioner, or petitioner's representative, shall make a presentation. The petitioner should 
include a description of the nature of the petition if there is additional information that has not 
been provided by city. In addition the petitioner shall introduce any exhibits and witnesses. 
(6) ?Parties who are in support of the petition shall make their presentation. The party shall 
introduce any exhibits and witnesses. 
(7) ?Parties who are in opposition of the petition shall make their presentation. The party shall 
introduce any exhibits and witnesses. 
(8) ?City personnel in attendance shall provide any responses to any other party to the proceeding. 
(9) ?After each witness testifies or documents are made a part of the record, a party shall be 
permitted to question the witness. The questioning party is not permitted to make any 
statements, only to ask questions which are directly related to the testimony presented. 
(10) ?Final presentation by petitioner in response to any testimony from other parties. 
(11) ?Final presentation by city in response to any testimony from other parties. 
(12) ?The city commission shall deliberate on the petition. No further testimony shall be taken and 
the members of the city commission shall not ask further questions of persons presenting 
testimony. The city commission shall discuss the evidence that was presented at the 
proceeding and vote on the petition. 
(f) ?Final determination by the city commission . In reaching a determination as whether to grant or deny 
the petition, the city commission shall: 
(1) ?Consider whether the petitioner's request is consistent with city's comprehensive plan, if 
applicable, and 
(2) ?State with specificity the reasons for the approval or denial of the petition, 
(3) ?State whether or not the order is to be recorded in the public records of Broward County. 
(g) ?Preparation of the order . The city attorney's office shall prepare the final order of the city 
commission based upon the determination. The final order shall include, but not be limited to, the 
finding of facts, any conditions, requirements or limitations on the approval of the petition, and 
whether or not the order shall be recorded in the Broward County public records. If an ordinance is 
required to be adopted upon approval of an action by the city commission, a final order will not be 
prepared unless the petition is denied. If the order is to be recorded in the public records of Broward 
County, the petitioner shall pay the cost for the recording. 
(h) ?Continuances and deferrals . If, in the opinion of the city commission, any testimony or documentary 
evidence or information presented at the proceeding justifies providing additional time to allow 
additional research or review in order to properly determine the issue presented, the city commission 
shall continue the case to a designated time to allow for the additional research or review. After the 
decision is made to continue, the date to which the proceeding shall be continued shall be 
announced at the city commission meeting. 
(i) ?Transcription of city commission proceedings . The official transcript of a proceeding shall be 
preserved by tape recording or other device by the city clerk's office. Nothing precludes any party 
from providing a court reporter for the proceeding. 
(j) ?Maintenance of evidence and other documents . The office of the city clerk shall retain all the 
evidence and documents presented at the proceeding, except for large scale exhibits which shall be 
retained by the community development department, all of which become a part of the public record 
of the proceeding. 
(k) ?Appeal of final determination by the city commission . The final determination of the city commission 
is subject to judicial review in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. O-95-8, § 1, 5-17-95; Ord. No. O-2009-014, § 3, 7-15-09; Ord. No. O-2016-007, § 3, 
7-20-16; Ord. No. O-2016-007, § 3, 7-20-16 ) 


Secs. 2-61—2-70. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE V. - BOARDS, COMMITTEES AND COMMISSIONS 


Sec. 2-71. - School advisory board. 
(a) ?The city commission of the City of Oakland Park hereby creates a school advisory board consisting 
of seven (7) members. The purpose and duties of the school advisory board are to advise the city 
commission on all issues relating to educational matters which will impact the quality of education for 
city residents, or which will impact education facilities located within the city. Furthermore, the board 
shall endeavor to insure that all community interests are identified as key intended goals and 
therefore, actively engaged in the formulation of a community partnership so as to insure heightened 
participation by all individuals that make up the Oakland Park community. 
(b) ?The school advisory board will be made up of seven (7) members consisting of citizens and 
residents of Oakland Park. Each member of the city commission shall be afforded the opportunity to 
appoint one (1) member to the board. The city manager shall be afforded the opportunity to appoint 
one (1) member and the board shall, as a whole, appoint an at large member who shall be a student 
attending either a high school or middle school located in the city. No member shall be an employee 
of the Broward County School Board. All appointments shall be subject to ratification by the city 
commission. Each member shall serve for a term of one (1) year and the city commission shall 
appoint new members at the first city commission meeting held in the month of August for each year. 
Attendance policy for members of this board is governed by section 2-72 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(c) ?The board shall meet no less than every other month and shall make its recommendations to the 
city commission to assist the commission in gaining an understanding of the goals and objectives 
adopted by the Broward County School Board from time to time which would affect the operation and 
management of the five (5) public schools located within the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2001-026, §§ 2—4, 8-1-01; Ord. No. O-2006-004, § 2, 4-5-06) 


Sec. 2-72. - Attendance policy. 
    If any member is absent from four (4) meetings during a twelve-month period, with or without 
advance notice to the board secretary acting as the liaison to the city commission via the city clerk's 
office, the member's position shall be referred to the city commission for review and consideration of 
vacating the position at the meeting following the fourth absence. The commissioners will be provided 
attendance records, including all documentation related to absences, managed by the board secretary 
when considering whether to retain the board member or appoint a new member. Notwithstanding any 
provision to the contrary, this section shall supersede all provisions in the Code relative to attendance at 
all board meetings. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-004, § 2, 4-5-06; Ord. No. O-2007-021, § 2, 7-18-07) 


Sec. 2-73. - Advisory boards action. 
    All advisory boards of the city shall be required to consider any and all matters brought before it and 
after hearing any evidence and testimony, it shall take action at the meeting in the form of a 
recommendation, either favorable or unfavorable. The recommendation shall then be presented to the 
city commission for its consideration when taking action on the specific matter. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-005, § 2, 4-19-06) 


Secs. 2-74—2-80. - Reserved.

RULE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 


Sec. 2-81. - Purpose of these rules. 
    These rules set forth the principles and procedures that are to be followed by the city in its human 
resources program to ensure that personnel actions are fair and based on merit, and that the citizens of 
Oakland Park may derive the benefits and advantages which can be expected to result from a competent 
staff of city employees. The rules are intended to be consistent with the following fairness, merit and 
efficiency principles: 
(1) ?Recruiting, selecting and advancing employees on the basis of their relative ability, knowledge, 
and skills, including open competition of qualified applicants for initial appointment; 
(2) ?Establishing pay rates consistent with the principle of providing comparable pay for comparable 
work; 
(3) ?Training employees, as needed, to assure high quality performance; 
(4) ?Retaining employees on the basis of the adequacy of their performance, making efforts to 
correct inadequate performance, and separating employees whose inadequate performance 
cannot be corrected; 
(5) ?Assuring fair treatment of applicants and employees in all aspects of human resources 
administration without regard to political affiliation, race, color, creed, national origin or ancestry, 
religion, disability, age, sexual orientation, gender, gender orientation and gender expression, 
and with proper regard for their privacy and constitutional rights; and 
(6) ?Establishing a procedure for the presentation and adjustment of employee grievances. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-006, § 2, 5-3-06; Ord. No. O-2011-014, § 2, 7-6-11) 


Sec. 2-82. - Positions covered by these rules. 
    These rules shall apply to all positions in the city's classified service except as noted in these Rules. 
If there is any conflict between these Rules and a collective bargaining agreement, the provisions of the 
collective bargaining agreement shall control. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-006, § 2, 5-3-06) 


Sec. 2-83. - The city service. 
    The city service shall comprise all offices and positions in the city employ now existing or hereafter 
created. The city service is divided into the following services: 
(a) ?The nonclassified service shall include the following positions and levels: 
(1) ?Elected officials; 
(2) ?The city manager, assistant city manager and assistant to the city manager; 
(3) ?Department heads; 
(4) ?Director—Office of management and budget; 
(5) ?Special projects coordinator; 
(6) ?Public information officer; 
(7) ?Tennis manager; 
(8) ?Engineer construction projects manager. 
(9) ?Community and economic development director; 
(10) ?Manager of technology, strategy and application; 
(11) ?Instructors. 
    Nonclassified personnel may not be assigned the duties of a vacant classified position except on a 
temporary basis or in accordance with civil service rules and regulations. 
    The city manager may, at his or her discretion, employ nonclassified personnel with or without an 
employment contract. The city manager shall have the authority to enter into an employment contract with 
nonclassified employees on behalf of the city. 
    Unless otherwise provided by the authority of the city commission or the city manager, the benefits 
and benefit administration policies outlined herein shall apply to benefit-eligible employees in positions in 
the nonclassified service with the exception that this section shall not be construed to grant such 
employees any property rights to continued employment or grievance, or appeal rights regarding any term 
or condition of their employment. 
(b) ?The classified service shall comprise all other positions now existing or hereafter created not 
specifically included in the nonclassified service. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-006, § 2, 5-3-06; Ord. No. O-2010-010, § 2, 2-17-10; Ord. No. O-2011-014, § 
2, 7-6-11) 


Sec. 2-83.1 - Status of employees in the city service. 
    All persons holding positions in the classified service whose positions normally involve continuous 
year round service, and have completed their respective probationary period, shall be considered to be 
regular full-time or part-time employees and as such entitled to the rights, benefits and privileges 
extended to such employees by the city charter and these rules. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-006, § 2, 5-3-06) 


Sec. 2-84. - Approval of rules. 
    These rules shall be in force and effect when approved by the city commission and shall have the 
force and effect of law insofar as they apply to positions covered by said rules. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-006, § 2, 5-3-06) 


Sec. 2-85. - Interpretation. 
    These rules are intended to cover most personnel issues and actions that will arise. Those situations 
not specifically covered shall be interpreted by the director of human resources with the oversight of the 
city manager, consistent with the overall intent of these rules and regulations, with written city policy, and 
with federal, state, county and city laws or regulations. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-006, § 2, 5-3-06) 


Sec. 2-86. - Enforcement and administration. 
    The responsibility and authority for the enforcement and administration of these rules and regulations 
is vested in the director of human resources and the city manager. The director of human resources is 
authorized to delegate responsibilities assigned to him/her under these rules and regulations to members 
of his/her staff, provided that the director of human resources retains the responsibility to assure that the 
actions of his/her staff are in accord and consistent with these rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-006, § 2, 5-3-06) 


RULE II. - DEFINITIONS 


Sec. 2-87. - Words, terms, phrases defined. 
    Allocation shall mean the act of assigning each position to its proper class. 
    Anniversary date shall mean the date an employee begins employment and the same date in 
following years unless the anniversary date is adjusted consistent with these Rules and Regulations. For 
the purpose of merit increases, the anniversary date shall be the date one year from the effective date of 
his or her last regular merit increase, promotion, or demotion unless the anniversary date is adjusted 
consistent with these Rules and Regulations. 
    Appointing authority shall mean the city manager. 
    Certify shall mean the act of the director of human resources in supplying a department head with 
the names of applicants who are eligible for appointment to the class and position in the classified service 
for which certification is requested.Class, or classification shall mean a position or group of positions 
having similar duties and responsibilities, requiring similar qualifications, which can be properly 
designated by one (1) title indicative of the nature of the work and which carry the same salary range, 
exclusive of any assignment or like pay. 
    Classification description shall mean a written document which generally describes a classification
