(a) ?Conviction . Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article, or convicted of 
knowingly or willfully assisting in the violation thereof, shall be punished as provided by law. 
(b) ?Separate offense . Each separate day a violation continues or is committed, shall be considered a 
separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. O-93-14, § 9, 10-6-93) 
Cross reference— General penalty, continuing violations, § 1-8. 


Chapter 5¼ - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Secs. 5¼-1—5¼-28. - Reserved. 


Chapter 6 - FIRE PREVENTION, SUPPRESSION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Building, construction and minimum housing, Ch. 5; code enforcement board, § 24-
234. 


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 6-1. - Fire department created. 
    A fire department for the city is hereby created and established for the protection of life and property 
from hazardous situations, for the giving of aid in emergencies and for the suppression and prevention of 
fire. 
(Code 1960, § 7-1) 
Cross reference— Police, firefighters and public safety officers retirement system, § 9-61 et 
seq. 


Sec. 6-2. - General powers and duties of fire chief. 
(a) ?The chief of the fire department shall direct the members of the department and it shall be his duty 
to see that the department attends fires promptly and renders efficient service. 
(b) ?The chief of the fire department shall have the authority to promulgate rules and regulations 
governing fire department personnel not in conflict with civil service rules [2] or other laws. 
(c) ?The chief of the fire department shall have charge of all apparatus and equipment belonging to the 
department, including the fire station and sleeping quarters. He shall have authority to have repair 
made upon such equipment when necessary. 
(d) ?It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to make and deliver to the city manager a 
yearly inventory of all equipment belonging to the department. 
(e) ?It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department, or any officer or member thereof designated 
by him, to strictly enforce the provisions of this chapter and any relevant or pertinent sections of this 
Code; to issue legal notices to correct violations; and to take out warrants for the arrest of violators 
failing to comply with any order issued pursuant to the authority of this chapter. 
(Code 1960, §§ 7-1.2, 7-3.6) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Civil service rules, § 2-81 et seq. 


Sec. 6-3. - Fire department divisions. 
    There shall be a fire inspection division of the fire department to perform the duties prescribed for it 
by this chapter and by the chief of the fire department. The chief shall have the authority to establish other 
divisions within the fire department, and rules governing such divisions, with the approval of the city 
manager. 
(Code 1960, §§ 7-1.2, 7-3) 


Sec. 6-4. - Supervision of fires. 
    The fire department shall supervise all fires, and its officers shall have the power to prevent any 
interference with the department or any of its companies or any members thereof in the performance of 
their duties in connection with such supervision. 
(Code 1960, § 7-1.1) 


Sec. 6-5. - Police authority of fire department chief and officers at fires. 
    The chief of the fire department and all fire department officers who may be placed in charge of a fire 
shall have police authority at such fires and shall be in charge of the territory immediately adjacent to the 
fire. 
(Code 1960, § 7-1.2) 


Sec. 6-6. - Destruction of buildings on fire or threatened with fire. 
    No building on fire or threatened with fire shall be blown up, pulled down or otherwise destroyed by 
the fire department or any company or member thereof, except by order of the chief of the fire department 
with the approval of the city manager. 
(Code 1960, § 7-1.2) 


Sec. 6-7. - Obstructing streets during practice drills or parades by fire department. 
    The fire department, when at drill practice or parade, shall not obstruct the streets or public 
thoroughfares for any unreasonable length of time. 
(Code 1960, § 7-1.3) 


Sec. 6-8. - Fire department to review plans for fire extinguishers and location of connections. 
    Prior to the issuance of any building permit for public or commercial building construction, building 
alterations, or the like, a member of the fire department delegated by the fire chief shall review any and all 
plans submitted to evaluate fire extinguishers, and approve the location of fire department connections as 
listed in the building code. 
(Code 1960, § 7-3.20) 
Cross reference— Building code, § 5-1. 


Sec. 6-9. - Drafting sites for pumping water in areas with inadequate fire hydrants. 
    In areas where, in the opinion of the chief of the fire department or his representative, there are 
inadequate fire hydrants to sufficiently protect commercial industries, such as yacht basins, boatyards 
and like places, drafting sites for pumping water, (wells, bodies of water, etc.) must be provided and 
maintained by the occupancy being protected. These drafting locations shall be designated by the chief or 
his representative. 
(Code 1960, § 7-1.4) 


Sec. 6-10. - Permit to handle flammable or hazardous material, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, transport, sell, care for, keep or give away any 
flammables or other substances of like nature, or any materials, compounds, combinations or things 
whatsoever which may tend to increase the fire hazard, or conduct any hazardous business or operation, 
or perform any service of like dangerous character, within the corporate limits of the city, without first 
obtaining a permit from the chief of the fire department. Application for such permit shall be made in 
writing to the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.3) 


Sec. 6-11. - Smoking in places of assembly. 
(a) ?The chief of the fire department or his representative shall order "No Smoking" signs erected in any 
place of public assemblage in the city wherein, in his opinion, smoking would constitute a menace to 
life or property. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke a cigar, pipe or cigarette, or to smoke or burn tobacco 
in any form in any theater or motion picture house or any place in the city where signs containing the 
words "No Smoking" have been posted pursuant to an order of the chief of the fire department or his 
representative. 
(c) ?This section shall not be construed so as to make it unlawful for a performer to smoke on the stage 
during and as part of any theatrical production, or for any person to smoke in smoking areas 
designated as such which have been approved by the chief of the fire department or his 
representative. 
(Code 1960, § 7-3.3) 
Cross reference— Motion picture houses generally, § 7-66. 


Sec. 6-11.1. - Smoking prohibited in certain public places; definitions; posting of signs; penalties. 
(a) ?Definitions. 
(1) ?Public place, for the purposes of this section, means a building or an area within such building 
that is operated by the City of Oakland Park, Florida. 
(2) ?Smoke or smoking includes the carrying of a lighted pipe, lighted cigarette, or lighted cigar, 
containing a tobacco product or any other substance, or the lighting of a pipe, cigar or cigarette 
of any kind. 
(b) ?Prohibitions: The smoking or carrying of a lighted cigarette, cigar or pipe in any public place as 
defined in this section is hereby prohibited, except as provided in subsection (c)(3), hereof. 
(c) ?Posting of signs: 
(1) ?The city manager is hereby authorized to have "no smoking" signs conspicuously posted in or 
about each public place, as designated by the city commission. 
(2) ?Such signs shall read: 
"No Smoking—Oakland Park Ordinance No. O-78-2." 
(3) ?The city manager may specify on such signs as to where, within the public place, smoking is 
prohibited or permitted. 
(d) ?Removal of signs prohibited: No person, other than upon order of the city manager, shall remove or 
cause to be removed, deface, mark upon or damage any sign posted under the authority of this 
section. 
(e) ?Removal from public place: Any person who violates any provisions of this section by smoking in a 
public place where smoking is prohibited is subject to removal from such public place. 
(f) ?Penalties: Any person who violates the provisions of this section by removing, causing to be 
removed, or defacing, marking or damaging any sign posted pursuant to this section shall be 
punished as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. O-78-2, §§ 2—6, 3-1-78) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-78-2, §§ 1—6, adopted March 1, 1978, did not specifically amend 
the Code. Codification herein as § 6-11.1 was, therefore, at the discretion of the editor. 


Sec. 6-12. - Inspections for fire hazards. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to inspect, or cause to be inspected by the 
officers or members of his department, as often as may be necessary, all buildings, premises and public 
thoroughfares, except the interior of private dwellings (unless invited by the owner or occupant), for the 
purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any condition liable to cause fire, or any violation of 
the provisions or intent of the ordinances of the city affecting fire hazards. 
(Code 1960, § 7-3.1) 


Sec. 6-12.1. - Fire inspection fees. 
(a) ?Periodic fire inspections. 
(1) ?Commercial, industrial, institutional and multi-family residential properties may be inspected 
annually by the fire rescue department at no charge. 
(2) ?Single-family and duplex residential properties may be inspected by the fire rescue department 
upon request at no charge. 
(3) ?Alarm systems, extinguishing systems or standpipe systems requiring a witnessed test: 
Minimum fee (up to one (1) hour) ..... $50.00 
Each additional hour, per hour ..... 50.00 
(4) ?Pre-sale, or like inspections, will be charged at a rate of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per hour or 
portion thereof. 
(b) ?Plans examination fees. 
(1) ?Single-family and duplex residential structures, new construction, per structure ..... $30.00 
(2) ?Commercial and residential structures (other than single-family or duplex residential): 
Minimum fee ..... 40.00 
New construction, additions, and alterations: per floor, per square foot ..... 0.015 
(3) ?Sprinkler, alarm, mechanical systems requiring fire rescue department review shall be charged 
at the same rate as the plumbing, electrical or mechanical permit fees as currently adopted. 
(4) ?Land development permit/order Fire Rescue Department review ..... 55.00 
(5) ?Re-examination of plans. If plans must be re-examined because of changes or alterations not 
based on city requirements, a fee equal to one-half (½) the original plan review fee shall be 
charged for each such review. 
(6) ?Plan review fees include required site inspections. If a re-inspection is required due to a missed 
scheduled appointment, non-compliance with plans, etc. a re-inspection fee of forty dollars 
($40.00) shall be charged. 
(c) ?Annual hazardous materials permit fee. A hazardous materials permit is required for more than ten 
(10) gallons of liquid material, or ten (10) pounds of gaseous or solid material, or any combination of 
liquid/gaseous/solid material whose total volume/weight exceeds ten (10) gallon/pounds with a NFPA 
704 hazard rating in any category of two (2) or greater as shown on the material's Material Safety 
Data Sheet (MSDS). A hazardous materials permit is required for any quantity of material with a 
NFPA 704 reactivity or health hazard rating of three (3) or greater. 
Minimum fee ..... $40.00 
Per hazardous material (up to ten (10)) ..... 10.00 
Per additional hazardous material (ten (10) or more) ..... 1.00 
    When the total quantity of liquid hazardous materials exceeds one hundred (100) gallons, or one 
hundred (100) pounds of a gaseous or solid hazardous material, or any combination of materials whose 
total volume/weight exceeds one hundred (100) gallons/pounds, an additional fee of ten dollars ($10.00) 
for each additional one hundred (100) gallons/pounds or portion thereof shall be charged. 
(1) ?Copies of MSDS sheets for materials on premise must be supplied to the fire rescue 
department when requested at the expense of the business owner. 
(2) ?Occupancies with over one hundred (100) gallons of gasoline or fuel oil, or over one hundred 
(100) pounds of natural, propane or compressed gas in any combination will be charged a flat 
fee of one hundred dollars( $100.00) per business location per year. 
(3) ?Occupancies housing five (5) or more hazardous materials exclusively packaged and offered 
for retail sale, will be charged a flat fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per business location per year. 
(4) ?Each occupancy applying for a hazardous material permit is required to submit a complete 
inventory of all chemical and trade names with the highest volume or amount on hand, or 
expected to be on hand at any one time. This amount is the basis for the annual hazardous 
material permit fee. 
(5) ?The hazardous materials permit fee shall be doubled for occupancies failing to obtain a 
hazardous material permit as required, or for occupancies housing quantities of hazardous 
materials in excess of the maximum amounts shown on the hazardous materials permit. 
(d) ?Hydrant flow tests: 
Per test ..... $75.00 
(e) ?Other fees: 
(1) ?Special event permit (carnivals, circuses, open burning, tents, etc.) ..... 110.00 
(2) ?Minor event permit (canopy, sparkler sales, etc.) ..... $55.00 
(3) ?Fire watch for events, inoperable systems, hazardous conditions, etc. (to be paid in advance of 
fire watch), per person, per hour ..... 50.00 
Unpaid fire watch fees become a lien on the property at the time of the fire watch. 
(4) ?Preparation for and appearance before code enforcement board, special master, or other 
board or court for code enforcement action ..... 100.00 
This fee charged only if party is determined by the board or court to be in violation. 
(f) ?Uses of fees. Ten (10) percent off all fees listed in subsections (a)—(e) which are collected shall be 
used for the professional development of fire rescue department personnel. This includes expenses 
related to training, education, educational and reference materials, training equipment, 
memberships, seminars, and conferences which specifically enhance the knowledge, productivity, or 
abilities of fire rescue department personnel, as may be recommended by the fire chief and 
approved by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. O-86-5, § 1, 2-19-86; Ord. No. O-88-24, § 1, 9-21-88; Ord. No. O-1999-012, § 2, 8-
18-99; Ord. No. O-2002-002, § 2, 1-16-02) 


Sec. 6-13. - Closing of buildings where fire hazards exist. 
    Whenever, in the opinion of the chief of the fire department or his representative, there exists a 
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or in his opinion, a hazardous condition exists, the chief, 
or his representative, shall have the power and authority, after reasonable notice, to close the building or 
place where such violation exists until such time as the violation or condition has been corrected and, in 
the opinion of the chief or his representative, such building is safe for use by the public. 
(Code 1960, §§ 7-3.1, 7-3.2) 


Sec. 6-14. - Order to remove fire hazards generally. 
(a) ?Whenever the chief of the fire department or any officer or member thereof shall find any building or 
other structure which, for want of repairs or by reason of age or dilapidated condition or for any other 
cause, is especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger other property, and 
whenever any officer or member shall find in any building or upon any premises or other place, 
combustible or explosive matter or dangerous accumulations of rubbish or unnecessary 
accumulations of wastepaper, boxes, shavings, or other highly flammable materials especially liable 
to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger property, or shall find obstructions to or on fire 
escapes, stairs, passageways, doors or windows liable to interfere with the operations of the fire 
department or egress of occupants in case of fire, the chief of the fire department, or his authorized 
representative, shall order the same to be removed or remedied and such order shall immediately be 
complied with by the owner or occupant of such premises or building. 
(b) ?Service of the order provided for in subsection (a) above shall be made upon the occupant of the 
premises, by either delivering a true copy of the same to such occupant personally or by delivering 
the same to and leaving it with any person in charge of the premises, or in case so such person is 
found upon the premises, by affixing a copy thereof in a conspicuous place on the door to the 
entrance of the premises. Whenever it may be necessary to serve such an order upon the owner of 
the premises, such order may be served in the same manner as upon the occupant of the premises, 
or by mailing such copy to the owner's last known post office address. 
(c) ?It shall be unlawful for any person who has been issued an order under this section to fail to comply 
with such order within the time prescribed therein. 
(Code 1960, § 7-3.6) 
Cross reference— Accumulations of refuse, § 13-31 et seq. 


Sec. 6-15. - Removal of weeds, rubbish, etc., constituting fire hazards. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to inspect or cause to be inspected at least 
twice in each year all lots and lands in the limits of the city, and wherever there are weeds, palmettos, 
wild growth or rubbish upon any lot or parcel of land in the city, which in the judgment of the chief may 
constitute a fire hazard, he shall give five (5) days' notice in writing to the owner, occupant or person 
having control of such lot or parcel of land, requiring the removal of the weeds, palmettos, wild growth 
and rubbish as herein provided. If, at the expiration of the notice, the same shall not have been removed, 
the chief shall summarily proceed to remove the same, or the same may be removed by the city and the 
cost thereof assessed. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.6) 
Cross reference— Removal of dense growths of vegetation generally, § 8-7. 


Sec. 6-16. - Disconnection of defective gas installations. 
    The chief of the fire department or his representative is hereby given authority to order any gas 
company to disconnect its service to any building containing gas installations which, in his opinion, is 
defective. 
(Code 1960, § 7-3.7) 


Sec. 6-17. - Disconnection of hazardous electrical service. 
    The chief of the fire department or his representative is hereby given authority to order the power 
company to disconnect its service to any building which, in his opinion, is hazardous to life or property. 
(Code 1960, § 7-3.8) 


Sec. 6-18. - Emptying waste oil, etc., into streets, waters; storage in buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any oil waste from motors, gasoline pumps or filling 
stations, or any other liquid waste or flammable or combustible material or substance to run or to be 
poured or emptied upon or into the ground of any premises or street; or to allow any such waste or 
flammable or combustible material to accumulate or to be kept in any building, except in a receptacle 
designed for that purpose. Such receptacle shall be emptied when filled and the contents disposed of in 
such a manner as to prevent danger of fire, subject to the approval of the city manager. No one shall pour 
or deposit any oil or oil product in any waters within the city limits except by authority of the city for 
sanitary purposes. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.4) 


Sec. 6-19. - Bonfires. 
    No person shall kindle, maintain or assist in maintaining any bonfire or other exposed fire within the 
city until a permit shall have been issued by the chief of the fire department. Such permit shall require the 
permittee to maintain sufficient, safe control of the fire, to be responsible for all damages therefrom, and 
to completely remove or extinguish all resultant embers and ashes at the close of the fire. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.1) 
State Law reference— Bonfires prohibited near buildings, § 823.02, Fla. Stats. 


Sec. 6-20. - Setting fires by lack of care. 
    Any person who, in smoking or attempting to light or to smoke a cigarette, cigar, pipe or tobacco in 
any form for which lighters or matches are used, or in the use of flammable liquids, through a lack of due 
care or attention, sets fire to any building or any bedding, furniture, curtain, drape or furniture in any 
building in the city shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.5) 


Sec. 6-21. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2008-036, § 2, adopted Nov. 19, 2008, repealed former § 6-21 in its 
entirety which pertained to false alarms and derived from the Code of 1960 and the following: 
Ord. No. O-87-36, § 2, 10-21-87; Ord. No. O-90-3, § 2, 3-7-90; Ord. No. O-92-11, §§ 3—5, 5-6-
92; Ord. No. O-1999-004, § 1, 5-5-99. 


Secs. 6-22—6-32. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - EXPLOSIVES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Manufacture, distribution and use of explosives, Ch. 552, Fla. Stat.; authority of 
city to regulate explosives, § 552.25, Fla. Stats. 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 6-33. - Defined. 
    As used in this article, the word "explosives" shall mean and include dynamite, nitroglycerine, 
detonators, dynamite caps or other high explosives. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.3) 


Sec. 6-34. - State law adopted. 
    The State of Florida Explosives Law is hereby adopted by reference to supplement but not 
supersede the requirements specifically set forth in this article. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.3) 
State Law reference— Manufacture, distribution and use of explosives, Ch. 552, Fla. Stats. 


Sec. 6-35. - Permit to manufacture, transport, sell, store or use. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, transport, sell, keep, store or give away any 
explosive within the city without first obtaining a permit so to do from the chief of the fire department 
or his duly authorized representative. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to use any high explosive in blasting or any other use, without 
first obtaining a permit so to do from the chief of the fire department or his duly authorized 
representative. 
(c) ?Application for a permit required by this section shall be made, in writing, to the chief of the fire 
department. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.3) 


Sec. 6-36. - Transporting in vehicles carrying passengers for hire prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to transport or carry any explosive in or upon any public 
conveyance which is carrying passengers for hire. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.3) 


Sec. 6-37. - Vehicles used for transporting—Smoking, reckless conduct, etc., in or near. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in, upon or near a vehicle containing explosives, to 
conduct himself in or upon such vehicle in a careless or reckless manner, or to load or unload such 
vehicle in a careless or reckless manner or while smoking. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.3) 
State Law reference— Marking of vehicles used to transport explosives, § 316.286, Fla. Stats. 


Sec. 6-38. - Same—Carrying metal, matches, detonators, etc. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to place or carry in the bed or body, or cause to be placed or 
carried in the bed or body, of any vehicle containing explosives, any metal tool or other piece of 
metal, or any matches. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to place or carry or cause to be placed or carried, in any vehicle 
containing explosives, any exploders, detonators, blasting caps or other similar explosive material. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.3) 


Sec. 6-39. - Storage of detonators or dynamite caps. 
    Not more than one thousand (1,000) detonators or dynamite caps shall be kept in one (1) location in 
the city and then only in a protective receptacle apart from any magazine wherein dynamite is stored and 
where they will be securely protected from shock and fire. Such receptacle for the storage of detonators 
or dynamite caps shall not be located within one hundred (100) feet of any main building. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.3) 


Sec. 6-40. - Article not applicable to keeping or sale of small arms ammunition. 
    Nothing in this article shall apply to the ordinary keeping or sale of small arms ammunition by 
hardware stores, sporting goods houses and other mercantile establishments. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.3) 


Secs. 6-41—6-44. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - RESERVED[4] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2014-005, § 2, adopted May 7, 2014, repealed former Div. 2, §§ 6-45—6-51, 
in its entirety which pertained to magazines for storage of dynamite and derived from the Code of 1960, § 
7-2.3. 


Secs. 6-45—6-62. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - FIREWORKS 


Sec. 6-63. - Defined. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "fireworks" shall mean and include any combustible or 
explosive composition, or any substance or combination of substances, or article prepared for the 
purpose of producing a visible or an audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation, 
and shall include blank cartridges, toy pistols, toy cannons, toy canes or toy guns in which explosives are 
used, the type of balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, 
skyrockets, rockets of any type. Roman candles, Dago bombs or other devices of like construction, and 
any device containing any explosive or flammable compound, or any tablet or other device containing any 
explosive substance. The term "fireworks" shall not include auto flares, sparklers, paper caps containing 
not in excess of an average of twenty-five-hundredths (0.25) of a grain of explosive content per cap, and 
toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns or other devices for use of such caps, the sale and use of which shall be 
permitted at all times. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, § 791.01, Fla. Stats. 


Sec. 6-64. - Manufacture prohibited. 
    The manufacture of fireworks within the city limits is prohibited. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.2) 


Sec. 6-65. - Storage, sale and use prohibited; exception and permit for public displays. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to store, offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at retail or use or 
explode any fireworks; provided that, the chief of the fire department shall have power to adopt 
reasonable rules and regulations for the granting of permits for supervised public displays of fireworks by 
the city, fair associations, amusement parks and other organizations. Application for such a permit shall 
be made in writing at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the date of the proposed display. After such a 
permit has been granted, the sale, possession, use and distribution of fireworks for such display shall be 
lawful for that purpose only. No permit granted hereunder shall be transferable. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions and authority of commission to authorize public 
displays, § 791.02, Fla. Stats. 


Sec. 6-66. - Bond or insurance for public displays. 
    At the time of the issuance of a permit under this article for a public display of fireworks, the 
permittee shall furnish a bond or public liability and property damage insurance in an amount of 
$100,000.00/$300,000.00 for the payment of all damages which may be caused either to a person or to 
property by reason of the permitted display, and arising from any acts of the permittee, his agent, 
employees or subcontractors. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.2) 


Sec. 6-67. - Safety requirements for public displays. 
    A public display of fireworks authorized under this article shall be handled by a competent operator 
approved by the chief of the fire department, and such display shall be of such character and so located, 
discharged or fired as, in the opinion of the chief of the fire department, after proper inspection, shall not 
be hazardous to property or endanger any person. Any fireworks that remain unfired after the display is 
conducted shall be immediately disposed of in a way safe for the particular type of fireworks remaining. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, § 791.02, Fla. Stats. 


Sec. 6-68. - Seizure of fireworks found in violation of article. 
    The chief of the fire department or any officer thereof shall seize, take, remove or cause to be 
removed, at the expense of the owner, all stock of fireworks offered or exposed for sale, stored or held in 
violation of this article. 
(Code 1960, § 7-2.2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, § 791.05, Fla. Stats. 


ARTICLE IV. - HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES 


Sec. 6-69. - Hazardous substances; recovery of costs. 
(a) ?Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall be defined as follows: 
    Costs mean those necessary and reasonable costs incurred by the City of Oakland Park in 
connection with investigating, mitigating, minimizing, removing or abating discharges of hazardous 
substances including, but not limited to, the following: actual labor costs of city personnel or its 
authorized agents, costs of equipment operation and rental, cost of expendable items including, but 
not limited to, fire-fighting foam, chemical extinguishing agents, absorbent material, sand, recovery 
drums, acid suits, acid gloves, goggles and protective clothing. 
    Discharge means any intentional or unintentional action or omission resulting in the releasing, 
spilling, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying or dumping of a hazardous substance upon public or 
private property located within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Hazardous substances mean any substances or materials in a quantity or form which, in the 
determination of the chief of fire rescue department and/or emergency management coordinator, or 
his/her authorized designee, poses an unreasonable and imminent risk to the life, health, safety or 
welfare of persons or property within the city and shall include, but not be limited to, those hazardous 
substances listed in the "N.F.P.A. Guide on Hazardous Materials" or the E.P.A.'s list of extremely 
hazardous substances, or the "Florida Substance List" promulgated by the department of labor and 
employment security. 
    Person means one (1) or more individuals, partnerships, corporations, joint ventures, 
associations, or any other entities or any combination thereof. 
(b) ?Abatement, removal; liability for costs; records; exempt costs. 
(1) ?Abatement, removal. The City of Oakland Park Fire Rescue Department is hereby authorized 
to take such steps as necessary to clean up, remove or abate the effects of any hazardous 
substances discharged upon or into public or private property or facilities located within the 
corporate limits of the city including, but not limited to, requested assistance through assistance 
from private sector contractors. 
(2) ?Liability for costs. Any person or persons responsible for causing or allowing an unauthorized 
discharge of hazardous substances that requires emergency action by the city fire rescue 
department or its authorized agents in order to protect the public health, safety or welfare shall 
be jointly and severally liable to the city for the costs incurred by the city in investigating, 
mitigating, minimizing, removing and abating any such discharge. 
(3) ?Record of costs. When responding to the emergency caused by the unauthorized discharge of 
hazardous substances, the city park fire rescue department shall keep a detailed record of the 
costs attributable thereto. 
(4) ?Exempt costs. The authority to recover costs under this section shall not include costs incurred 
for actual fire suppression services which are normally or usually provided by the city fire rescue 
department or its authorized agents. 
(c) ?Reimbursement of costs; penalties, remedies for failure to reimburse. 
(1) ?Reimbursement. Any person or persons responsible for causing or allowing an unauthorized 
discharge of hazardous substances shall reimburse the city for the full amount of all costs, as 
defined herein, associated with the investigating, mitigating, minimizing, removing and abating 
of any such discharge within a period of thirty (30) days after receipt of an itemized bill for such 
costs from the city. 
(2) ?Penalties. Any person or persons responsible for causing or allowing an unauthorized 
discharge of hazardous substances and who fails to reimburse the city within the time set forth 
in subsection (c)(1) hereof shall be subject to a fine equal to the greater of one hundred dollars 
($100.00) per day or ten (10) percent of the total amount of the bill for each additional day that 
the bill for such costs remains unpaid. 
(3) ?Remedies. The remedy provided for in this section shall be supplemental to and in addition to 
all other available remedies at law and equity. 
(d) ?Cost recovery. 
(1) ?Generally. Any person(s) responsible for causing or allowing a discharge or threatened 
discharge of any hazardous substances which require response actions by the city fire rescue 
department and/or regional hazardous materials response team, in order to protect the public 
health, safety, welfare, or the environment shall be required to reimburse the city for the full 
amount of the cost of any and all response actions. When responding to an emergency caused 
by a discharge or threatened discharge of hazardous substances, the responding regional 
hazardous materials team shall keep a detailed record of the costs of all response actions. The 
cost of all response actions shall be calculated in accordance with the following scheduled. 
(2) ?For all incidents of less than one-hour duration, the responsible party shall reimburse the city 
for the costs of all expendable supplies used during response actions, including, but not limited 
to: Firefighting foam, chemical extinguishing agents, recovery drums, absorbent materials, 
protective clothing, gloves and testing equipment. 
(3) ?For all incidents of one (1) hour or greater in duration, the responsible party shall reimburse the 
city for the costs of all expendable supplies used during response actions, the costs of 
equipment and apparatus used during response actions and the actual labor costs of personnel 
assigned to the responding regional hazardous materials response team. The cost of equipment 
and apparatus shall be calculated in accordance with the current resource typing rate schedule, 
as listed by the Federal Emergency Management Agency and as periodically amended. 
(4) ?Further, the city may invoice the responsible party for the allowable cost of those municipal 
services which were required to support the emergency response team its emergency response 
actions, including, but not limited to, law enforcement and public works services. 
(5) ?For the purpose of this article, "duration" shall be considered as the time period beginning with 
the arrival on scene of the first emergency response team member and ending with the release 
of the last emergency response team member from the scene and the return to their home 
station. 
(e) ?Authority to recover costs. The City of Oakland Park is hereby authorized to invoice and collect the 
emergency response costs from the responsible party. In the event that the responsible party does 
not reimburse the city for the recoverable costs, the city is authorized to seek reimbursement 
consistent with the applicable provisions of the City of Oakland Park Code of Ordinances or any 
other lawful means. 
(Ord. No. O-89-19, § 2, 11-15-89; Ord. No. O-2011-003, § 2, 2-2-11) 


ARTICLE V. - USER FEES FOR AMBULANCE SERVICE 


Sec. 6-70. - Ambulance user fees. 
(a) ?The fee for ambulance services provided by the city are as follows: 
Basic life support ambulance transport service (per transport/per patient ..... $670.00 
Advanced life support-1 ambulance transport service (per transport/per patient) ..... 700.00 
Advanced life support-2 ambulance transport service (per transport/per patient) ..... 750.00 
Transport mileage (per mile) ..... 10.00 
Administration of IV solution ..... 32.00 
Cardiac monitor ..... 25.00 
Cervical collar and/or backboard ..... 25.00 
Intubation ..... 25.00 
Medications (other than oxygen) ..... 27.50 
Oxygen ..... 28.50 
Amounts paid by Medicaid, Medicare or private insurance toward the cost of ambulance services 
shall be accepted by the city as partial payment. 
(b) ?The city manager is authorized to approve any and all adjustments and settlements as may be 
presented by the finance director. Each adjustment or settlement shall be based on the merits of that 
account or patient and shall have no bearing on other accounts or patients. 
(Ord. No. O-93-2, § 1, 2-17-93; Ord. No. O-1999-014, § 2, 9-1-99; Ord. No. O-2001-029, § 2, 9-
19-01; Ord. No. O-2005-029, § 2, 9-21-05; Ord. No. O-2011-018, § 2, 9-7-11) 


Chapter 6½ - HEALTH AND SANITATION 


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Secs. 6½-1—6½-10. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - RODENT CONTROL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-76-10, adopted May 5, 1976, did not expressly amend this Code; hence, 
inclusion herein as §§ 6½-11—6½-23 is at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference— Code enforcement board, § 24-234. 


Sec. 6½-11. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the following definitions shall apply: 
(a) ?Building . Any business building, nonbusiness building and multifamily building, as hereinafter 
defined. 
(b) ?Business building . Any structure, whether public or private, that is adopted for occupancy for 
the transaction of business, for rendering of professional service, for amusement, for the 
display, sale or storage of goods, wares or merchandise, or for the performance of work or 
labor, including hotels, apartment buildings, tenement houses, rooming houses, office buildings, 
public buildings, stores, theaters, markets, restaurants, grain elevators, warehouses, 
workshops, factories and all other outhouses, sheds, barns and other structures used for 
business purposes. 
(c) ?Nonbusiness building . Any structure, whether business or private, that is used or adapted for 
the use of human habitation and is not hereinabove defined as a business building. 
(d) ?Occupant . The individual, partnership or corporation that has the use of or occupies any 
building, or a part or fraction thereof, whether the actual owner or tenant. In the case of a vacant 
building or any vacant portion of a building, the owner shall have the responsibilities of an 
occupant. 
(e) ?Owner . The actual owner of the building, whether individual, partnership or corporation, 
including committees and trustees, except trustees under a mortgage or deed of trust. 
(f) ?Ratproofing . The term "ratproofing" as used herein applies to a form of construction to prevent 
the ingress of rats into buildings from the exterior, or from one building or establishment to 
another. It consists essentially of treatment with material impervious to rat gnawing of all actual 
or potential openings in exterior walls, ground or first floors, basements, roofs and foundations 
that may be reached by climbing or by burrowing. 
(g) ?Rat harborage . The term "rat harborage" shall mean any condition which provides shelter or 
protection for rats, thus favoring their multiplication and continued existence in, under or outside 
of any structure. 
(h) ?Rat eradication . The term "rat eradication" means the elimination or extermination of rats 
within buildings by any or all of the accepted measures, such as: Poisoning, fumigation, 
trapping and clubbing. 
(i) ?Health officer . The term "health officer" as used herein means the chief building official of the 
City of Oakland Park, or the director of the Broward County health department or any duly 
authorized representative of either. 
(j) ?Ratstoppage . A method of preventing the ingress of rats from the exterior into nonbusiness 
buildings, consisting essentially of closing, with material impervious to rat gnawing, all openings 
in floors and exterior walls and the proper screening of doors and windows within four (4) feet of 
the ground. 
(Ord. No. O-74-10, § 1, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-12. - All buildings to be ratproofed and freed of rats. 
    All business and nonbusiness buildings of the city shall be ratproofed, freed of rats and maintained in 
a ratproof and rat-free condition in accordance with established specifications and under the supervision 
of the health officer. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, § 2, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-13. - Notification by health officer to ratproof and ratstop buildings; time limitations. 
    Upon receipt of written notice or order from the health officer, the owner of any business building 
specified therein shall take immediate measures for ratproofing such building, and upon receipt of like 
notice or order the owner of any nonbusiness building shall take immediate measures for ratstopping 
such buildings. Unless such ratproofing and ratstoppage shall be completed by the owner in the time 
specified in the written notice or order, in no event to be less than fifteen (15) days, or within the time to 
which a written extension may have been granted by the health officer, such owner shall be guilty of an 
offense under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, § 3, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-14. - Buildings to be maintained in ratproof condition. 
    The occupants of all ratproofed buildings are required to maintain the premises in a ratproof 
condition and to repair all breaks or leaks that may occur in the ratproofing, unless such breaks or leaks 
develop as the result of natural deterioration of the building. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, § 4, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-15. - Removal of ratproofing or ratstoppage unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for the occupant, owner, contractor, public utility company, plumber or any other 
person to remove the ratproofing or ratstoppage from any building for any purpose and fail to restore the 
same in a satisfactory condition, or to make any new openings that are not closed or sealed against the 
entrance of rats. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, § 8, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-16. - Unannounced inspections. 
    The health officer is empowered to make such unannounced inspections of any property, including 
the interior and exterior of any building, as in his opinion may be necessary to determine full compliance 
with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, § 6, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-17. - Closing of occupied business buildings affording extensive rat harborage. 
    Whenever, in the opinion of the health officer, conditions inside or under occupied business buildings 
provide extensive harborage for rats, said health officer is empowered, after due notification in 
accordance with section 6½-3, to close such business buildings until such time as the conditions are 
abated by ratproofing and harborage removal, including, if necessary, the installation of suitable concrete 
floors in basements, replacement of wooden first or ground floors with concrete, or other major repairs 
necessary to facilitate rat eradication. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, § 5, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-18. - Authority of health officer to require specific action to correct interior rat harborage. 
    Whenever conditions inside or under any building provide such extensive harborage for rats that the 
health officer deems it necessary to eliminate such harborage, he may require the owner to install 
suitable cement floors in basements or to replace wooden first or ground floors or require the owner to 
correct such other interior rat harborage as may be necessary in order to facilitate the eradication of rats 
in a reasonable time and thereby to reduce the cost thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, § 7, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-19. - Conditions promoting rat harborage unlawful. 
(a) ?Within the corporate limits of the city, all garbage or refuse consisting of waste animal or vegetable 
matter upon which rats may feed, and all small dead animals, shall be placed and stored, until 
collected by the garbage department, in covered containers of a type prescribed by the health officer 
according to existing conditions. It is hereby declared unlawful for any person to dump or place on 
any premises, land or waterway, any dead animals or any waste vegetable or animal matter of any 
kind. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to place, leave, dump or permit to accumulate any garbage, 
rubbish or trash in any building or premises in the city so that the same shall or may afford food or 
harborage for rats. 
(c) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to permit to accumulate on any premises, improved or vacant, 
and on all open lots and alleys in the city any lumber, boxes, barrels, bricks, stones or similar 
materials that may be permitted to remain thereon, unless same shall be placed on open racks that 
are elevated not less than eighteen (18) inches above the ground, and evenly piled or stacked so 
that these materials will not afford harborage for rats. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, §§ 9-11, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-20. - Inspection for and eradication of rat infestation as condition for demolition permit. 
    Prior to issuance of a permit for demolition of a building, an inspection has to be made by a 
representative of the health officer to determine if the structure is harboring rodents. If the building is 
infested, eradication is necessary and must be completed prior to issuance of a permit for demolition. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, § 12, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-21. - Access of health officer to property. 
    The health officer or his designee shall not be denied access to any property or building for the 
purpose of eradication (setting traps, baiting, etc.) of rats or rodents in the interest of health or safety for 
the general public of Oakland Park. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, § 15, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-22. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be 
punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00), and each day's continuance of a violation 
shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, § 13, 5-5-76) 


Sec. 6½-23. - Cooperation between local government agencies; notification requirement. 
    The chief building official of Oakland Park and the director of the Broward County health department 
or their duly authorized representative shall work in a coordinated effort to carry out the provisions of this 
article. If either party exercises his power provided by sections of this article, he shall notify the other in 
writing within seven (7) days from date of action. 
(Ord. No. O-76-10, § 14, 5-5-76) 


Chapter 7 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1]
