ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 7-1. - Soliciting sales by loud, obscene, etc., methods. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit sales of goods, wares, merchandise, real estate or any 
other thing or service whatsoever upon the streets, avenues, parks, parkways or public places in the 
city, in a manner which shall disturb the peace of others or by violent conduct or carriage or by loud 
and unusual noise or by profane or obscene language or in any manner whatsoever calculated to 
provoke a breach of the peace. 
(b) ?Any person who shall be convicted of violating any of the provisions of this section shall be subject 
to have any occupational license, privilege or permit previously granted by the city revoked by the 
court, in its discretion. 
(Code 1960, § 16-8) 
Cross reference— Noise generally, § 8-46 et seq. 


Sec. 7-2. - Identification of motor vehicles used in business; descriptive lettering required. 
(a) ?Any truck or other motor-driven vehicle operated or used in connection with any business, 
occupation or profession in the city, or which is dispatched from a fixed location within the city shall 
have prominently displayed on each side thereof, the following information: 
(1) ?The grade name, symbol or "logo" of the person or individual utilizing the vehicle for a 
commercial or business purpose; 
(2) ?The general nature or character of the business if the trade name or symbol does not describe 
the general nature of the business; 
(3) ?The street address of the business, or if there is none, then the resident street address of the 
person owning or operating the business or the telephone number of the business, or if none, 
the telephone number of the person owning or operating the business. 
(b) ?The information required to be placed upon a commercial vehicle by subsection (a) of this section 
shall be in bold letters and numerals at least one and one-half (1½) inches high distinctly contrasting 
in color with the background and permanently fixed to the vehicle in such a manner so as to be 
readily distinguishable, from a distance of not less than thirty (30) feet. 
(c) ?There shall be exempt from the provisions of this section all vehicles which are: 
(1) ?Used primarily in interstate commerce and duly licensed by a federal or state agency and 
which have no fixed bases of operation within Broward County, Florida; 
(2) ?Taxicabs or limousines; 
(3) ?Implements of husbandry; 
(4) ?Consigned to any licensed motor vehicle franchise operated within Broward County and not 
otherwise sold, rented or leased; 
(5) ?Owned or operated by the United States, the State of Florida, the City of Oakland Park or any 
political subdivisions thereof; 
(6) ?Owned or operated by franchised utilities licensed by the Florida Public Service Commission 
and which are conspicuously marked or painted with the name, symbol or trademark of the 
utility; 
(7) ?Owned or operated by state regulated and licensed firms or individuals and where the state 
requires such persons to identify the vehicles used in their trade or profession; 
(8) ?Used only for personal transportation and not for any business or commercial purpose; 
(9) ?Classified or known as passenger automobiles and designed for the carriage of people; 
(10) ?Used for the collection or carriage of cash money or negotiable securities. 
(d) ?Anything in this section to the contrary notwithstanding, magnetic signs may be used on pickup 
trucks which do not have an enclosed or covered rear storage area. 
(Code 1960, § 10-9; Ord. No. O-86-9, § 1, 3-5-86) 


Sec. 7-2.1. - Enforcement of section 7-2. 
    All law enforcement officers, code enforcement officers, and building officials employed by the City of 
Oakland Park shall have the power and authority to enforce the provisions of this section and section 7-2. 
(Ord. No. O-86-9, § 2, 3-5-86) 
Editor's note— Sections 2 and 3 of Ord. No.O-86-9, adopted March 5, 1986, added §§ 7-10 and 
7-11 to Ch. 7. At the discretion of the editor, said sections have been redesignated §§ 7-2.1 and 
7-2.2, respectively, in order to keep related provisions together. 


Sec. 7-2.2. - Penalties for violation of sections 7-2 or 7-2.1. 
(a) ?Any person violating any provision of sections 7-2 or 7-2.1 shall be punished pursuant to section 1-
8. 
(b) ?Each separate day of operation or use of a commercial vehicle in violation of sections 7-2 or 7-2.1 
shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. O-86-9, § 3, 3-5-86) 
Note— See the editor's note following § 7-2.1. 


Sec. 7-3. - Contractor's liability insurance. 
    Before a license shall be issued to any contractor or subcontractor, the contractor shall file with the 
chief building official a certificate signed by a qualified agent of an insurance company stating that a 
policy or policies have been issued to the licensee for public liability insurance and public property 
damage insurance in the sum of not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); the minimum limits of 
each; the policy number or numbers; the name of the company or companies; the effective date of each; 
the expiration date of such policy or policies; together with a statement and a copy of an endorsement 
placed on such policy or policies requiring five (5) days' written notice by registered mail to the chief 
building official, if it becomes necessary to cancel the policy or policies for any reason. In the event of 
cancellation, the contractor shall be required to furnish a new certificate in full compliance with this 
section within ten (10) days. Failure to do so shall result in the license being automatically revoked at the 
end of such time. 
(Code 1960, § 10-8) 
Cross reference— Relocation of buildings or structures into or within the city, permit and bond 
required therefor, § 5-8; license tax for contractors, § 7-22(74). 


Sec. 7-4. - Permit to engage in refuse collection business, supplying a compactor, roll-off or cardboard 
recycling container. 
(a) ?Definitions. 
(1) ?For the purposes of this section: 
    "Collection capacity" shall be defined as the potential monthly collection volume of a 
container, including roll-off containers or compactor containers, and is determined by multiplying 
its capacity by the compaction ratio times the number of times the container is emptied during 
the month in question. 
    "Compactor" shall be defined as a refuse reduction system, including storage container, 
which turns loose refuse into small, compact objects by use of a mechanical system that 
compresses said loose refuse or recyclable cardboard material into bundles or containers to 
reduce their volume. 
    "Roll-off" shall be defined as a large portable container used on a temporary basis for 
disposal and removal of refuse, or recyclable cardboard materials. 
(2) ?For the purpose of user fee determination, the "volume or capacity of a container" is the 
measured volume of the container in cubic yards enclosed within its bottom, top, and sides. 
(b) ?Any person desiring to provide compactor, roll-off, or container services within the city shall apply to 
the chief building official for a permit. In order for the chief building official to issue said permit, the 
following shall be set forth by the applicant: 
(1) ?Name and address; 
(2) ?Trade name under which applicant proposes to do business; 
(3) ?Nature and character of the services the applicant proposes to render; 
(4) ?The experience applicant has in rendering such service; 
(5) ?Any other information as the building official may require. 
(c) ?When a new permit is applied for or when a permit is renewed, licensed private contractors shall 
supply the city, on a form and in manner prescribed and approved by the building official, information 
concerning all accounts served within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Each month during the term of a permit, by the twentieth calendar day of the month, each licensed 
private collector shall supply the city with the following information on a form and in the manner 
prescribed and approved by the building official. 
(1) ?A statement of changes in the status of accounts serviced by the licensed private collector 
within the city. 
(2) ?The total collection capacity of all accounts serviced during the previous month within the city. 
(d) ?All information submitted by the contractor should accurately reflect the status of all accounts within 
the city and shall be subject to audit by city officials. Licensed private collectors will retain for a 
minimum of five (5) calendar years all information they possess concerning accounts serviced by 
them within the city. 
(e) ?A permit issued under this section shall be for one (1) year and may be canceled at any time for 
inadequate precaution in collection or disposal, littering of streets, alleys, or roads or interfering with 
and hindering the city's solid waste or recycling services. 
(f) ?Solid waste services. Upon providing the necessary information, applicants shall be entitled to a 
permit for a period of one (1) year, provided: 
(1) ?The applicant shall pay the city an annual fee of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) 
for compactor container service or two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for roll-off 
container service. All monies collected shall be transferred to the solid waste budget. 
(2) ?In addition to the above annual fee, permitted private solid waste contractors shall be charged 
a monthly usage fee of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) per cubic yard of the total collection 
capacity of all accounts, serviced by them within the city exclusive of materials that will be 
recycled and are collected in designated cardboard recycling containers. 
(3) ?Permitted private collector usage fees due the city will be calculated by the permitted private 
collector in the manner prescribed by the finance department and be based upon the total 
monthly collection capacity in cubic yards of all accounts serviced by them in the city and the 
current usage fee rates per cubic yard of collection capacity. Usage fees are due and payable to 
the city by the twentieth of the previous month within which the collection and/or services were 
provided. 
(4) ?Permitted private collectors who do not pay usage fees when due will be assessed a penalty of 
one (1) percent per month calculated daily on the unpaid balance of all fees due. The date of 
arrival at the city will be used to determine the amount of penalty levied. Billings for penalties 
shall be calculated and billed monthly and are due and payable upon receipt. 
(g) ?Recycling of cardboard materials. Upon providing the necessary information, including but not 
limited to monthly weight reports, collectors shall be entitled to a permit for a period of one (1) year to 
bundle, bale, store and transport recyclable cardboard materials. The applicant shall pay the city an 
annual permit fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00). All monies collected shall be transferred to the 
solid waste budget. 
(h) ?Licensed private collectors operating within the city shall dispose of recyclables, garbage, trash, 
yard trimmings, construction debris, demolition debris, and/or similar waste material at a site or sites 
designated by the city and will comply with all city, county, state and federal regulations pertaining to 
the collection, transportation, recycling, and disposal of solid waste, recyclables and hazardous 
materials. 
(i) ?If the building official or designee identifies an unpermitted roll-off or recycling container within the 
city, the building official shall notify the public works department which will have the container 
removed. The container will be returned to the owner upon payment of the applicable permit fee as 
designated under paragraph (f) or (g). 
(Ord. No. 533,§ 1, 5-5-71; Ord. No. O-85-32, § 1, 12-4-85; Ord. No. O-88-37, § 1, 12-7-88; Ord. 
No. O-91-7, § 2, 7-17-91; Ord. No. O-93-7, § 2, 6-2-93; Ord. No. O-98-23, § 1, 10-21-98) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, Ch. 13. 


Sec. 7-5. - Junkyards. 
(a) ?Junkyards as defined in subsection 7-5(b) are a prohibited use in the City of Oakland Park. 
(b) ?For the purposes of this section, a "junkyard" is any place where two (2) or more motor vehicles not 
in running condition, or parts thereof, are stored and are not being restored to operation, or any place 
used for wrecking or storing of such motor vehicles or farm machinery, or parts thereof, and not 
being restored to operating condition, or any area where junk is bought, sold, exchanged, stored, 
baled, packed, disassembled or handled. As used herein, the word "junk" shall be deemed to be any 
personal property which is or may be salvaged for reuse, resale, reduction or similar disposition, or 
which is possessed, transported, owned, collected, accumulated, dismantled or assorted for any of 
the aforesaid purposes. Used household furniture, used wearing apparel, used lumber, used brick, 
used tile, used plumbing fixtures, used electrical fixtures, used articles made of precious metal or 
metals, used jewelry, used tools and other used articles of personal property, which are bought and 
sold as secondhand property and which are not handled as what is ordinarily called "junk" or 
salvaged material shall not be included in the term "junk" as used herein. Without limiting the 
aforesaid definition of "junk," the term shall include used or salvaged iron, brass, lead, copper and 
other base metal or metals, and their compounds or combinations; used or salvaged rope, bags, 
paper, rags, glass, rubber and similar articles or property; and used motor vehicles which are used, 
owned or possessed for the purpose of wrecking or salvaging parts therefor. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.2; Ord. No. O-2014-006, § 2, 5-7-14) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, Ch. 13; abandoned property, Ch. 23. 


Sec. 7-6. - Permit to engage in waste tire collection business. 
(a) ?Definition. For the purpose of this section, "waste tire collection business" shall be defined as a 
business which mechanically or manually collects waste tires from any individual or other business 
for disposal at any site licensed by the State of Florida Department of Environmental Regulation. 
(b) ?Any person desiring to provide waste tire collection services within the city shall apply to the 
sanitation department for a permit. 
(c) ?In order for the sanitation department to issue a permit, the following information shall be provided 
by the applicant: 
(1) ?Name and address of the applicant; 
(2) ?Trade name under which the applicant proposes to do business; 
(3) ?Nature and character of the service the applicant proposes to render; 
(4) ?The experience the applicant has in rendering such service; 
(5) ?Any other information which the chief sanitation official may require; 
(6) ?A copy of the State of Florida Department of Environmental Regulation permit. 
(d) ?A permit issued under this section shall be valid for one (1) year and may be cancelled by the 
sanitation department for inadequate precaution in collection or disposal of waste tires. Inadequate 
precaution in collection or disposal of waste tires may be evidenced by the littering of public or 
private property or by interfering with or hindering of city garbage and water collection services. If the 
sanitation department determines that there has been inadequate precaution, a notice of intent to 
revoke the waste tire permit shall be issued. Said permit shall be deemed revoked thirty (30) days 
after issuance of the notice unless withdrawn by the sanitation department. After receipt of said 
notice, the holder of the permit may seek review of the revocation with the sanitation department. 
(e) ?Upon providing the necessary information, the applicant shall be entitled to a permit for a period of 
one (1) year, provided, however, that the applicant shall pay the city an annual fee of five hundred 
dollars ($500.00). All monies collected shall be transferred to the refuse fund budget. 
(f) ?The permit for waste tire collection services may be cancelled as set forth in subsection (d) or for any 
other due cause as determined by the sanitation department. 
(Ord. No. O-89-9, § 1, 6-21-89) 


Sec. 7-7. - Minors prohibited in poolrooms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or any employee thereof operating any commercial pool or billiard 
hall or saloon or room in the city or operating any place where pool or billiards are publicly played, and in 
which alcoholic beverages are sold or dispensed, to permit or allow any person under eighteen (18) years 
of age to play pool or billiards or visit or loiter in any pool or billiard hall or saloon or room in the city or 
place where pool or billiards are publicly played. 
(Code 1960, § 13-33) 
Cross reference— Minors not permitted in room where alcoholic beverages dispensed, § 3-16; 
curfew for minors, § 8-10. 


Sec. 7-8. - Soundproofing of poolrooms and bowling alleys operated after midnight. 
    Any person who shall keep open a room containing billiard or pool tables, or bowling or tenpin alleys 
for the purpose of playing after 12:00 midnight shall be deemed guilty of an offense, unless the rooms 
containing billiard tables, pool tables, tenpin or bowling alleys are housed in a soundproof building. 
(Code 1960, § 13-7) 
Cross reference— Noise generally, § 8-46 et seq. 


Sec. 7-9. - Special events. 
(a) ?Special event shall mean the temporary use of public or private property for any meeting, activity, 
parade, or gathering for civic, philanthropic, cultural, educational, religious or similar purposes, which 
substantially inhibits the normal flow of pedestrian or vehicular travel or which deviates from the 
established use of the property. 
(b) ?Submittal of application. 
(1) ?A complete application shall be submitted no later than thirty (30) days prior to the 
commencement of an event along with a non-refundable application fee based on the following 
schedule: 
a. ?Submitted more than sixty (60) days before the event ..... $250.00 
b. ?Submitted between forty-five (45) and fifty-nine (59) days before the event ..... $350.00 
c. ?Submitted between forty-four (44) and thirty (30) days before the event ..... $450.00 
(2) ?An applicant for a special event which is a Florida-certified not for profit organization shall be 
exempt from payment of the pre-application fee. 
(3) ?The application date shall be deemed to be that date on which all required documents have 
been submitted. 
(4) ?The application shall include a legible and dimensioned site plan which provides the following 
information: 
a. ?Existing improvements. 
1. ?Permanent structures. 
2. ?Off-street parking spaces. 
3. ?Sidewalks. 
4. ?Driveways. 
5. ?Exterior lighting. 
6. ?Fences, walls or hedges. 
7. ?Drainage ponds or retention areas. 
b. ?Temporary improvements. 
1. ?Tents or canopies. 
2. ?Portable restrooms. 
3. ?Solid waste containers or receptacles. 
4. ?Stages. 
5. ?Mechanical rides, bounce houses and similar equipment. 
6. ?Fencing. 
7. ?Size, character and location of signage. 
c. ?Live animals. 
(c) ?Site requirements. Within fifteen (15) working days of receipt of a complete application, the planning 
and zoning division shall determine whether the application complies with all criteria enumerated 
below: 
(1) ?The property shall be located and the event situated so as not to disturb the peace and quiet of 
nearby residents. 
(2) ?There shall be sufficient off-street parking spaces available so as not to cause congestion and 
obstruction of adjacent residential streets. 
(3) ?There shall be adequate open space to accommodate all proposed temporary improvements 
associated with the event. 
(d) ?If the determination is in the affirmative, the application along with the permit fee will be forwarded to 
the special events committee for review and approval. The amount of the permit fee shall be the 
amount necessary to recoup expenses for the provision of city services including, but not limited to 
installation of water meters, barricades, street closures, police and fire services, or other necessary 
city services as determined by the special events committee. An applicant for a special event which 
is a Florida-certified not for profit organization shall be exempt from payment of the permit fee. 
(e) ?Special events committee. 
(1) ?Within thirty (30) working days of receipt of the application, the special events committee and 
city manager or his/her designee shall review and issue an approval letter including any 
necessary conditions. 
(2) ?The letter shall be prominently posted on site during the event. 
(f) ?Other requirements. 
(1) ?The applicant shall furnish additional information requested by either the planning and zoning 
division or the special events committee which is reasonably necessary to make a 
determination of approval, denial or approval with conditions. 
(2) ?All necessary building permits, inspections, licenses, insurance, and other approvals shall be in 
place prior to commencement of any special event. 
(g) ?Failure to obtain a special event approval prior to the commencement of any event or to comply with 
any condition of approval shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(h) ?Failure to obtain necessary building permits and inspections prior to the day of commencement of 
the event shall be grounds for a city code enforcement or law enforcement officer to shut down the 
event until all necessary permits and inspections are obtained. 
(i) ?Activities taking place on properties, the principal use of which is a single-family residence, and 
which activities are customary and incidental functions related to a single-family residence including, 
but not limited to, birthday parties and similar celebrations, family reunions and similar gatherings are 
not intended to be regulated by these provisions and are exempted therefrom. 
(j) ?Block parties are not required to obtain a special event permit and are regulated pursuant to section 
21-04, Code of Ordinances (Temporary closing of streets to traffic). 
(Code 1960, § 13-8.1; Ord. No. O-74-29, §§ 1—4, 3-5-75; Ord. No. O-2008-033, § 2, 10-1-08) 


Sec. 7-10. - Occupational license tax equity study board. 
(a) ?Created; meetings . The city commission hereby creates an occupational license tax equity study 
board consisting of nine (9) members. Membership shall include occupational licensees in the 
following categories: Retail, hotel/motel, wholesale/distribution, manufacturing, professional, service 
and repair, restaurant, financial institution and chamber of commerce (general). The board will meet 
as needed pursuant to a request from the city commission to develop biannual recommendations on 
occupational license categories and rates. This study board may be abolished at any time by the city 
commission. 
(b) ?Appointment of members . Members shall be appointed by the city commission by resolution from 
time to time for terms as specified in such resolution. 
(Ord. No. O-93-10, §§ 2, 3, 9-15-93) 
Cross reference— Attendance policy for city boards, § 2-72. 


Sec. 7-11. - Fee assessment on telecommunications companies that occupy municipal rights-of-way for 
telecommunications facilities. 
(a) ?Purpose and application. 
(1) ?The purpose of this section is to establish fees for occupation of the city's rights-of-way for 
telecommunications facilities of telecommunications companies not otherwise paying a fee to 
the city for occupation of the city's rights-of-way. Any telecommunications company paying fees 
for the occupation of the city's rights-of-way for telecommunications facilities as of the effective 
date of this section shall continue to pay fees to the city as the company has been paying them. 
(2) ?The fees imposed pursuant to this section shall apply to all telecommunications companies 
occupying the city's rights-of-way for telecommunications facilities and not otherwise paying a 
fee to the city for occupation of the city's rights-of-way. 
(3) ?The fees imposed pursuant to this section are a fee and not a tax as specified in Section 
337.401, Florida Statutes (2000); consequently, (1) the payments to be made pursuant to this 
section 7-11 shall not be deemed to be in the nature of a tax; (2) such payments shall be in 
addition to any and all taxes of a general applicability; and (3) the fee specified herein is in 
consideration for occupation of the city's rights-of-way, including all public easements, for the 
purpose of erecting, constructing and maintaining telecommunications systems. 
(b) ?Fee for telecommunications company occupation of rights-of-way. 
(1) ?a. ?Any telecommunications company providing local telephone service, as defined in section 
203.012(3), Florida Statutes (2000), in the city and that is occupying municipal streets or 
rights-of-way within the corporate limits of the city with poles, wires or other fixtures shall 
pay to the city a fee in the amount of one (1) percent of the gross receipts on recurring 
local service revenues for services provided within the corporate limits of the city by such 
telecommunications company. Included within the fee are all taxes, licenses, fees, in-kind 
contributions accepted pursuant to section 337.401, Florida Statutes (2000), and other 
impositions except ad valorem taxes and amounts for assessments for special benefits, 
such as sidewalks, street pavings, and similar improvements, and occupational license 
taxes levied or imposed by the city upon the telecommunications company. 
b. ?In the event that a telecommunications company which provides telecommunications 
services defined as toll services in section 203.012(7), Florida Statutes (2000), occupies 
the city's rights-of-way, the telecommunications company shall pay to the city annually five 
hundred dollars ($500.00) per linear mile, which amount is prorated for any portion thereof, 
for any cable, fiber optic, or other pathway that makes physical use of the city's rights-of-
way. Such annual fee shall be prorated to reflect the expiration date of this section and 
shall be payable annually, in advance. If a telecommunications company that is required to 
pay a fee pursuant to this subsection (b)(1)b. increases the amount of its facilities 
occupying the city's rights-of-way after such advance payment has been made, but prior to 
the expiration date of this section, the fees due for the additional facilities shall be prorated 
and paid in full at the time the facilities are installed in the city's rights-of-way. 
The fee or other consideration imposed pursuant to this subsection (b)(1)b. shall not apply 
in any manner to any telecommunications company which provides local telephone service 
as defined in section 203.012(3), Florida Statutes (2000), for any services provided by 
such telecommunications company. 
c. ?Telecommunications company, as used in this section, shall have the meaning set forth in 
section 364.02(12), Florida Statutes (2000). 
(2) ?The fees provided for in subsection (1)a. shall be paid by the telecommunications company to 
the city in quarterly installment(s). The installment payment(s) shall be based upon such gross 
receipts on recurring local service revenues for the immediately preceding installment period or 
portion thereof after the effective date of this section, and shall be made within thirty (30) 
calendar days following the end of the period. Past due payments or underpayments shall bear 
interest accrued from the last day of the quarter for which the payment was due. Interest shall 
be paid at the Florida statutory rate of interest on judgments as established by section 55.03, 
Florida Statutes (2000). Payments shall include a statement as to how the fee amount was 
determined and the statement shall be certified by the telecommunications company's chief 
financial officer or other duly authorized representative of the company. 
(3) ?If the city wishes to verify the payments due to the city under this section, the 
telecommunications company shall permit the city or a designated representative of the city, 
upon reasonable advance written notice, and during normal business hours at the location of 
the telecommunications company where such records are maintained in the city, at another 
location satisfactory to the city, or elsewhere pursuant to subsections (b)(3)a. or b. below, to 
review or audit the telecommunications company's billing and payment records kept in the 
ordinary course of business upon which the payments were based. If a telecommunications 
company's records are not maintained in the city, the telecommunications company shall either: 
a. ?Pay all reasonable expenses, including travel, following the provisions of subsections 
112.061(6), (7) and (8), Florida Statutes (2000), to the city for the city to have a review or 
audit performed; or 
b. ?Provide the city with access to copies of the telecommunications company's records in the 
city or within fifty-five (55) miles of the city or by any electronic method satisfactory to the 
city. 
However, without the specific written consent of a telecommunications company's audit 
representative, no company records may be duplicated or taken from the telecommunications 
company's premises, and the city shall maintain the confidentiality of the information disclosed 
in these records and use the information solely for the purposes of verifying payments by the 
telecommunications company. No acceptance of payment shall be construed as a release or as 
an accord and satisfaction of any claim the city may have for sums due and payable under this 
section unless the city agrees in writing. In the event that the city, pursuant to final audit 
findings, determines that there exists a difference between the amount due to the city and the 
amount paid to the city, indicating an underpayment to the city, in excess of five (5) percent of 
the amount due, such telecommunications company shall pay all reasonable costs, fees and 
expenses of the audit. 
(4) ?This section is adopted consistent with the provisions of Section 337.401, Florida Statutes 
(2000), and other applicable provisions of law. This section shall not be construed as a waiver 
or limitation of the power of the city to prescribe and enforce reasonable rules and regulations 
pursuant to applicable provisions of law. 
(5) ?If required by applicable city ordinances, codes or regulations, a telecommunications company 
shall be registered with the city and obtain all permits that may be required by the city regarding 
occupation of the city's public rights-of-way for telecommunications facilities. 
(Ord. No. O-2001-003, §§ 1, 2, 1-17-01) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2001-003, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 17, 2001, did not specifically 
amend this Code; hence, inclusion of its provisions as § 7-11 herein was at the discretion of the 
editor. 
Cross reference— Telecommunications regulations, § 24-246 et seq. 


Sec. 7-12. - On-site shopping cart retention system required. 
(a) ?It is unlawful for any business establishment which uses twenty (20) or more shopping carts at any 
business location within the city to fail to install and maintain an on-site shopping cart retention 
system for the location. A "shopping cart" is a device which consists of a basket mounted on a frame 
with wheels capable of being moved by a person, which device is generally and ordinarily found and 
used in a retail commercial business establishment by a customer or employee of the establishment 
for the purpose of transporting goods or merchandise from one place to another. 
(b) ?Each such business establishment shall post signs in conspicuous locations within the business 
establishment premises to notify shopping cart users that an on-site shopping cart retention system 
is in place. Such signs shall describe how the system operates. 
(c) ?Permitted methods of retention shall include any one of the following systems or methods: 
(1) ?A physical barrier or barriers may be installed, such as bollards, which restrict shopping carts to 
the main or primary entryway to the business; 
(2) ?Shopping carts may be equipped with protruding devices, arms or similar devices, which 
operate to prohibit the cart from being removed from the interior of the business establishment; 
(3) ?A system may be used, which may be mechanical in nature, requiring a monetary deposit 
which is of a reasonable amount such that it does not deter usage of the cart but encourages 
return of the cart and allows for a refund of the deposit; or 
(4) ?A shopping cart wheel locking system may be used in conjunction with an electronic barrier 
along the perimeter of the business establishment premises; such a system causes the 
shopping cart wheels to lock when the cart approaches or crosses the barrier location by 
activating the electronic barrier. 
(d) ?Any business establishment that does not provide one of the foregoing systems or methods shall be 
afforded a period of six (6) months form the effective date of this section within which to comply. 
(e) ?The owner or operator of any business establishment who or which fails to provide and maintain an 
on-site shopping cart retention system shall be in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-024, § 2, 11-15-06) 


Secs. 7-13—7-16. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - LICENSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to license and tax businesses, occupations and professions, Art. I, § 14(c). 
Cross reference— Bicycle licenses, § 21-68 et seq. 
State Law reference— As to issuance, amounts, revocation, etc., of state and county licenses and 
license taxes, see Ch. 205, Fla. Stats. 


Sec. 7-17. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in or manage any business, occupation or profession referred to in section 
7-22, without first paying the tax prescribed in said section and obtaining a city license therefor. 
(Code 1960, § 10-1) 


Sec. 7-18. - Separate license for each location. 
(a) ?No person shall engage in or manage any business, profession or occupation in this article 
mentioned, without first obtaining from the city a license for each separate location in the city. A 
license shall be required to cover each and every business advertised by sign, newspaper, magazine 
or other form of advertising, and any such sign, newspaper, magazine or other advertisement shall 
be considered evidence of conducting the business advertised. No license shall be issued to cover 
more than one (1) location. 
(b) ?Every person having a license shall exhibit same when called to do so by an officer of the city. 
(c) ?All licenses shall be posted in a conspicuous place where they may be seen upon inspection by any 
official of the city. 
(d) ?Failure to do so shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1960, § 10-4; Ord. No. 550, § 1, 11-3-71; Ord. No. O-2006-019, § 2, 9-6-06) 


Sec. 7-19. - Application. 
(a) ?No license shall be issued or be granted after the thirtieth day of September of any year to any 
applicant therefor to engage in the business of selling merchandise at retail or wholesale, or the 
practice or pursuit of any profession or occupation as set forth in this article, until the applicant has 
registered as required by section 7-21 and has made application and filed the same with the zoning 
official on an application blank furnished by the city, which shall state: 
(1) ?The applicant's name; home address, home phone number and date of birth; 
(2) ?The particular location in the city where he proposes to engage in the business for which the 
license is sought; 
(3) ?Articles of incorporation and/or fictitious name filed with the state; 
(4) ?Federal employee ID number or social security card; 
(5) ?Florida drivers license or Florida identification card; 
(6) ?Any and all other city, county, state licenses/certificates that may be required; 
(7) ?Retail merchants shall provide an estimated average annual retail inventory value; 
(8) ?The owner or an officer of the business must apply in person for the license. In the event the 
home office is located out-of-state the local manager or representative may apply for the 
license. 
(b) ?Each day's selling or disposing of merchandise or engaging in a business or profession without 
making the application required by this section shall constitute a separate and distinct violation of this 
article. 
(c) ?No license shall be issued or granted to any applicant seeking to engage in the management, 
operation or participation in a business which utilizes a mail box rental location without first supplying 
the following information above and beyond that required by section 7-19(a) to the owner/agent of 
the mail box rental business and to the City of Oakland Park, Florida: 
(1) ?Applicant's name; 
(2) ?Applicant's verifiable residential address, post office box number and telephone number; 
(3) ?Applicant's date of birth; 
(4) ?Marital status; 
(5) ?Applicant's drivers license number; 
(6) ?Applicant's social security number; 
(7) ?Applicant's corporate information; 
a. ?Name of corporation; 
b. ?Names of all officers and directors of said corporation; and 
c. ?Copy of corporate certificate. 
(8) ?Description of the nature of the business intended. 
(d) ?The owner/agent of a mail box rental business is required to maintain all the aforementioned 
information in written record form for the time period the lessor continues to engage in business 
activities at the mail box rental location, and for no less than six (6) months after the lessor ceases to 
engage in business activities at such mail box rental location, and to produce such written records 
upon demand of the public safety department of the city. 
(e) ?No license shall be granted until there has been full compliance with section 7-19, and no license 
granted without full compliance shall be protection to the applicant in any proceeding civil or criminal. 
(f) ?The fact that any person represents himself as being engaged in any business, calling, profession or 
occupation for the transaction of which a license is required, or that such person exhibited a sign or 
advertisement indicating such business, calling, or profession or occupation, shall be evidence of the 
liability of such person to pay a license. 
(Code 1960, §§ 10-5, 10-6; Ord. No. O-86-1, § 1, 2-5-86; Ord. No. O-94-8, § 2, 7-6-94) 


Sec. 7-20. - Penalty for violating section 7-18 or 7-19 or making fraudulent return. 
    Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of section 7-18 or 7-19, or of making a 
fraudulent return, shall be punished by a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) or be imprisoned not 
more than thirty (30) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court, and pay, 
in addition, twenty-five (25) percent of any license tax evaded through such violation. 
(Code 1960, § 10-6) 


Sec. 7-21. - Annual registration of licensees. 
    Any person engaged in or managing any business, occupation or profession and having a place of 
business in the city is required to renew their city license on or before September thirtieth annually, before 
engaging in any business, profession or occupation. 
(Code 1960, § 10-2; Ord. No. O-94-8, § 3, 7-6-94)

Sec. 7-23. - Proration of tax. 
    For each license obtained between October first and March thirty-first, the full tax for one (1) year 
shall be paid, except as otherwise provided, and for each license obtained from April first to September 
thirtieth, one-half (½) the full tax for one (1) year shall be paid, except as otherwise provided. 
(Code 1960, § 10-3; Ord. No. 539, § 1, 6-2-71) 


Sec. 7-24. - Occupational licenses; dates due and delinquent; penalties. 
(a) ?All licenses shall be sold by the appropriate tax collector beginning August 1 of each year, are due 
and payable on or before September 30 of each year, and expire on September 30 of the 
succeeding year. If September 30 falls on a weekend or holiday, the tax is due and payable on or 
before the first working day following September 30. Licenses that are not renewed when due and 
payable are delinquent and subject to a delinquency penalty of ten (10) percent for the month of 
October, plus an additional five (5) percent penalty for each subsequent month of delinquency until 
paid. However, the total delinquency penalty shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the 
occupational license tax for the delinquent establishment. 
(b) ?Any person who engages in or manages any business, occupation, or profession without first 
obtaining a local occupational license, is subject to a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of the 
license due, in addition to any other penalty provided by law or ordinance. 
(c) ?Any person who engages in any business, occupation, or profession covered by this chapter, who 
does not pay the required occupational license tax within one hundred fifty (150) days after the initial 
notice of tax due, and who does not obtain the required occupational license is subject to civil actions 
and penalties, including court costs, reasonable attorneys' fees, additional administrative costs 
incurred as a result of collection efforts, and a penalty of up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
The penalties hereby imposed shall be collected in addition to the amount of the license tax, and the 
payment of such penalty shall not be pleaded in bar in any proceedings charging the offense of 
doing business without a license under this article. 
(Code 1960, § 10-4; Ord. No. 550, § 1, 11-3-71; Ord. No. O-94-8, § 5, 7-6-94) 


Sec. 7-25. - Exemptions from tax. 
(a) ?Invalids, cripples, aged, widows . All confirmed cripples or invalids physically incapable of manual 
labor, widows with minor dependents, and persons sixty-five (65) years of age or older, who are 
bona fide residents of the city, upon filing with the license department satisfactory proof of such 
conditions, shall be allowed to engage, solely upon their own account as individuals with capital not 
exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), in the business of merchants for the sale of merchandise 
other than drugs, medicine and liquor, without being required to pay the license tax as provided in 
this chapter for the operation of such business. 
(b) ?Disabled veterans . Any bona fide permanent resident elector of the state who has served in the 
armed forces, and who was honorably discharged from the service of the United States, and who at 
the time of application for a license shall be disabled from performing manual labor, shall, upon 
sufficient identification and proof of being a permanent resident elector of the state and production of 
an honorable discharge from the service of the United States and proof of disability satisfactory to 
the city, be granted a license to engage in any business or occupation which may be carried on 
mainly through the personal efforts of the licensee as a means of livelihood and for which the state, 
county and municipal license does not exceed the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00), without payment of 
any license tax otherwise provided by law, or shall be entitled to an exemption to the extent of fifty 
dollars ($50.00). When any such person shall apply for a license to conduct any business or 
occupation for which the state, county or municipal license tax, as fixed by law, shall exceed the sum 
of fifty dollars ($50.00), the remainder of such license tax in excess of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be 
paid by the licensee. 
(Code 1960, § 106.1) 


Sec. 7-26. - Term. 
    Licenses shall expire on the thirtieth day of September of each year. No license shall be issued for 
more than one (1) year. 
(Code 1960, § 10-3; Ord. No. 539, § 1, 6-2-71) 


Sec. 7-27. - Transfer. 
(a) ?Any business license may be transferred to a new owner, when there is a bona fide sale of the 
business, upon payment of a transfer fee of ten (10) percent of the annual license tax, but not less 
than three dollars ($3.00) nor more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00), and presentation of the original 
license and evidence of the sale. 
(b) ?Upon written request and presentation of the original license, any license may be transferred from 
one (1) location to another location in the same municipality with approval of the zoning official upon 
payment of a transfer fee of up to ten (10) percent of the annual license tax, but not less than three 
dollars ($3.00) nor more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Code 1960, § 10-3; Ord. No. 539, § 1, 6-2-71; Ord. No. O-94-8, § 6, 7-6-94) 
State Law reference— Transfer from one location to another, fee authorized, § 205.043, Fla. 
Stats. 


Sec. 7-28. - Suspension or revocation. 
    Any license issued by the city may be temporarily suspended or absolutely revoked or canceled by a 
majority vote of the city commission, when the commission shall have ascertained and determined, in the 
exercise of its sound discretion, that such action will promote the public peace, health, safety, welfare, 
harmony or good order of the neighborhood in which the licensee's place of business is located; provided, 
however, in the case of the revocation and cancellation of such license, the city shall refund to the 
licensee the pro rata unearned or unused portion of the tax paid for his license. No refund shall be made 
where the license is temporarily suspended. 
(Code 1960, § 10-12) 


Sec. 7-29. - Construction of article. 
    Each provision of this article contained, and each license tax by this article imposed, is intended to 
be separate and independent, and this article is intended to be construed distributively. 
(Code 1960, § 10-1) 


Sec. 7-30. - Responsibility of corporate officers and agents for violations of article. 
    It shall be the duty of all officers and agents of any corporation to see that such corporation complies 
with the provisions of this article and all officers or agents of any corporation required by this article to be 
licensed and which does business without having procured such license, shall be subject to the penalties 
provided for violations of this article. 
(Code 1960, § 10-7) 


Secs. 7-31—7-41. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - FIRE AND GOING-OUT-OF-BUSINESS SALES 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 7-42. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Fire and other altered goods sale: A sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the 
public to believe that the sale will offer goods damaged or altered by fire, smoke, water or other means. 
    Going-out-of-business sale: A sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to 
believe that, upon the disposal of the stock of goods on hand, the business will cease and be 
discontinued, including but not limited to the following sales: Adjusters; adjustment; alteration; assignees; 
bankrupt; benefit of administrators; benefit of creditors; benefit of trustees; building coming down; closing; 
creditor's committee; creditors; end; executors; final days; forced out of business; insolvents; last days; 
lease expires; liquidation; loss of lease; mortgage sale; receivers; trustees; quitting business; removal. 
Any sale using any of the foregoing words or words of similar import, at the conclusion of which sale the 
business will not cease and be discontinued, and not publishing that fact or the qualified nature of the 
sale with equal prominence with each advertisement of such sale, shall be deemed to be a going-out-of-
business sale. 
    Goods: Includes any goods, wares, merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a 
sale regulated by this article. 
    Publish, publishing, advertising and advertisement: Includes any and all means of conveying to the 
public notice of a sale or notice of intention to conduct a sale, whether by word of mouth, newspaper 
advertisement, magazine advertisement, handbill, written notice, printed display, billboard display, poster, 
radio announcement and any and all means including oral, written or printed. 
    Sale: A "fire and other altered goods sale" or a "going-out-of-business sale," as defined in this 
section. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-43. - Person conducting going-out-of-business sale to surrender business license. 
    Upon being issued a permit under this article for a going-out-of-business sale, the permittee shall 
surrender to the license inspector all other business licenses he may hold at that time applicable to the 
location and goods covered by the application for a permit under this article. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-44. - Stock list to be available; books and records to be kept. 
(a) ?A duplicate original of the application and stock list pursuant to which a permit was issued under this 
article shall at all times be available, at the place of sale, to the license inspector, who may examine 
all merchandise in the premises or in the warehouses for comparison with such stock list. 
(b) ?Suitable books and records, as prescribed by the license inspector, shall be kept by the person 
conducting a sale under this article and shall, during business hours, be available to the license 
inspector. At the close of business each day, the stock list attached to the permit application shall be 
revised and those items disposed of during such day shall be so marked thereon. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-45. - Only inventoried goods to be sold. 
    A permit issued under this article shall authorize only the sale of goods described in the inventory 
attached to the application for the permit, and the permittee shall make no additions whatsoever, during 
the period of authorized sale, to the stock of goods set forth in the inventory attached to the application for 
the permit. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-46. - Advertising. 
(a) ?All advertisements or advertising, and the language contained therein, used in connection with a 
sale shall be in accordance with the purpose of the sale as stated in the application pursuant to 
which a permit was issued under this article and the wording of such advertisements shall not vary 
from the wording as indicated in the application. Such advertising should contain a statement in 
these words and no others: 
"Sale held pursuant to _______ County, _______ sale No. _______ granted the _______ day of 
_______," (in such blank spaces shall be indicated the type of sale, the permit number and the 
requisite dates). 
(b) ?No person holding a permit for a sale under this article shall employ any untrue, deceptive or 
misleading advertising in connection with such sale. 
(c) ?A person holding a permit for a sale under this article shall conduct such sale in strict conformity 
with any advertising or holding out incident thereto. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-47. - Exemptions from article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following persons: 
(1) ?Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2) ?Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officers, such as sheriffs 
and marshals and similar public officers. 
(3) ?Duly licensed auctioneers, selling at auction. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Secs. 7-48—7-52. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 


Sec. 7-53. - Required. 
    No person shall publish or conduct any fire and other altered goods sale or any going-out-of-
business sale within the city, without first obtaining a permit so to do. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-54. - Application. 
    Written application for a permit under this division, in a form approved by the city commission and 
verified by the applicant, shall be filed in the office of the license inspector. Such application shall contain 
a description of the place where such sale is to be held; the nature of the occupancy, whether by lease or 
sublease and the effective date of termination of such occupancy; and the means to be employed in 
publishing such sale. Such application shall further contain, as a part thereof, an itemized list of the 
goods, wares and merchandise to be offered for sale. Such list shall show the goods, wares and 
merchandise at the business premises and separately show the goods, wares and merchandise in any 
and all warehouses owned or leased by the applicant and located in the County of Broward. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-55. - Fee. 
    Upon filing an application for a permit under this division, the applicant shall pay to the license 
inspector a fee in the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00). If the application is disapproved, such fee 
shall be retained as and for the cost of investigating the applicant and the statements contained in the 
application. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-56. - Issuance. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a permit under this division, and payment of the fee prescribed by 
section 7-55, the license inspector shall examine the application and may make such investigation as he 
may deem proper. If after such investigation he is satisfied as to the truth of the statements contained in 
the application, he may issue a permit permitting the publication and conduct of the sale. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-57. - Term. 
    A permit issued under this division shall authorize the sale described in the application for a period of 
not more than forty-five (45) consecutive days, counting Sundays and legal holidays, following the 
issuance thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-58. - Authorizes only sale of the type and at the location described in application. 
    A permit issued under this division shall authorize only the one (1) type of sale described in the 
application and only at the location named therein. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-59. - Not transferable. 
    A permit issued under this division shall not be assignable or transferable. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Sec. 7-60. - Display. 
    Upon commencement of any sale, the permit issued under this division shall be prominently 
displayed near the entrance to the premises. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10.1) 


Secs. 7-61—7-65. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IV. - MOTION PICTURE HOUSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Smoking in motion picture houses, § 6-11. 


Sec. 7-66. - License applicant to be fingerprinted and furnish references. 
    All persons applying for an occupational license to operate a motion picture theater, house, building 
or structure shall be fingerprinted by the police department and shall submit three (3) letters of reference 
as to their good moral character to the chief building official. Where the applicant is a corporation, an 
officer, director or person who shall be in charge of the business shall submit such letters of reference 
and shall be fingerprinted. 
(Code 1960, § 12A-5) 


Sec. 7-67. - Commission finding prerequisite to issuance of license. 
    No license shall issue for the operation of a motion picture house unless the city commission finds 
that the applicant is a person of good moral character. 
(Code 1960, § 12A-5) 


Sec. 7-68. - Employees to be fingerprinted. 
    All employees of a motion picture house shall be fingerprinted by the police department. 
(Code 1960, § 12A-5) 


Sec. 7-69. - Required parking spaces. 
    Each house, building or structure to be used for the public viewing of motion pictures shall provide 
one (1) parking space for each four (4) seats, or one (1) space for each thirty (30) square feet of public 
area, whichever is greater; provided, however, provision shall be made for a minimum of one hundred 
(100) parking spaces. 
(Code 1960, § 12A-3) 


Secs. 7-70—7-79. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE V. - FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-76-11, § 2, adopted May 5, 1976, repealed Ord. No. 594, §§ 1—10, adopted 
May 16, 1973, setting standards for food establishments, which provisions were codified herein as Art. V, 
§§ 7-80—7-100; Ord. No. O-76-11, § 1, being nonamendatory of this Code, is included herein as a new 
Art. V, § 7-80, at the editor's discretion. 


Sec. 7-80. - Broward County Ordinance No. 75-43 adopted. 
    The City of Oakland Park does hereby accept the terms and conditions of Broward County's 
Ordinance No. 75-43 which sets minimum standards of hygiene for food establishments; provides for 
issuance of permits and approval for such establishments; requires instruction in basic food hygiene; 
creates the Broward County food protection advisory board, and provides for its membership, powers and 
duties; provides for inspections and revocation of licenses; provides for immediate closure when there is 
a threat to life and health; provides for revocation of certain permits; provides for penalties and other 
remedies for violations thereof, and the City of Oakland Park does hereby specifically incorporate within 
the Code of Ordinances of the City of Oakland Park, Broward County Ordinance No. 75-43. 
(Ord. No. O-76-11, § 1, 5-5-76) 


Secs. 7-81—7-100. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VI. - COIN-OPERATED DEVICES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-74-26, adopted Dec. 18, 1974, did not expressly amend this Code, hence 
inclusion of §§ 1—9 herein as Art. VI, §§ 7-101—7-109, was at the discretion of the editors. 


Sec. 7-101. - License required; provisions not applicable to certain machines or devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to set up for operation, operate, lease or distribute for the purpose 
of operating, any coin-operated device as defined in section 7-102, without first having obtained a license 
therefor. This article, however, does not apply to machines or devices being displayed or demonstrated 
by manufacturers, distributors, salesmen and agents for sales purposes. 
(Ord. No. O-74-26, § 1, 12-18-74) 


Sec. 7-102. - Coin-operated devices defined and classified. 
    For the purposes of this article, coin-operated devices are defined and classified as follows: 
(1) ?Automatic vendors . Automatic coin-operating vending and amusement machines with 
premium features, which may vend for each coin deposited a standard article of merchandise 
having a recognized retail value, and which at intervals vends checks, tokens, coins or orders 
which may not be exchanged for additional merchandise. Hereinafter this type will be referred to 
as "automatic vendors." 
(2) ?Skill machines . Coin-operated skill machines (commonly referred to as pin games, marble 
tables and similar devices of this type which may have a skill feature) which may or may not pay 
a reward for skillful operation or upon which operation, premiums may or may not be given for 
high score or making certain combinations. Such premiums may be awarded either 
automatically by the machine in the form of checks, tokens or orders, which designate the value 
of the premium or premiums or may be indicated by a score card attached to the machine. 
Hereinafter this type shall be referred to as "skill machines." 
(3) ?Trade machines . Trade machines have no automatic vending feature, although at intervals 
indicate that patron is entitled to receive premiums. Herein after this type will be referred to as 
"trade machines." 
    Only such types of machines as are hereinabove described [subsections (1) through (3)] 
and referred to as automatic vendors, skill machines and/or trade machines are covered by this 
article. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply to any coin-operated machine or 
device which returns amusement, entertainment or some service or article of value, or a 
combination of the above, uniformly as to quantity and quality, upon each insertion of a coin into 
the same, nor to any coin-operated telephone. 
(4) ?Other machines . All other coin-operated machines or slot machines not covered by any of the 
above definitions, classifications or descriptions, shall be classified as "other machines" and 
shall be subject to an occupational license tax as hereinafter provided. 
    This article shall not apply to coin-operated telephones nor to U.S. stamp machines. 
(Ord. No. O-74-26, § 2, 12-18-74) 


Sec. 7-103. - "Operator" and "location operator" defined. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who leases or rents out or places, under any kind of arrangement 
whatsoever with any other person, or a location operator, any coin-operated device or devices, as herein 
defined, shall pay an occupational tax and shall be known as an "operator." 
    Any person, firm or corporation who displays any coin-operated device or devices, as herein defined, 
to the public to be played or operated by the public, shall be known as a "location operator" and shall pay 
an occupational license tax as provided in section 7-105. 
(Ord. No. O-74-26, § 3, 12-18-74) 


Sec. 7-104. - When licenses due and payable. 
    All licenses shall be due and payable on or before the first day of October of each year, and no 
license shall be issued for any fractional portion of a year, except as otherwise provided in this article, and 
except that any license for a location tax may be issued after the first day of April and to expire on the 
thirtieth day of September of the same year, upon the payment of one-half (½) of the amount fixed as the 
price of such license for one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. O-74-26, § 4, 12-18-74) 


Sec. 7-105. - Fees for licenses. 
    The fees for such licenses shall be those certain fees set forth in section 7-22 of this Code of 
Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. O-74-26, § 5, 12-18-74) 


Sec. 7-106. - Enforcement of article provisions. 
    The city manager, the building official, chief of police and the police officers of the city are hereby 
directed, authorized and empowered to enforce the provisions of this article, and to confiscate all 
machines as herein defined upon which said occupational tax herein imposed has not been paid as 
herein provided. 
(Ord. No. O-74-26, § 6, 12-18-74) 


Sec. 7-107. - General provisions to which machines subject. 
    Any and all machines licensed under this article shall be subject to the following provisions: 
(1) ?All machines licensed by this article must be operated and maintained at all times in an orderly 
manner and the operation thereof shall be conducted with the same dignity as any other well-
regulated business. 
(2) ?It shall be unlawful for any location operator or any person in direct charge or supervision of 
such machines to permit persons of disorderly character to engage in the play of such machines 
or to loiter about the same. 
(3) ?It shall be unlawful for any location operator or any person in direct charge or supervision of 
such machines to knowingly permit any person who is receiving public charity or charitable aid 
and assistance from any relief agency, to engage in the play of such machines. 
(4) ?It shall be unlawful for any location operator or any person in direct charge or supervision of 
such machines to place or maintain such machines behind any blind, screen, or in any hidden 
or secretive location, except when such machines are not open to play. 
(5) ?Occupational license certificates which may be issued by the city for such machines, shall at all 
times be posted and/or attached to such machines and prominently displayed thereon. Such 
licenses shall designate the location for which such machines shall be operated, and there shall 
appear upon said license, the number of the license and the manufacturer's serial number of 
the machine. Any machine which shall be removed for operation to another location in the city 
shall not be permitted to be operated or played unless and until the license certificate shall have 
been presented to the finance director and a new certificate shall have been issued for such 
new location, and a fee of one dollar ($1.00) shall be paid to said finance director for the 
issuance of such certificate; this provision shall also apply to any machine or machines which 
may be taken out by the operator for repairs or other purposes and another machine of the 
same exact type and classification left in place of the machine removed. 
(Ord. No. O-24-26, § 7, 12-18-74) 


Sec. 7-108. - Revocation of license. 
    Any license issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked and cancelled in the discretion 
of the municipal judge, upon the holder thereof being convicted of a felony by a court of competent 
jurisdiction, and/or being convicted in the municipal court of a violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-74-26, § 8, 12-18-74) 


Sec. 7-109. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall upon conviction be punished as 
provided by section 7-108. 
(Ord. No. O-74-26, § 9, 12-18-74) 


ARTICLE VII. - SECONDHAND DEALERS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Solicitors and peddlers, Ch. 17. 


Sec. 7-110. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2011-024, § 2, adopted Oct. 19, 2011, repealed former § 7-110 in its 
entirety which pertained to definitions relating to secondhand dealers and derived from Ord. No. 
O-83-9, § 2, adopted April 20, 1983. 


Sec. 7-111. - Certain acts and practices prohibited. 
    Each of the following acts of commission or omission of a secondhand dealer or by any of his 
employees is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall subject the person convicted thereof by a court of 
competent jurisdiction to the penalties prescribed: 
(a) ?Carrying on the business of a secondhand dealer without a valid license or from any place 
other than the place designated in the license therefor. However, this provision does not apply 
to those businesses or individuals purchasing used or secondhand goods at a residence or 
business establishment other than their principal place of business. 
(b) ?Purchasing or otherwise acquiring any article covered by this article where the licensee knows 
or reasonably should know that the person the article was acquired from is under the age of 
eighteen (18) years or a person using a name other than his own. 
(c) ?Refusing, denying, retarding, or interfering with the lawful inspection of the premises by a police 
officer of the city during hours establishment is open for business. 
(d) ?Failing or neglecting to retain on the premises and have available for inspection by a police 
officer of the city any article covered by this article for a period of at least five (5) working days 
from and after the date of purchase. The articles are to be ticketed with a number identical to 
the number on the ticket exchanged for the item referred to above, provided that the provisions 
of this subsection shall not be applicable when the person known by the secondhand dealer to 
be the true owner of any article desires to redeem, repurchase or recover such article at any 
time within five (5) working days. The secondhand dealer shall keep a record of the proof of 
ownership such as sale's receipt, statement of ownership, bill of sale, etc., which provides for 
the dealer to sell the property at his convenience. 
(e) ?Reserved. 
(f) ?Failing or neglecting to comply with any applicable provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-83-9, § 2, 4-20-83) 


Sec. 7-112. - Recording of transactions to be kept. 
(a) ?Recording of acquisition of articles . Every secondhand dealer shall keep a record of acquisitions of 
secondhand goods approved as to type and form by the public safety director, with certification of 
such approval endorsed therein over the signature of a member of the police department designated 
for that purpose by the public safety director. The record shall be in a form that contains 
consecutively prenumbered pages and is in triplicate. The record shall be clearly and legibly written 
in ink in the English language at the time of each loan, purchase or other method of acquisition and 
shall contain an accurate, true and complete description of each loan, purchase or other method of 
acquisition and shall contain an accurate, true and complete description of each article, the amount 
of money or other consideration loaned thereon or paid or given therefor, the date and time of the 
acquisition of such article by the secondhand dealer, the true name of the person dealt with, as 
nearly as known, such person's signature, place of residence, race, sex, age, height, build, color of 
hair, color of eyes, complexion, home telephone number, business telephone number, and 
reasonable proof of identification by an exhibition of driver's license, provided it has a picture on the 
driver's license or any two of the following: Voter's registration card, birth certificate, draft registration 
card, police identification card, passport or other similar reliable means of identification, minimum of 
one (1) picture, I.D. as well as a photograph or legible thumb print of the person. The record shall 
contain the type of identification exhibited, the issuing agency and the number thereon. 
Unacceptable identification includes, but is not limited to, credit cards, social security cards and 
handwritten identification cards. No entry made in such record shall be erased, obliterated or 
defaced. 
(b) ?Copy of record . Every dealer shall prepare and maintain a copy of the record required by 
subsection (a) to the person selling or pledging any item. 
(Ord. No. O-83-9, § 2, 4-20-83) 


Sec. 7-113. - Records to police generally. 
    It shall be the duty of every secondhand dealer to maintain a record of acquisition of any article 
covered by this article, in the form approved for such purposes by the public safety director, a legible, 
complete and correct record, as required by section 7-112(a) for the immediately preceding period. 
(Ord. No. O-83-9, § 2, 4-20-83) 


Sec. 7-114. - Inspection of premises and records. 
    Any law enforcement officer of the city shall have the right to inspect premises of any secondhand 
dealer in the city during normal business hours for the purpose of locating stolen goods and inspecting 
the records required to be kept by this article. 
(Ord. No. O-83-9, § 2, 4-20-83) 


Sec. 7-115. - Application generally. 
(a) ?Information required . Every applicant for a license to engage in the business of a secondhand 
dealer shall file with the code enforcement officer of the City of Oakland Park a written application 
upon a form prepared and provided by the city, signed by the applicant. An application fee the sum 
of one hundred dollars ($100.00) is required. If approved, the application fee will be applied to the 
license fee. If the application is disapproved, such fee shall be retained as and for the cost of 
investigating the applicant and the statements contained in the application. Every application of a 
license to engage in the business of a secondhand dealer shall be signed and acknowledged before 
a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths. Such application shall state: 
(1) ?The names and residences of the applicant, if an individual, partnership or firm, or the names 
of the directors and officers and their residences, if the applicant is an association or 
corporation. 
(2) ?The length of time such applicant, if an individual partnership and the manager or person in 
charge, if such applicant is an association or corporation, has resided at his current residence, 
his place of previous employment, whether he has been convicted of a felony, and if so, what 
offense, when, and in what court. 
(3) ?Whether the applicant or officers or manager of the applicant has been employed by a 
secondhand dealer or has been a secondhand dealer. 
(4) ?The detailed nature of the business to be conducted and the kind of materials to be collected, 
bought, sold or otherwise handled. 
(5) ?The premises where such business is to be located or carried on. 
(6) ?That the applicant accepts the license, if granted, upon the condition that it will be revoked by 
the city upon conviction of any offense enumerated in section 7-116(a). 
(7) ?That the applicant accepts the license if granted on the condition that it accepts the right of a 
city law enforcement officer to inspect his premises in accordance with the terms of section 7-
114. 
(b) ?Numbering and contents. All licenses issued under this article shall be numbered in the order in 
which they are issued and shall state clearly the location of the secondhand business, the date of 
issuance and expiration of the license, and the name and address of the licensee. Such license shall 
designate the place of business in or from which the secondhand dealer receiving the license shall 
be authorized to carry on such business. Such license is in addition to any other license required by 
applicable law. 
(Ord. No. O-83-9, § 2, 4-20-83) 


Sec. 7-116. - Not to be issued to persons convicted of certain offenses. 
(a) ?No license as a secondhand dealer shall be granted to any person who shall have been convicted 
within ten (10) years of the date of application of the offense or offenses of theft; larceny, 
embezzlement; conversion, obtaining money or property by false pretenses, fraud or deception; 
receiving stolen property; dealing in stolen property; possession of altered property; burglary; or 
violation of Florida Statutes, Section 812.051, unless the person has had his civil rights restored. If 
the licensee is a corporation or an association, the above restrictions apply to all officers and 
directors thereof. If the licensee is a partnership, the restrictions apply to each partner. 
(b) ?No person licensed as a secondhand dealer shall knowingly employ any person in any secondhand 
business who has within ten (10) years of the date of employment been convicted of the offense or 
offenses of theft; larceny, embezzlement, conversion, obtaining money or property by false 
pretenses; fraud or deception; receiving stolen property; dealing in stolen property; possession of 
altered property; burglary; or violation of Florida Statutes, Section 812.051, unless the person has 
had his civil rights restored. The names and addresses of all employees shall be submitted to the city 
police department within ten (10) days of employment. 
(Ord. No. O-83-9, § 2, 4-20-83) 


ARTICLE VIII. - CONVENIENCE STORES 


Sec. 7-117. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Convenience store. Any place of business that is engaged in the retail sale of groceries, including 
the sale of prepared foods, and gasoline and services, that is regularly open for business at any time 
between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., and that is attended during such hours by one (1) 
employee. The term "convenience store" does not include a store which is solely or primarily a restaurant. 
    Principal operator of a convenience store. The person, corporation, partnership, joint venture, or 
other entity having lawful possession of the premises upon which a convenience store is operated and 
who operates the convenience store on a day-to-day basis. 
(Ord. No. O-91-20, § 1, 12-18-91; Ord. No. O-2005-016, § 2, 2-16-05) 


Sec. 7-118. - Convenience store security. 
    Each convenience store located within the city shall: 
(1) ?Be equipped with the following security devices: 
a. ?A silent alarm that notifies the Oakland Park Public Safety Department or a private security 
agency that a robbery is taking place. 
b. ?A security camera system capable of retrieving an image to assist in the identification and 
apprehension of a robber. 
c. ?A drop safe or cash management device that provides minimum access to the facility's 
cash receipts. 
(2) ?Have lighted parking lots illuminated at an intensity of two (2) footcandles per square foot with 
a uniformity ratio of no more than five (5) to one (1) at eighteen (18) inches above the surface. 
(3) ?Post a conspicuous sign in the convenience store entrance which states that the cash register 
contains fifty dollars ($50.00) or less. 
(4) ?Maintain window signage so that there is a clear and unobstructed view of the cash register 
and transaction area. 
(5) ?Prohibit window tinting on the windows of the establishment if such tinting reduces exterior or 
interior viewing during the hours of operation to which this act is applicable. 
(6) ?Install height markers at the entrance of the establishment which display height measures from 
the floor. 
(7) ?Establish a cash management policy to limit the amount of available cash on hand between the 
hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(8) ?Establish telephone access within the building for use by employees. 
(Ord. No. O-91-20, § 1, 12-18-91) 


Sec. 7-119. - Training of employees. 
    The owner or principal operator of a convenience store shall provide robbery deterrence and safety 
training to at least its employees who work between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. Any proposed 
program of training shall be submitted in writing to the attorney general. The attorney general shall review 
and approved or disapprove of training programs within sixty (60) days after receipt of a proposal 
describing the training to be provided. Programs shall be designed to train and familiarize store 
employees with the security principles, devices and measures required by Section 812.173, Florida 
Statutes. Decisions of the attorney general relating to approval of training programs shall be subject to the 
provisions of Chapter 120, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. O-91-20, § 1, 12-18-91) 


Sec. 7-120. - Authority of code enforcement board. 
    The code enforcement board is hereby granted the authority to enforce compliance with this article 
and to assess fees for noncompliance in the manner provided for by Chapter 162, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. O-91-20, § 1, 12-18-91) 


Sec. 7-121. - Noncompliance fee. 
(a) ?Any owner or principal operator of a convenience store who fails to comply with the requirements of 
this article shall be assessed the fees for noncompliance in accordance with Section 162.09(2)(a), 
Florida Statutes, up to a maximum fine of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(b) ?No fee for noncompliance may be assessed against an owner or principal operator of a 
convenience store for a violation of this article unless such owner or operator has been provided with 
written notice of such noncompliance by the code enforcement officer at least ten (10) days prior to 
the issuance of a citation of violation of this article in accordance with Section 162.21, Florida 
Statutes, and the noncompliance is corrected within such period. 
(Ord. No. O-91-20, § 1, 12-18-91) 


ARTICLE IX. - PSYCHIC CONSULTING
