(3) ?Reserved. 
(4) ?Vesting. Upon obtaining his first possible optional retirement date, the participant shall become 
one hundred (100) percent vested. 
(5) ?Terms and conditions of election of optional retirement date . A participant who has completed 
seven (7) years of service may elect an optional retirement date, subject to the following 
conditions and restrictions: 
a. ?An optional retirement date may be elected by filing the request therefor with the board. 
b. ?If the election of an optional retirement date would result in monthly annuity payments to 
any person of less than five dollars ($5.00) each, such election shall not become operative 
except upon the specific consent in writing of the board. 
c. ?The written consent of the board will be required if a member elects to change an optional 
retirement date previously elected. 
(c) ?Deferred retirement benefit. 
(1) ?Deferred commencing date. If participant, whose retirement date is his normal retirement date, 
continues in the service of the city after his normal retirement date, such participant may elect 
that his retirement benefits become payable to him at a deferred commencing date, instead of 
at the normal retirement date, by filing a written request with the board prior to his normal 
retirement date and obtaining the board's consent. 
The deferred commencing date shall be the first day of the calendar month coinciding with or 
next following the earlier of: 
(1) ?The termination of the participant's employment with the city; or 
(2) ?The death of the participant. 
(2) ?Retirement benefit at deferred commencing date. The retirement benefits commencing at the 
deferred commencing date shall be on the annuity form in effect with respect to the participant 
immediately prior to the member's deferred commencing date, except that the certain period 
shall be a period of sixty (60) months beginning at the deferred commencing date. 
If the life annuity-five years certain form is in effect and the member is not living at the deferred 
commencing date, the annuity payments shall commence to the beneficiary designated by the 
member in accordance with section 9-39; or if no beneficiary is designated and living on the 
deferred commencing date, the commuted value of any remaining annuity payments will be paid 
in accordance with said section 9-39. 
The amount of each monthly payment commencing at the deferred commencing date shall be 
calculated the same as his normal retirement income as described under section 9-33(a)(1) of 
this plan, except the participant's final average monthly earnings and credited service will be 
determined as of the participant's deferred commencing date. 
(d) ?Notwithstanding any other provision of the plan, and regardless of a participant's election pursuant 
to section 9-31(b) to join the Florida Retirement System or to continue to participate in this plan, a 
participant must meet all requirements for retirement and terminate city employment to be eligible for 
benefits under the plan. An exception to this section shall apply to a participant who is employed by 
the Broward Sheriff's Office and who has reached age sixty-two (62) or had thirty (30) years of 
continuous service. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. IV, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-83-5, § 2, 1-19-83; Ord. No. O-83-17, §§ 4, 5, 7-
6-83; Ord. No. O-88-14, §§ 4, 5, 6-1-88; Ord. No. O-2007-022, § 4, 7-18-07; Ord. No. O-2009-
009, § 2, 4-15-09; Ord. No. O-2011-007, § 2, 3-16-11) 


Sec. 9-33. - Amount of retirement income. 
(a) ?Participants. 
(1) ?Retirement income—Normal retirement date. 
a. ?A participant who has at least twenty (20) years of service at normal retirement date will 
receive a monthly retirement income equal to seventy (70) percent of his final average 
monthly earnings. If such participant has less than twenty (20) years of service at his 
normal retirement date, the participant will receive a proportionately reduced monthly 
income. 
b. ?In addition to subsection a. above, a participant's monthly retirement income shall increase 
one-half (½) of one (1) percent of the participant's final average monthly earnings for each 
year of service over twenty (20) years up to a maximum of seventy-five (75) percent and a 
cap of thirty (30) years continuous service. 
c. ?The retirement income benefit calculation shall be determined as of the date of termination 
of the participant as otherwise defined herein. 
(2) ?Retirement income—Optional retirement date . If an optional retirement date shall have been 
elected by a participant, the amount of the monthly payments commencing at the optional 
retirement date shall be reduced by three and one-tenth (3.1) percent for each of the years by 
which the starting date of the monthly payment precedes the normal retirement date. 
(3) ?Employees who were participants under the original plan . In the case of a participant who was 
included in the original pension plan and trust agreement, adopted by the city on May 1, 1963, 
before becoming a participant under this plan, the amount of retirement income provided under 
this section shall not be less than the amount of retirement income the participant would have 
been eligible to receive at retirement date if the original plan had continued in effect until such 
retirement date and the participant's earnings in effect immediately before the effective date of 
this plan had continued at the same level until his retirement date. 
(4) ?Transfer of certain employees. Any employee as defined by this plan, who ceases to be an 
employee as defined in this chapter but who remains with the city or Broward Sheriff's Office in 
some capacity and who has seven (7) or more years of continuous employment with the city or 
county shall have all benefits accrued under this system preserved. No benefit shall be payable 
under this plan, however, during any period of continued employment with the city or county in 
any capacity unless the employee has retired from the plan or transferred to the Florida 
Retirement System (FRS). 
(b) ?Participants with thirty (30) years of service . A participant who has at least thirty (30) years of 
service shall receive the maximum monthly retirement income as otherwise provided herein without 
reduction or penalty as may be otherwise provided herein. Age of the participant who elects to retire 
under this provision shall specifically not be a factor in computation of the monthly retirement income 
as to the participant who has thirty (30) years of service at the date of termination. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. V, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-82-15, § 2, 7-7-82; Ord. No. O-83-5, § 3, 1-19-
83; Ord. No. O-83-17, § 6, 7-6-83; Ord. No. O-84-18, § 1, 9-5-84; Ord. No. O-88-14, §§ 6, 7, 6-
1-88; Ord. No. O-90-18, § 3, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-93-22, § 4, 12-15-93; Ord. No. O-2000-013, § 
2, 6-21-00) 


Sec. 9-34. - Contributions. 
(a) ?Employees who are members of the plan shall contribute a percentage of their earnings to fund the 
plan. Employee contributions shall be funded by payroll deduction. The contribution rate, shall be 
stated as a percentage of base pay. The initial contribution rate is four (4) percent and shall take 
effect the first pay period in July, 2009, or as otherwise provided in a collective bargaining agreement 
which is in effect on the effective date of this amendment. The contribution rate may thereafter be 
adjusted annually by the city commission as part of the city's annual budget process and reflected in 
the annual budget adoption resolution. In the case of collective bargaining unit employees, the 
employee contribution rate shall be set forth in the employee's collective bargaining agreement, or, in 
the case when the collective bargaining agreement is silent, as established by the city commission 
for non-bargaining unit employees. 
(b) ?The city is required to make annual contributions to the plan which are at least equal to the 
minimum as required under Florida Statutes, Chapter 112. 
(c) ?Effective as of the first payroll check issued after June, 2009, the city shall pick up the employee 
contributions at the rate set forth in this section, as provided in section 414(h)(2) of the Internal 
Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. The amount picked up by the city shall be treated as employer 
contributions for tax purposes. However, for all purposes of determining benefits under the plan, they 
will be considered employee contributions. 
(d) ?Refund of member contributions. 
(1) ?Vested member. 
a. ?In the event a member who has a vested interest in the plan and who has contributed to 
the plan pursuant to this section, separates from city employment prior to the normal or 
optional retirement date, such member may leave his/her employee contributions in the 
plan and receive a deferred benefit commencing at the normal retirement date, based on 
the member's vested interest, years of creditable service and average final compensation 
as of the date of separation. In lieu of a deferred benefit, the member may elect to receive 
a refund of one hundred (100) percent of the employee contributions, without interest. Any 
member who accepts such refund shall be forever barred from receiving benefits under the 
plan. 
b. ?In the event a member who has not selected a joint and survivor annuity separates from 
city employment after attaining a vested interest in the plan and dies prior to the 
commencement of benefits at the normal retirement date, the member's designated 
beneficiary shall receive one hundred (100) percent of the member's contributions to the 
plan, without interest. 
(2) ?Non-vested member. In the event a member separates from city employment other than by 
disability before attaining a vested interest in the plan, such member shall receive a refund of 
one hundred (100) percent of the employee contributions to the plan, without interest. 
(e) ?Notwithstanding any other provision of the plan, effective October 1, 2011 member contributions to 
the plan shall cease. Employees who were participants of this plan on September 30, 2011 who 
become participants of the city's defined contribution plan on or after October 1, 2011 shall make 
mandatory contributions to the city's defined contribution plan established pursuant to Resolution R-
2011-103, as provided in the defined contribution plan. Employer contributions to this plan shall 
continue in accordance with subsection (b) above, until the plan is fully funded and additional 
contributions are no longer required as determined by the plan actuary. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. VI, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-82-15, § 3, 7-7-82; Ord. No. O-88-14, § 8, 6-1-
88; Ord. No. O-2009-013, § 3, 7-1-09; Ord. No. O-2009-020, § 1, 9-16-2009; Ord. No. O-2011-
021, § 4, 9-12-11) 


Sec. 9-35. - Form of retirement income. 
(a) ?Normal annuity form . The normal form of retirement income is a life annuity—five years certain 
annuity, which provides monthly payments beginning at the participant's retirement date, provided he 
is then living, and ending with the last monthly payment due before his death or the end of the 
certain period, whichever is later. Payments will be made to the participant, while living, and, after his 
death, any annuity payments becoming due will be paid to the beneficiary authorized to receive such 
payments in accordance with section 9-39. The certain period is a period of sixty (60) months 
beginning at the participant's retirement date. 
(b) ?Optional annuity form . Subject to the conditions and restrictions set forth in paragraph (b) below, a 
participant may elect to have his annuity benefit payable on the optional annuity forms set forth in 
paragraph (1) below in lieu of on the normal annuity form. 
(1) ?Forms described: 
    Joint and survivor five years certain life annuity . This option provides monthly payments 
beginning at the participant's retirement date and payable during the lifetime of the participant. 
Said payments shall continue after the participant's death, in the same or a reduced amount, to 
the joint annuitant designated by the participant prior to the participant's retirement for the 
lifetime of said joint annuitant. After the deaths of the participant and the joint annuitant, monthly 
payments in the amount payable to the participant will continue to a beneficiary designated by 
the participant prior to the participant's retirement until at least a total of sixty (60) such monthly 
payments have been made (including the payments made to the participant and the joint 
annuitant). 
(2) ?Conditions and restrictions: 
    The participant shall file in writing his election of the optional form with the board before his 
retirement date. 
    If the election of an optional annuity form would result in monthly payments to any person 
of less than five dollars ($5.00) each, such election shall not become operative except upon the 
specific consent in writing of the board. 
    If the participant or the joint annuitant dies before the participant's retirement date, the 
election of the optional annuity form shall not be effective. 
    The participant is to designate, on the form on which the optional annuity form of payment 
is elected, his joint annuitant and the percentage (not to exceed one hundred (100) percent) of 
the monthly annuity payments to the participant to be continued to the joint annuitant. The 
designation of any person as joint annuitant shall not constitute such person a beneficiary with 
respect to any other benefit provided under this plan. 
    Proof satisfactory to the board of the age of the joint annuitant shall be furnished within 
ninety (90) days after the board receives the election of the optional annuity form, but in no 
event later than the participant's retirement date. 
    The participant may not revoke his election of the optional annuity form nor change the 
designated joint annuitant or the amount payable to the joint annuitant without the written 
consent of the board. 
(c) ?Optional temporary annuity . In order that a participant who retires under this plan before the earliest 
date upon which his primary insurance benefits may commence under the Social Security Act may 
receive a level income where the monthly annuity payable under this plan is taken together with the 
participant's primary insurance benefit under the Social Security Act, such participant may, with the 
consent of the board, elect to convert a portion of his lifetime annuity to an actuarially equivalent 
temporary annuity to be determined by the board. 
    The temporary annuity provides for monthly payments commencing at the participant's 
retirement date, provided he is living, and terminating with the monthly payment next preceding the 
earlier of: 
(1) ?The date of the participant's death, and 
(2) ?A date that the board will designate on or before the participant's retirement date. Such election 
may be made by filing a proper written request with the board before the participant's retirement 
date. 
(d) ?City managers . If the city manager or assistant city manager, by written agreement, has elected an 
optional retirement plan, the amount of retirement income will be provided by said plan. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. VII, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-88-14, § 9, 6-1-88) 


Sec. 9-36. - Disability benefits. 
(1) ?A participant in the plan will become eligible for a disability benefit upon a finding of disability by the 
Social Security Administration for disabilities occurring on or after the date of employment of the 
participant with the city. Upon a finding of disability, the disability benefits in the amount of sixty-six 
and two-thirds (66 2/3 ) percent of annual salary at time of disability, less Social Security and 
Workmen's Compensation Benefits, shall commence on the first day of the sixth month coinciding 
with or next following the date of disability. The disability benefits will only be payable for the period 
of time when an employee is eligible for and receives disability benefits under the Social Security 
Act. The disability benefits provided in this subsection 9-36(1) shall continue to apply to all 
participants who are employed on September 30, 2011, for as long as they are an employee under 
the plan. 
(2) ?Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, it is the intent of this benefit to provide disability 
benefits only for disabilities occurring on or after the date of employment of the participant with the 
city and not for disabilities which existed prior thereto. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. VIII, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-82-15, § 4, 7-7-82; Ord. No. O-98-15, § 2, 7-
15-98; Ord. No. O-2011-021, § 5, 9-12-11) 


Sec. 9-37. - Termination of employment, membership in plan. 
(a) ?Participants . A participant whose service with the city is terminated prior to his retirement date and 
who has seven (7) or more years of service with the city under this plan as of his date of termination 
of service shall receive a benefit payable at his normal retirement date based on his service to the 
date of termination of employment in accordance with the following schedule: 
Years of Service 
Vested Percentage of Pension 
At least 7 years 
35 
Each year of service after 7 years 
5 
20 or more years of service 
100 
 
    Notwithstanding the above, a participant shall be one hundred (100) percent vested upon first 
becoming eligible for optional retirement or upon reaching his normal retirement date. 
    The monthly benefit payment as of a participant's normal retirement date is determined by the 
benefit calculated pursuant to section 9-33(a)(1) of the plan reduced proportionately for credited 
service less than twenty (20) years of service. Such accrued monthly benefit shall then be reduced 
by the vesting percentage determined by this subsection of the plan using the specific percentage of 
benefits set forth herein. 
(b) ?Optional retirement date; reduction of monthly payments . If an optional retirement date shall have 
been elected by a participant, the amount of the monthly payments commencing at the optional 
retirement date shall be reduced by three and one-tenth (3.1) percent for each of the years by which 
the starting date of the payment precedes normal retirement date. 
    The benefit reduction provided for in this subsection is in confirmation of and not in addition to the 
optional retirement date calculation provided for in section 9-33(a)(2). 
(c) ?Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth in this section, the right of a participant to a benefit 
as provided for hereunder is subject to the provisions of subsection 9-31(g) which shall control as to 
rights and eligibility to pension benefits under the provisions of this chapter. 
(d) ?Notwithstanding any other provision of the plan, a participant who elects to join the Florida 
Retirement System pursuant to section 9-31(b), and is employed by the city for a total of seven (7) or 
more years, including employment prior to and after joining the Florida Retirement System, shall be 
eligible to receive a normal retirement benefit from the plan upon reaching the normal retirement 
date and terminating city employment. The benefit payable to such participant shall be based upon 
the participant's service as of the last day of participation in the plan before joining the Florida 
Retirement System, and final average monthly earnings as of the date the participant terminates city 
employment. Such participant's vested percentage shall be determined in accordance with 
subsection (a), above, but based on all years of city employment. 
(e) ?Notwithstanding any other provision of the plan, effective September 30, 2011 the accrued benefits 
of employees who are participants in this plan on that date shall be frozen, and such participants 
shall not accrue benefits under this plan after that date. All such participants shall become one 
hundred (100) percent vested in their frozen accrued benefits under this plan as of September 30, 
2011. Such participants shall be eligible to receive their frozen accrued benefits, upon separation 
from employment and attaining eligibility for normal or optional retirement in accordance with the 
provisions of the plan in effect on September 29, 2011. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. IX, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-82-15, § 6, 7-7-82; Ord. No. O-83-17, § 7, 7-6-
83; Ord. No. O-84-18, § 1, 9-5-84; Ord. No. O-88-14, § 10, 6-1-88; Ord. No. O-93-22, § 5, 12-
15-93; Ord. No. O-98-14, § 3, 7-17-98; Ord. No. O-2007-022, § 5, 7-18-07; Ord. No. O-2011-
021, § 6, 9-12-11) 


Sec. 9-38. - Death benefits. 
    In the event of the death of a participant prior to his retirement date, who has a vested interest in the 
plan, a death benefit shall be paid to his designated beneficiary by a lump sum payment equal to one (1) 
times the annual pay for less than fifteen (15) years' service, and one and one-half (1 1/2) times the 
annual pay for over fifteen (15) years' service with an overall maximum of thirty thousand dollars 
($30,000.00). The death benefits provided in this Section 9-38 shall continue to apply to all participants 
who are employed on September 30, 2011, for as long as they are an employee under the plan 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. X, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-82-15, § 6, 7-7-82; Ord. No. O-2011-021, § 7, 9-
12-11) 


Sec. 9-39. - Beneficiary. 
    A participant may designate a beneficiary (with the right to change such designation) to receive any 
payment or payments to which a beneficiary may become entitled under this plan. Any other person to 
whom periodic payments are payable under this plan may designate (with the right to change such 
designation) a beneficiary to receive any single sum payment or any remaining periodic payments 
becoming due upon the death of such person, if no prior designation is then in effect with respect thereto. 
    If no designated beneficiary is surviving when a payment becomes payable to a beneficiary, any 
single sum payment of the commuted value of any monthly payments payable to a beneficiary shall be 
made to the person or persons in the first then surviving class of the following classes of successive 
preference beneficiaries: 
(a) ?The participant's widow or widower, or registered surviving domestic partner, as defined by and 
recorded with Broward County, or 
(b) ?The participant's surviving children, 
(c) ?The participant's surviving parents, 
(d) ?The participant's surviving brothers and sisters, or 
(e) ?The executors or administrators of the estate of the person upon whose death the payment 
becomes payable to a beneficiary. 
    In the absence of a duly appointed guardian, any minor's share of a benefit may be paid in monthly 
installments at a rate to be determined by the board to such adult or adults who have assumed the 
custody and principal support of the minor, provided such custody has been approved by an appropriate 
court of law. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XI, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-88-14, § 11, 6-1-88; Ord. No. O-2009-009, § 3, 
4-15-09) 


Sec. 9-40. - Small retirement income. 
    If the retirement income to which any participant becomes entitled should be less than five dollars 
($5.00) per month, the participant may be paid, in lieu of such income, a lump sum cash payment 
actuarially equivalent to such retirement income. 
    If periodic payments to any person would be less than twenty dollars ($20.00) per month, the 
fiduciary or board may pay at such intervals as will make each payment at least twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XII, 8-3-77) 


Sec. 9-41. - Nonalienation of benefits. 
(a) ?No benefits or beneficial interests provided for hereunder shall be subject in any manner to 
anticipation, alienation, sale, transfer, assignment, pledge, encumbrance, or charge, either voluntary 
or involuntary, and any attempt to so anticipate, alienate, sell, transfer, assign, pledge, encumber or 
charge the same shall be null and void; neither shall such benefits or beneficial interests be liable for 
or subject to the debts, contracts, liabilities, engagements or torts of any person to whom such 
benefits or funds are payable, and no such benefits or beneficial interests shall in any way be subject 
to any legal process to subject the same to the payment of any claims against such payee; except 
that it is permissible for a participant to authorize deductions from retirement benefits to provide 
premiums for group health and life insurance benefits for said participant and dependents, and 
deductions from a participant's benefit may be made in accordance with a qualified domestic 
relations order as provided in section 9-41(b), below. 
(b) ?Domestic Relations Order Exception: Effective January 1, 1985, the creation, assignment or 
recognition of a right to any benefit payable with respect to a participant pursuant to a "Qualified 
Domestic Relations Order" as defined in the Retirement Equity Act of 1984, shall not be treated as 
an assignment or alienation prohibited as set forth in section 9-41(a) above. The plan shall establish 
reasonable procedures to determine the qualified status of domestic relations orders, in accordance 
with the rules set forth in the Retirement Equity Act of 1984 and any regulations which may be 
prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury or the Secretary of Labor with regard to qualified 
domestic relations orders. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XIII, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-88-14, § 12, 6-1-88; Ord. No. O-2007-022, § 
6, 7-18-07) 


Sec. 9-42. - Amendment and termination of the plan. 
(a) ?Although the city intends to continue the plan indefinitely, it reserves the right at any time to amend 
or terminate the plan. However, no such action shall cause any part of the corpus or income of the 
plan to be used for, or diverted to purposes other than, the exclusive benefit of the participants, nor 
shall any such action adversely affect the retirement income already provided under the plan. In the 
event of a merger or consolidation of services which results in employees of the plan being 
employed by the Broward Sheriff's Office, the employees so affected shall have the option of 
remaining in this plan or participating in the Florida Retirement System (FRS). In no event shall an 
employee's rights be diminished or impaired in violation of F.S. § 112.0515. 
(b) ?This plan may be amended by the city from time to time in any respect whatever by delivery to the 
trustees of a copy of the ordinance of the City Commission of Oakland Park, Florida, specifying such 
amendment and duly certified by an official of the city, subject to the following limitations: 
(1) ?Under no condition shall such amendment or amendments result in or permit the return or 
repayment to the city of any property held or acquired by the trustee hereunder, or the proceeds 
thereof, or result in or permit the distribution of any such property for the benefit of anyone other 
than employees of the city who are beneficiaries under the plan, except to the extent provided 
by section 9-52(b). 
(2) ?The city shall notify board members, in writing, of any amendments to the Ordinance which 
would affect their duties and responsibilities. 
(c) ?This plan may be terminated at any time by an ordinance of the City Commission of Oakland Park, 
Florida, duly certified by an official of the city, specifying that: 
(1) ?The plan is being terminated; or 
(2) ?Contributions hereunder are permanently discontinued; provided, however, that such 
termination shall not become effective until two (2) years after the effective date of the 
ordinance, unless an earlier termination date is specified in such ordinance. 
(d) ?This plan shall automatically terminate when no cash or other property remains in the trust fund. 
(e) ?In the event of discontinuance of the plan, the contributions made by the city will remain for the 
exclusive benefit of participants under the plan. In the event of the termination of the plan, the fund, 
to the extent sufficient therefore, shall be allocated toward providing retirement benefits herein for 
participants in the following order of precedence, based on service to the date of termination: 
(1) ?To provide retirement benefits for participants who had reached their normal retirement date 
but had not retired on the date of termination; 
(2) ?To provide retirement benefits for participants who were eligible for early retirement but had not 
retired on the date of termination of the plan; 
(3) ?To provide retirement benefits for participants who would have been eligible for retirement 
benefits if their employment had been terminated on the date of termination of the plan; 
(4) ?To provide retirement benefits for all other participants on the basis of years of service to the 
date of termination. 
If the balance remaining for allocation under any of the foregoing paragraphs is insufficient to provide in 
full the allocations under such paragraph, allocations to individual participants under such paragraph shall 
be reduced pro rata and no allocations shall be made under subsequent paragraphs. 
After all of the foregoing allocations have been made, any amounts remaining shall be returned to the 
city. 
(f) ?In the event the plan is terminated or contributions to the trust are permanently discontinued, the 
benefits of each participant in the plan on such date of termination or discontinuance are 
nonforfeitable and shall be one hundred (100) percent vested to the extent then funded. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XIV, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-82-15, § 7, 7-7-82; Ord. No. O-2000-013, § 3, 
6-21-00; Ord. No. O-2007-022, § 7, 7-18-07) 


Sec. 9-43. - General provisions. 
(a) ?Each participant entitled to benefits under the plan shall furnish to the board such evidence, data or 
information as the board considers necessary or desirable in order to properly administer the plan. 
(b) ?At the time of retirement, each retired participant will receive from the board a certificate outlining 
the amount of annuity and the conditions of payment. 
(c) ?The provisions of the contract between the board and the fiduciary shall govern with respect to the 
rights and obligations of the fiduciary, notwithstanding any contrary provisions of the plan. 
(d) ?If a participant's membership in the plan is discontinued and subsequently followed by re-entry into 
the plan, such re-entry shall be on a uniform, nondiscriminatory basis, and in no event will any 
duplication of benefits result therefrom. Upon re-entry a participant who has a vested interest in the 
plan shall be additionally credited for any subsequent period of continuous service of seven (7) years 
or more. A participant shall not be credited for any period of service, either prior or subsequent to re-
entry into the plan, which is less than seven (7) continuous years. The payment of retirement 
benefits to a participant shall be suspended during any period of re-employment of the participant by 
the city. Retirement benefits shall then be calculated for the participant based upon the credited 
service at the time of retirement by the participant subsequent to the re-employment period. 
(e) ?Forfeitures arising from the termination of a participant's employment, death or for any other reason, 
shall not be used to provide additional benefits for the remaining participants but shall be used to 
reduce the next immediate contribution by the city. 
(f) ?All dividends earned on insurance and annuity contracts held hereunder shall be applied against and 
used to reduce the current or next preceding year's contributions to the plan by the city. 
(g) ?Benefits or retirement income as provided for herein shall be limited to the specific statutory 
provisions restricting defined benefit plan benefits as provided for in Internal Revenue Code section 
415 as determined applicable to the payments hereunder pursuant to the Internal Revenue Code 
and regulations promulgated thereunder. Notwithstanding the foregoing, all increases in such 
limitations provided for under cost of living increases shall accrue to the benefit of the plan 
participants. To the extent applicable, the provisions of this plan are intended to meet the 
requirements of code section 415. If the administrator determines a conflict exists between the plan 
and code section 415, then code section 415 will supersede the plan in order to maintain qualified 
status thereof with the applicable regulatory entities with jurisdiction over this plan. 
(h) ?The plan administrator may charge, in addition to the actual cost of duplication, a reasonable 
service charge or actual costs incurred for purposes of reimbursing the plan for actuarial information 
technology resources or the labor costs of the personnel providing the service that is actually 
incurred by the plan or chargeable to the plan for the clerical and supervisory assistance required to 
obtain information, benefit calculations, or other documentation or information otherwise requested 
by or required of a participant. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XV, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-82-15, § 8, 7-7-82; Ord. No. O-93-22, § 6, 12-
15-93; Ord. No. O-98-15, § 4, 7-15-98; Ord. No. O-1999-006, § 4, 5-19-99) 


Sec. 9-44. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2007-22, § 8, adopted July 18, 2007, repealed former § 9-44 in its 
entirety which pertained administration of the plan and derived from Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. 
XVI, adopted Aug. 3, 1977. 


Sec. 9-45. - Contributions to the trust fund. 
    Subject to the provisions of section 9-51 hereof, the city, on behalf of itself and its employees is 
required to deliver or cause to be delivered to the trustee such amounts of cash and other property 
acceptable to the trustee as the fiduciary or an actuary (or an independent actuary engaged by the 
trustee to make such determination) deems necessary to comply with the provisions of the plan. All such 
amounts received by the trustee from the city shall constitute one (1) common fund and may be 
commingled. Unless the context clearly implies or indicates the contrary, the term "trust fund" comprises 
all property of every kind held by the trustee, from time to time, pursuant to this agreement. The trustee 
shall have no duty, express or implied, to compel any payment to be made to it by the city, or otherwise 
be responsible for the adequacy of the trust fund to meet and discharge any liabilities under the plan, and 
shall be accountable only for cash and other property actually received by it. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XVII, 8-3-77) 


Sec. 9-46. - Payments from the trust fund. 
    Payments shall be made from the trust fund by the trustee to such persons, in such manner, at such 
times, and in such amounts as the trustee may from time to time determine in writing; provided, however, 
that the trustee may withhold compliance with or modify its payment determinations if the trustee shall 
deem such withholding or modification necessary to insure payment of the trustee's expenses or to 
protect the trustee against liability for taxes or any other liability. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XVIII, 8-3-77) 


Sec. 9-47. - Investment of the trust fund. 
(a) ?The trust fund, except such estimated amounts as, in the opinion of the board, are required to meet 
current payments and expenses, shall be invested and reinvested by the board without distinction 
between principal and income. Subject to the provisions of this section 9-47 and paragraphs (a) and 
(b) of section 9-48, the board is authorized to: 
(1) ?Make deposits in federally insured financial institutions; and 
(2) ?Invest and reinvest the trust fund in such bonds, notes, debentures, mortgages, equipment 
trust certificates, investment trust certificates, preferred or common stock, or in such other 
property, real, personal, or mixed, either within or without the State of Florida, as it may deem 
advisable, in compliance with the standards for investment of trust funds set forth in Florida 
State Statute § 112.661. 
The board may, to the extent it deems advisable, invest in any common trust fund that qualifies 
under Section 401 (a) of the Internal Revenue Code, which is maintained by any bank in Florida 
or in any other state of the United States. The board may hold any portion of the trust fund in 
cash pending investment or payment of expenses or benefits without liability for interest. In 
purchasing investments, the board shall endeavor to exercise the judgment and care in the 
circumstances then prevailing which persons of prudence, discretion and intelligence exercise 
in the management of their own affairs, not in regard to speculation but in regard to the 
permanent disposition of their funds, considering the probable income as well as the probable 
safety of their capital. The board shall not be liable for the making, retaining or selling of any 
investment or reinvestment made by it as herein provided, or for any loss to or diminution of the 
trust fund, except such as may be due to a breach of the standards set forth herein, and for its 
own negligence, willful misconduct, or lack of good faith. 
(3) ?Invest as a participating employer in a master trust fund created for the purpose of receiving, 
holding, investing, reinvesting, managing, administering and distributing the assets of the plan 
to be held in common with other municipalities for a municipal public purpose subject to the 
supervision by the board of trustees and the provisions of this plan as to approval of any 
agreement with the trust fund by the board and the city commission. 
(b) ?Investments. 
(1) ?The board shall adopt and review annually a written investment policy, identifying the 
parameters for investment decisions, and consistently comply with its investment policy. The 
investment policy must be approved by the city commission at least annually, and any 
subsequent changes thereto must also be approved by the city commission. The previously-
approved investment policy shall remain in effect if the city commission fails to act, or 
disapproves the proposed amendment under review. The reasons for disapproval shall be set 
forth in writing and provided to the board. If the city commission disapproves a previously-
approved investment policy, the board shall resubmit a revised investment policy for approval. 
The city commission and the board shall act as soon as administratively convenient. 
(2) ?The board shall engage a firm or other entity ("investment firm") to manage the investments of 
the plan which firm shall have a background in investment management of municipal pension 
plans. The investment firm shall submit a quarterly investment report to the board within a 
maximum of sixty (60) days of the end of each quarter. The investment report shall include a 
certification that the plan investments are in compliance with the adopted investment policy; the 
investment portfolio composition; whether investment benchmarks were met; the performance 
of the plan assets in the previous quarter, for the plan year-to-date, the trailing twelve (12) 
month period, and for the previous three plan years; and other investment information that the 
board may reasonably request. 
(3) ?The board shall engage an advisor ("investment monitor") that shall have a background in: (i) 
monitoring the performance of investment firms with respect to municipal pension plan 
investments and (ii) providing advice to municipal pension boards on selection and retention of 
investment firms. The investment monitor shall submit a quarterly report ("investment report") to 
the board within forty-five (45) days of the end of each quarter. Such investment report shall 
include a written analysis of the investment firm's performance in investing the trust assets for 
the following time periods: (i) the previous quarter, (ii) the plan year to date, (iii) the trailing 
twelve (12) months; and (iv) the previous three (3) plan years. The investment report shall also 
render an opinion as to whether the investments are in compliance with the investment policy of 
the board; if the investment benchmarks were met; and provide other investment information as 
the board shall reasonably request. 
(4) ?The board shall submit the investment firm's and the investment monitor's quarterly investment 
report to the city manager within fifteen (15) days of receipt by the board or plan administrator, 
whichever receives it first. 
(c) ?The board shall keep detailed written minutes of all meetings. A copy of the minutes of such 
meetings shall be furnished to the city manager promptly after each such meeting. The board shall 
keep and maintain recordings of all meetings and make such recordings available to the city 
manager upon request. The city manager shall also have full access to all data regarding 
investments. 
(d) ?The board may enter into a contract with a life insurance company for direct disbursement of 
retirement benefits or for the purchase of retirement annuities on an individual or group basis, in 
such manner and in such form as may be deemed appropriate by the board, as provided for in the 
plan, and specifically, such retirement annuities and other benefits as may be provided for in the plan 
may be purchased under one (1) or more deposit administration type group annuity contracts. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XIX, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-2004-018, § 2, 9-16-04; Ord. No. O-2004-018, 
§ 2, 6-16-04; Ord. No. O-2007-022, § 9, 7-18-07; Ord. No. O-2007-029, 10-3-07) 


Sec. 9-48. - Powers of the trustee. 
(a) ?Subject to the provisions of section 9-47, the trustee is authorized and empowered: 
(1) ?To sell, exchange, convey, transfer or dispose of and also to grant options with respect to any 
property, whether real or personal, at any time held by it, and any sale may be made by private 
contract or by public auction, and no person dealing with the trustee shall be bound to see to 
the application of the purchase money or to inquire into the validity, expediency or propriety of 
any such sale or other disposition; 
(2) ?To retain, manage, operate, repair and improve and to mortgage or lease for any period and on 
such terms as the trustee shall deem proper and real estate or personal property held by the 
trustee, including power to demolish any buildings or other improvements in whole or in part and 
to erect buildings or other improvements and to make leases that may extend beyond the term 
of the trust; and to foreclose, extend, renew, assign, release or partially release and discharge 
mortgages or other liens; 
(3) ?To compromise, compound and settle any debt or obligation due from third persons to it or to 
third persons from it as trustee hereunder, and to reduce the rate of interest on, to extend or 
otherwise to modify or to foreclose upon default or otherwise to enforce such obligation; 
(4) ?To vote in person or by proxy, with or without power of substitution, on any stocks, bonds or 
other securities held by it; to exercise any options appurtenant to any stocks, bonds or other 
securities for the conversion thereof into other stocks, bonds or other securities for the 
conversion thereof into other stocks, bonds or securities, or to exercise any rights to subscribe 
for additional stocks, bonds or other securities and to make any and all necessary payments 
thereof; to join in, dissent from or oppose the reorganization, recapitalization, consolidation, sale 
or merger of corporations or properties in which it may be interested as trustee, upon such 
terms and conditions as it may deem wise and to accept any securities which may be issued 
upon any such reorganization, recapitalization, consolidation, sale or merger and thereafter to 
hold the same; 
(5) ?To make, execute, acknowledge and deliver any and all deeds, leases, assignments, 
documents of transfer and conveyance, documents of release and satisfaction and any and all 
other instruments that may be necessary or appropriate to carry out the powers herein granted; 
(6) ?To enforce any right, obligation or claim in its discretion and in general to protect in any way the 
interest of the trust fund, either before or after default; and in case it shall consider such action 
for the best interest of the trust fund, to abstain from the enforcement of any right, obligations or 
claim, to abandon any property, whether real or personal, which at any time may be held by it; 
(7) ?To borrow from anyone, including the trustee, such sum or sums, from time to time, as the 
trustee considers necessary or desirable and for the best interest of the trust fund and for that 
purpose to mortgage or pledge all or any part of the trust fund; 
(8) ?To cause any investment in the trust fund to be registered in or transferred into, its name as 
trustee, or the name or names of its nominee or nominees, or to retain them unregistered or in 
form permitting transferability by delivery, but the books and records of the trustee shall at all 
times show that all such investments are part of the trust fund; 
(9) ?To retain in cash or other property unproductive of income such portion of the trust fund as 
deemed advisable, without liability therefor; 
(10) ?If a bank, to deposit in its commercial banking department that portion of the trust fund as 
deemed advisable, without liability for the payment of any interest thereon; 
(11) ?To acquire property returning no income or slight income, or to retain any such property so 
long as the trustee shall deem advisable; 
(12) ?To purchase, convey, lease and otherwise deal with oil, gas and other minerals, mineral rights 
and royalties; to operate and develop oil, gas and other mineral properties and interests, 
including, but not limited to, the power to make and release oil, gas and mineral leases and 
subleases; to make mineral deeds and royalty transfers; to create, reserve and dispose of 
overriding royalties, oil payments, gas payments, and any other interests; to execute division 
orders and transfer orders; to enter into development and drilling contracts, operating 
agreements and unitization agreements; and to make agreements for present or future pooling 
of any and all interests in oil, gas and other minerals; 
(13) ?To consult with counsel, who may be counsel to the city, and in so doing shall be fully 
protected in acting upon the advice of such counsel; 
(14) ?To continue to exercise any powers and discretion herein granted for a reasonable time after 
the termination of the trust; 
(15) ?To utilize, if an individual or individuals, the facilities of any bank, as a depository; 
(16) ?To perform all acts which it may deem necessary or proper and to exercise any and all 
powers of the trustee under this agreement upon such terms and conditions as it may deem for 
the best interest of the trust fund. 
(b) ?In addition to the powers and authorities herein elsewhere granted, except as herein expressly 
provided otherwise, the trustee shall have the powers, authorities and discretions set forth in the 
laws of the State of Florida insofar as applicable hereto. The powers and authorities granted to the 
trustee shall not be limited by the fact that such trustee may be a bank or other financial institution, 
and no trustee duly appointed, qualified and acting hereunder shall be subject to limitations or 
restrictions imposed upon a bank or other financial institution or upon fiduciaries generally with 
respect to the type of investment any such institution or trustee may make of its own funds or the 
funds or others. Specifically such trustee may retain, acquire or otherwise deal in stock for which it is 
registrar, transfer agent, and the like, may deposit trust funds with itself as a bank, may contract or 
otherwise enter into transactions between itself as trustee and as a bank or between itself as trustee 
and any other institution for which it then, therefore, or thereafter may be acting as trustee, subject to 
the laws of the State of Florida. 
(c) ?Wherever and as often as the trustee deems such action desirable, it may by written instrument 
appoint any person or corporation in any state of the United States to act as ancillary trustee with 
respect to any portion of the trust assets then held or about to be acquired on behalf of the trustee. 
Each such ancillary trustee shall have such rights, powers, duties and discretions as are delegated 
to it by the trustee, but shall exercise the same subject to such limitations or further directions of the 
trustee as shall be specified in the instrument evidencing its appointment. The ancillary trustee may 
resign or may be removed by the trustee, as to all or any portion of the assets so held at any time or 
from time to time, by written instrument delivered one to the other, and the trustee may thereupon 
appoint another ancillary trustee or successor to whom the assets shall be promptly transferred, or 
may itself receive such assets in termination of the ancillary trusteeship to that extent. Such ancillary 
trustee shall be accountable solely to the trustee and shall be entitled to reasonable compensation. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XX, 8-3-77) 


Sec. 9-49. - Administrative provisions. 
(a) ?The board shall maintain true and accurate records and accounts reflecting all receipts and 
disbursements made by it pursuant to the plan and containing a description of all assets held by it. 
Such records and accounts shall be open to the inspection of the city at all reasonable times and 
may be audited from time to time by such person or persons as the city may designate. 
(b) ?Each year, the board shall distribute to all participants of the plan an annual report ("annual report") 
which shall include highlights of the past year's activities and the prior plan year's performance of the 
trust investments. The annual report shall be distributed no later than one hundred eighty (180) days 
after the end of the plan year. 
(c) ?The board shall meet, at a minimum, on a quarterly basis. A quorum of the board shall constitute a 
majority of all of the members of the board. A majority of a quorum shall approve any action by the 
board, except for the appointment and removal of an approved professional or a change in the 
investment policy, which will require at least four (4) board member votes. 
(d) ?Professional services: 
(1) ?Subject to the city commission's right to approve and remove as set forth below, the board 
shall engage the following professionals ("professional(s)"): Investment monitor, actuarial firm, 
independent auditor, and investment firm after undertaking reasonable due diligence as to the 
experience, reputation, cost and quality of the selected professionals. However, the 
engagement of any professional shall not be effective until (i) the city commission formally 
approves the engagement of each professional (an "approved professional") and (ii) the board 
and the respective professional execute a "professional service contract," as defined in this 
section (d)(4). If the city commission shall not affirmatively approve or disapprove the respective 
professional within sixty (60) days after written notification of the proposed engagement of the 
professional by the board, such engagement shall be deemed to have been approved by the 
city commission. 
(2) ?The board shall select the professionals using objective and subjective criteria related to the 
professional standards for each profession. At least once every sixty (60) months, the board 
shall select professionals through a formal selection process in which the board issues a 
request for proposals ("RFP") and duly examines, compares, and ranks the qualifications of the 
firms or persons who submit proposals meeting the requirements of the RFP. A general RFP 
request shall be sent at least thirty (30) days prior to the selection interview date that shall 
describe the duties of the position and the selection process. The board may select for interview 
any or all of RFP respondents as the board shall determine. In addition, RFPs may be 
selectively sent to specific firms or persons as the board may select, including existing approved 
professionals, in order to achieve a reasonable sample of qualified candidates for selection. 
However, if the board determines that a single entity with extensive experience providing 
investment management, investment monitoring and administrative services for municipal 
pension plans, can provide these services for a fee that is less than that of the combined fees of 
individual professionals or firms providing these services, upon a finding by the board that the 
selection has been made utilizing a process consistent with the selection of the approved 
professional using objective and subjective criteria related to the professional standards of the 
professionals as defined herein, the board may, subject to City Commission approval, select 
such entity as a professional to provide these services. Once a professional is selected by the 
board and approved by the city commission, the board may grant professional service contracts 
to such approved professionals. 
(3) ?Other than the professionals under subsection (d)(1), without approval of the city commission, 
the board may engage such persons, agents, or entities, including fiduciaries, as in its discretion 
may be required or advisable to enable it to perform custodial and investment duties hereunder; 
provided further, the board may enter into agency, investment, advisory and custodial 
agreements for the purpose of securing investment and custodianship services for the system 
and fund. 
(4) ?Each contract for the appointment of any professional by the board (a "professional service 
contract") shall be for a term of no longer than two (2) years, with a maximum of three (3) one-
year renewal options. Renewals of the professional service contracts for approved professionals 
shall require city commission approval. Each of the board's professional service contracts shall 
clearly set forth the board's and city commission'sability to terminate the approved 
professional's services pursuant to subparagraph (d)(5) and set forth performance standards 
and contract requirements under the plan. 
(5) ?The board shall retain the ability to terminate any professional service contract with or without 
cause and without approval by the city commission. The city commission shall also have the 
right to terminate any professional service contract with cause and without approval of the 
board, which termination shall supersede any action to the contrary which may be taken by the 
board. The term "with cause" shall mean: 
(i) ?A final disciplinary determination by the responsible professional or regulatory authority 
governing such professional, the suspension or revocation of the respective professional's 
license which is required to engage in the services for which the professional is engaged, 
either temporarily or permanently, and wherever situated, including revocation of an 
unrelated license by the relevant licensing authority on account of disciplinary proceedings; 
(ii) ?A material breach of any provision(s) of any contract with the board or the city, or any 
other failure to perform diligently and in good faith any provision(s) of such a contract, after 
reasonable prior notice from either the board or the city specifying the nature of the alleged 
breach or failure and after reasonable opportunity to correct the alleged breach or failure, 
provided such correction is possible; 
(iii) ?Conviction of, or pleading guilty or no contest to, any crime; 
(iv) ?Failure to perform professional services according to the standard of care required in the 
professional's respective profession or within the time frames set forth herein; or 
(v) ?Engaging in or committing any act of notoriety, including acts or omissions of the 
professional's firm or institution which create adverse publicity for the firm, institution or 
directly or indirectly to the city. 
(6) ?The board shall engage an attorney who shall advise the board prior to the board entering into 
agreements and contracts, and on other legal matters. 
(7) ?The board shall engage a plan administrator who is not a board member, who shall prepare 
agendas, minutes, computations, motions and other required documentation for the board. 
(8) ?Subject to the foregoing provisions of appointment and removal, the board shall engage an 
independent auditor who shall provide audited annual financial statements to the board. The 
board shall provide a copy of the audited annual financial statements to the city commission no 
later than one hundred fifty (150) days from the end of the plan's fiscal year. 
(9) ?Subject to the foregoing provisions of appointment and removal, the board shall engage an 
actuarial firm who shall submit actuarial reports and recommendations to the city commission 
and the board no later than one hundred eighty (180) days after the close of the plan's fiscal 
year. The city manager shall furnish to the board all data reasonably required for the actuarial 
computations within forty-five (45) days after the end of the city's fiscal year. The board shall 
furnish to the actuarial firm all data required and/or requested for the actuarial computations 
within sixty (60) days after the end of the plan year. Failure of the city manager or the board to 
furnish the foregoing information within sixty (60) days after the plan year shall extend the 180-
day period by as many days as such information is late. 
(e) ?The city manager, utilizing city funds, may obtain independent financial and/or actuarial analysis 
and evaluation of fund activities and make periodic reports to the city commission. The city manager 
shall provide a copy of any such report or analysis to the board. 
(f) ?The board shall institute, maintain, or defend any litigation required for the preservation of the trust 
fund or in connection with the administration of the trust fund. The trust fund shall be obligated to pay 
on behalf of the board all expenses and/or liabilities incurred as a result of institution, maintenance or 
defense of any litigation related to the trust fund. 
(g) ?The board shall be reimbursed for all of its expenses incurred as provided within this plan, and such 
expenses shall be paid from the trust fund. All expenses shall be specifically authorized by the board 
and records maintained of all such approvals. 
(h) ?No person shall be obliged to see to the application of any money or property delivered to the 
board. The certificate of the board, duly executed, may be received by any person dealing with the 
board as conclusive evidence of any matter relating to this agreement or the administration thereof. 
In general, each person dealing with the board may act upon any advice, request or representation 
in writing by the board, or the board's duly authorized agent, and shall not be liable to any person in 
so doing. In case of doubt as to whether the board has or has not been granted a specific power not 
enumerated hereunder, the certificate of the board that the exercise of such power is necessary or 
desirable for the proper administration or distribution of the trust fund shall be conclusive upon all 
persons dealing with the board to the same extent as if such power had been specifically granted to 
the board. 
(i) ?The board may require any certificate, notice or other instrument or information believed by it to be 
necessary to perform its duties hereunder, and may rely and act upon the basis of any such 
certificate, notice, instrument or other information furnished to the board which it believes to be 
reliable and to have been signed, made or presented by the proper party or parties, except that any 
action herein permitted or required to be taken by the city shall be by resolution of its city 
commission or by a person authorized by resolution of its city commission to take such action. 
(j) ?The board shall not be liable for its action in making payment or delivery of any cash or other 
property to any person other than fraud, and, in the event of litigation, actual or threatened, the board 
shall not be liable for declining to make delivery thereof until final adjudication shall have been made 
by a court of competent jurisdiction or by agreement of the parties. 
(k) ?The city intends that the trust herein established for the purpose of implementing the plan shall 
qualify under applicable provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, and until 
advised to the contrary in writing, the board may assume that the trust is so qualified. In the event 
the board at any time believes in good faith that such exemption is uncertain, the board may, but is 
not required to, take such steps and withhold such payments as it deems necessary to protect the 
fund. 
(l) ?The city shall deliver to the board at the time of making payment of each contribution and at any 
other such time as the trustee shall request a written statement which shall certify: 
(1) ?The names and addresses and social security numbers, if any, of all persons who at the end of 
such fiscal year are participants (including those who may have become participants during or 
as of the end of such fiscal year); 
(2) ?The names and addresses, if any, of all persons who were participants in the plan and whose 
employment has been terminated by retirement, death or disability; 
(3) ?The amount of benefits, if any, in accordance with the provisions of the plan, that shall be 
payable to an eligible employee and the date or dates as of which the payment of such benefits 
shall commence; and 
(4) ?Any other information necessary to the proper administration of this plan and the provisions 
hereunder. 
(m) ?A certification in writing to the board from or by the city as to the occurrence or happening of any 
event contemplated in and by the plan shall constitute conclusive evidence of such occurrence or 
happening, and the board hereunder shall be fully protected in accepting and relying upon such 
certification and shall incur no liability or responsibility for so doing. 
(n) ?The board shall administer the plan subject to the duties, powers, and responsibilities imposed on it 
under this plan. 
(o) ?Title to all property and records or true copies of such records necessary to the operation of the 
trust fund held by the board hereunder shall vest in any successor board acting pursuant to the 
provisions hereof without the execution or filing of any further instrument. Any resigning or removed 
board member shall execute all instruments and do all acts necessary, if any, to vest such title in any 
successor board member of record. Each successor board member shall have, exercise and enjoy 
all the powers, both discretionary and ministerial, herein conferred upon his predecessor. No 
successor board member shall be obligated to examine the accounts, records and acts of any 
previous board member or board, and each successor board member in no way or manner shall be 
responsible for any action or omission to act on the part of any previous board member. 
(p) ?Any corporation resulting from any merger or consolidation to which the board may be a party, or 
succeeding to the trust business of the board, or to which substantially all the trust assets of the 
board may be transferred, shall be the successor to the board hereunder without any further act or 
formality with like effect as if such successor board had originally been named trustee herein; and, in 
any such event, it shall not be necessary for the board or any successor board to give notice thereof 
to any person, and any requirement, statutory or otherwise, that notice shall be given is hereby 
waived. 
(q) ?The city commission may certify to any party, fiduciary or any other person as to the identity of the 
trustees under the plan at any time. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XXI, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-83-6, §§ 1, 2, 1-19-83; Ord. No. O-88-14, § 
13, 6-1-88; Ord. No. O-2004-018, § 2, 6-16-04; Ord. No. O-2007-022, § 10, 7-18-07; Ord. No. 
O-2007-029, § 3, 10-3-07) 


Sec. 9-50. - Board of trustees. 
(a) ?Prior to October 1, 2011, the general administration and responsibility for the proper operation of the 
plan and for making effective the provisions of this article are hereby vested in a board of trustees 
("board") consisting of seven (7) members as follows: 
(1) ?The city commission shall appoint three (3) members ("commission appointees") who shall not 
be employees of the city. To the extent possible, commission appointees shall have some 
professional financial or professional investment experience. The current board members who 
have been appointed by the city commission shall serve in their respective capacities for the 
balance of their current terms subsequent to this amendment to section 9-50. Notwithstanding 
the foregoing sentence, any commission appointee may be removed and replaced by the city 
commission at any time, with or without cause, upon written notice to the respective commission 
appointee. 
(2) ?The general employees of the city shall elect three (3) board members ("employee 
appointees"). To be eligible for election as a board member, an employee must be a general 
employee of the city, have elected to continue participation in the plan pursuant to section 9-
31(b), and be vested in the plan under the terms of section 9-37 hereof. To be eligible to vote 
for a board member, an employee must be a general employee of the city who elected to 
continue participation in the plan pursuant to section 9-31(b); or a general employee of the city 
who was vested in the plan on October 1, 2007, and elected to become a member of the Florida 
Retirement Plan pursuant to section 9-31(b). The current board members who have been 
elected by the general employees shall serve out the balance of their current terms subsequent 
to this amendment to section 9-50. 
(3) ?The city's finance director or designee shall serve as the seventh board member. 
(4) ?Attendance policy for members of this board is governed by section 2-72 of this Code of 
Ordinances. 
(5) ?Board members, except the city's finance director or designee, shall each serve forty-eight (48) 
month terms. 
(b) ?Effective October 1, 2011, the board of trustees provided for in subsection (a) above is hereby 
dissolved and the general administration and responsibility for the proper operation of the plan and 
for making effective the provisions of this article are thereafter vested in a board of trustees 
consisting of three (3) members as follows: 
(1) ?The city manager or designee; 
(2) ?The director of financial services or designee as appointed by the city manager; and 
(3) ?The human resources director or designee as appointed by the city manager. 
(c) ?In lieu of the board serving as trustee and designating an investment firm as otherwise provided in 
this article, the board may engage an entity having (i) experience in the administration of municipal 
pension plans and (ii) trust powers within the State of Florida as trustee of the General Employees' 
Pension Plan (the "alternate trustee"). Such alternate trustee must, at a minimum, invest trust funds 
as required of the board under section 9-47 entitled "Investment of the trust fund." Such alternate 
trustee must comply with the same reporting requirements as the investment firm as provided in this 
article. The board's engagement of an alternate trustee shall not be effective until the city 
commission approves by the engagement of such alternate trustee. The board shall retain the ability 
to terminate any alternate trustee with or without cause and without approval by the city commission. 
The city commission shall have the right to terminate any alternate trustee with cause and without 
approval of the board, which termination shall supersede any action to the contrary that may be 
taken by the board. The term "with cause" shall have the same meaning as in subsection 9-49(d)(5). 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XXII, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-84-18, § 1, 9-5-84; Ord. No. O-88-14, § 14, 6-
1-88; Ord. No. O-88-21, § 3, 7-20-88; Ord. No. O-2004-018, § 2, 6-16-04; Ord. No. O-2006-004, 
§ 2, 4-5-06; Ord. No. O-2007-022, § 11, 7-18-07; Ord. No. O-2008-003, § 2, 1-9-08; Ord. No. O-
2009-020, § 2, 9-16-09; Ord. No. O-2011-021, § 8, 9-12-11; Ord. No. O-2015-005, § 2, 3-4-15) 


Sec. 9-51. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2007-022, § 12, adopted July 18, 2007, repealed former § 9-51 in its 
entirety which pertained to amendment and termination of the plan and derived from Ord. No. O-
77-11, Art. XXIII, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-2004-008, § 2, 3-3-04. 


Sec. 9-52. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a) ?The city assumes no obligation or responsibility for any act or omission of the trustee hereunder. 
The trustee assumes no obligation or responsibility with respect to any action on the part of the city 
required by this agreement. No personal liability whatever shall attach to or be incurred by any 
official or employee, as such, of the city, under or by reason of the terms or conditions contained in 
or implied from this agreement. The duties, obligations and rights of the trustee shall be limited to 
and by the provisions of this agreement; and the city agrees to deliver to the trustee a copy of each 
amendment to the plan within thirty (30) days of the date of such amendment duly certified by an 
official of the city. 
(b) ?The city shall have no beneficial interest in the trust fund or any part thereof, and no part of the trust 
fund shall ever revert or be repaid to the city either directly or indirectly, except for such part of the 
trust fund, if any, which remains in the trust after satisfaction of all liabilities to persons entitled to 
benefits under the plan. 
(c) ?The laws of the State of Florida shall govern, control and determine all questions arising with 
respect to the trust fund and interpretation and validity of the provisions of this agreement. In the 
event any provision or provisions of this agreement shall be held illegal or invalid for any reason, said 
illegality or invalidity shall not affect the remaining provisions of this agreement, but shall be fully 
severable and the agreement shall be construed and enforced as if said illegal or invalid provision or 
provisions had never been inserted herein. 
(d) ?This plan shall be binding upon persons who are entitled to any benefits hereunder, their heirs and 
legal representatives, and upon the city, the trustee and their respective successors and assigns. 
(e) ?No benefit formula, decision, plan distribution or other act taken by the board of trustees shall 
discriminate against any participant based on color, national origin, sex, or marital status; however, if 
a participant elects a joint annuitant option and the participant selects such option specifying the 
participant's spouse to receive the benefits which continue to be payable upon the death of the 
participant, this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit such election as a violation of this 
declaration of intent to apply benefits in a nondiscriminatory fashion. The plan administrator may 
modify benefit calculations and make modifications necessary to adjust or make payments 
hereunder in order to pay the benefits and apply the plan provisions in a nondiscriminatory manner. 
Nothing herein shall preclude the plan for actuarially adjusting benefits or offering options based 
upon age, early retirement, or disability, as may be allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. O-77-11, Art. XXIV, 8-3-77; Ord. No. O-93-22, § 7, 12-15-93; Ord. No. O-2007-022, 
§ 13, 7-18-07) 


Secs. 9-53—9-60. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IV. - POLICE, FIREFIGHTERS AND PUBLIC SAFETY OFFICERS RETIREMENT SYSTEM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-95-10, § 1, adopted July 5, 1995, is codified herein as superseding former 
Art. IV, §§ 9-61—9-69, providing for a municipal police, firefighters and public safety officers retirement 
system. Said former sections were derived from Ord. No. O-75-15, §§ 1—9, adopted Dec. 3, 1975. 
Cross reference— Fire department generally, § 6-1 et seq.; police, Ch. 10. 


Sec. 9-61. - Definitions. 
    As used herein, unless otherwise defined or required by the context, the following words and 
phrases shall have the meaning indicated: 
    Actuarial assumption means the 1951 Group Mortality Table projected to 1965 by Scale C and 
interest at eight (8) percent. Each beneficiary's age shall be set back by five (5) years. 
    Agreement for fire and EMS services means an agreement entered into on August 1, 1991, which 
merged the Oakland Park Fire Department into the Broward County Fire Department and which was 
repealed on November 1, 1992, recreating the Oakland Park Fire Department. 
    Average monthly earnings means one twelfth ( 1/12 ) of the arithmetic average of annual earnings 
for the highest consecutive thirty-six (36) month period of continuous employment, or the member's five 
(5) highest years during the past ten (10) years, whichever is greater. 
    Beneficiary means the person or persons entitled to receive benefits hereunder at the death of a 
member (but only to the extent so permitted by the system) who has or have been designated in writing 
by the member and filed with the board. If no such designation is in effect at the time of death of the 
member, or if no person so designated is living at the time, the beneficiary shall be the surviving spouse 
of such participant, or if there be none, the lineal heirs of such participant, per stirpes, or if there be none, 
the estate of the last to die of such participant or his beneficiary. 
    Board means the board of trustees; which shall administer and manage the system herein provided 
and serve as trustee of the fund. 
    City means City of Oakland Park, Florida. 
    Code means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
    Continuous service means uninterrupted service by a member, expressed as years and completed 
calendar months from the date he last entered employment as an employee until the date his 
employment shall be terminated by reason of his death, disability, resignation, discharge, early normal or 
deferred retirement; provided, however, the continuous service of any member shall not be deemed to be 
interrupted by: 
(1) ?Any period of disability, authorized leave of absence or vacation, provided that all members 
similarly situated in similar circumstances shall be treated alike pursuant to uniform, 
nondiscriminatory rules. 
(2) ?Any service, voluntary or involuntary in the Armed Forces of the United States, provided the 
member is legally entitled to re-employment under the provisions of the Universal Training and 
Service Act, and any amendments thereto, or any law applicable to such re-employment. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing, no credit for eligibility or benefit computation purposes under the 
system shall be allowed for any period or leave of absence or military service, unless the 
granting of credit is otherwise required by law. 
(3) ?Any leave of absence permitted by the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. 
    County means Broward County, Florida. 
    Earnings means basic wages and longevity pay of a member, excluding overtime, bonuses, holiday 
premiums, vacation premiums, and any other nonregular payments. Earnings for firefighters who have 
become county employees shall be as defined above. For any year beginning after December 31, 1988, a 
member's annual earnings for purposes of the system shall not exceed the maximum amount permitted 
by the Internal Revenue Code. The definition of "earnings" as used in this plan shall, when employed 
using the benefit structure of this plan, exceed the minimums required under chapters 175 and 185. 
Effective October 1, 2003 earnings for active police officer members shall include up to three hundred 
(300) hours of overtime per year. 
    Effective date means the date on which this section and system become effective. 
    Employee means all employees of the city classified under civil service as full time sworn police 
officers, regular full time firefighters, or regular full time public safety officers, excluding volunteers, as 
defined on the effective date in F.S. 175.032(1)(b), and excluding all civilian members of the police and 
fire departments. All regular firefighters and paramedics employed by Broward County who were 
employed by the city on July 31, 1991, and became county employees pursuant to the agreement for fire 
and EMS services between the city and Broward County, and made an irrevocable election to remain as 
members of this system. "Employee" shall exclude all civilian members of the police and fire departments. 
For the purpose of this section, a "full time employee" shall mean a regular employee who is defined as 
such in the civil service rules and regulations of the city, and performs more than one thousand (1,000) 
hours of service in any plan year. For all purposes under this system, effective October 1, 1990, 
employee shall exclude public safety officers; however, all continuous service and benefits hereunder 
accrued by a member while acting as a public safety officer prior to such date shall not be reduced and 
shall be credited toward future continuous service and/or benefits accrued by such members thereafter 
either as a police officer or a firefighter. The definition of employee shall also include all former police 
officers of the city assigned as deputy sheriffs with Broward Sheriff's Office, pursuant to the police 
services contract between the city and the Broward Sheriff's Office and has elected to remain members of 
this system. 
    Employee pension plan means the pension plan for all employees of the city as in effect immediately 
prior to the effective date of this system. 
    Firefighter means a firefighter, as that term is defined in F.S. 175.032(1), employed by the city's fire 
department or a firefighter or paramedic employed by Broward County who was employed by the city on 
July 31, 1991, and became a county employee pursuant to the agreement for fire and EMS service 
between the county and the city. 
    Fiscal agent means any person or entity to serve as investment agent, or custodian of the fund of the 
retirement system. 
    Fund means the trust fund established herein as part of the system. 
    Interest means an amount determined at the rate of three (3) percent per annum compounded semi-
annually. Interest shall be credited to each member's contribution account semi-annually on a fiscal year 
basis, except as provided herein. Interest shall not be credited to the member contributions of firefighters 
hired on or after March 1, 2013 or firefighters who have completed less than ten (10) years of continuous
