service on March 1, 2013 and no interest shall be included in a refund of such members' contributions. 
    Medical board means the three (3) physicians who may be appointed as follows: one (1) by the 
board of trustees, one (1) by the city manager, and one (1) by the mayor with commission approval for 
the purpose of assisting the board in all matters referred to it regarding medical questions and/or 
disabilities. 
    Member means an employee who fulfills the prescribed participation requirements. 
    Police officer means a person who is certified pursuant to F.S. Chapter 943 as a condition of 
employment and whose primary duty is the prevention and detection of crime and the enforcement of the 
highway, safety, criminal, and penal laws of the State of Florida. This shall include command, supervisory 
and training officers but shall not include any part time, reserve, or auxiliary police officers. 
    Service connected death disability means death or disability of a member occurring as the direct 
result of performance of duty as a police officer, firefighter, or public safety officer of the city or of the 
county, as defined by any state law applicable to such personnel. Such performance of duty shall include 
the rendering of noncompensable services during off-duty hours which, by reason of custom or because 
of the person's training or experience as a police officer, firefighter or public safety office, as the case may 
be, he is specially qualified to render. Compensable off-duty services rendered within the corporate limits 
of the city, or for firefighters, within the county limits while in uniform, shall also qualify as performance of 
duty. Death or disability not occurring as the direct result of performance of duty as a police officer, 
firefighter, or public safety officer of the city or, for firefighters, the county, shall be considered a non-
service connected death or disability. 
    Spouse means the lawful wife or husband of a member. 
    System means the city police, firefighters and public safety officers retirement system as contained 
herein and all amendments thereto. Effective August 1, 1991, "system" shall mean the city police and 
firefighters retirement system. 
(Ord. No. O-75-15, § 1, 12-3-75; Ord. No. O-76-23, § 1, 9-15-76; Ord. No. O-83-23, § 1, 12-21-
83; Ord. No. O-95-10, § 1, 7-5-95; Ord. No. O-1999-015, § 1, 9-1-99; Ord. No. O-2000-011, § 1, 
6-21-00; Ord. No. O-2000-011, § 1, 6-21-00; Ord. No. O-2005-030, § 1, 9-21-05; Ord. No. O-
2013-004, § 1, 2-20-13) 


Sec. 9-62. - Membership. 
(a) ?Conditions of eligibility. 
(1) ?Existing employees. Employees, as defined herein, who are covered under the retirement 
program provided under chapters 175 and 185, Florida Statutes Annotated, as of the effective 
date, shall become members of this system. 
(2) ?New employees. All other employees, as defined herein, shall as a condition of employment, 
become a member upon such employment, provided that such employee falls within the 
definition of an employee set forth in this chapter. At the time of entry into the plan, members 
shall be subjected to a physical examination. Any pre-existing condition revealed by said 
examination shall not be considered as the source of a disability retirement except to the extent 
that any accident or injury suffered by an employee would have resulted in a disability as 
defined by this plan, notwithstanding the pre-existing condition. No employee shall be denied 
membership in the plan on the basis of a pre-existing physical condition. 
(b) ?Application . Each eligible employee shall complete an application form covering the following 
points, as well as such other points or items as may be prescribed by the board: 
(1) ?Such employee's acceptance of the terms and conditions of the retirement system, including 
the execution of a waiver of disability claim, in a form as prescribed by the board of trustees, 
relating to any pre-existing condition revealed at the time of entry into the plan. In the event that 
any employee should refuse to execute the acknowledgement of pre-existing condition form, the 
member shall still be permitted entry into the plan; provided, however, that in any future claim 
for disability benefits, there shall be a presumption that the condition giving rise to the claim for 
disability pre-existed entry into the plan; 
(2) ?Such employee's designation of a beneficiary or beneficiaries; and 
(3) ?Authorization of payroll deduction of member contributions to this system. 
(4) ?Authorization of the transfer to, and use by, this fund, of any funds previously allocated to the 
member under chapters 175 or 185, Florida Statutes Annotated. 
(c) ?Change in designation of beneficiary . A member may from time to time change his designated 
beneficiary by written notice to the board upon forms provided by the board. Upon such change, the 
rights of all previously designated beneficiaries to receive any benefit under the system shall cease. 
In any post-retirement change of a designated beneficiary, the replacement beneficiary shall not be 
entitled to receive an amount greater than the actuarial value of the benefit which would have been 
received by the beneficiary named at the time of retirement. A member may designate a choice of 
one (1) or more persons, named sequentially or jointly, as the member's beneficiary or beneficiaries. 
(d) ?Firefighters. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the city shall join the Florida 
Retirement System (FRS) for firefighters effective September 1, 2018, or as soon thereafter as 
administratively feasible, and this system shall be closed to new members on that date. Firefighters 
hired on or after the date the city joins FRS shall become compulsory members of the Florida 
Retirement System and shall not be eligible for membership in this system. Firefighters hired before 
the date the city joins FRS who are contributing members of this system on the date the city joins 
FRS may elect to participate in FRS or continue participating in this system, in accordance with 
section 9-63(j). 
(Ord. No. O-75-15, § 2, 12-3-75; Ord. No. O-95-10, § 1, 7-5-95; Ord. No. O-2000-011, § 2, 6-
21-00; Ord. No. O-2018-018 , § 2, 8-1-18) 


Sec. 9-63. - Benefit amounts and eligibility. 
(a) ?Normal retirement. 
(1) ?Normal retirement date . 
a. ?The normal retirement date for a member will be the first day of the month coincident with 
or next following completion of the earlier of: (i) the member's twentieth year of continuous 
service and the member's attainment of age of forty-two (42), (ii) the attainment of age fifty-
five (55) and the completion of ten years of continuous service, or (iii) the attainment of age 
fifty-eight (58), regardless of length of service. A member will be one hundred (100) 
percent vested upon the attainment of his normal retirement date regardless of any other 
provision of the system. 
b. ?Beginning October 31, 2000, an active member of the plan with fifteen (15) or more years 
of service credit who was hired as an employee with the City of Oakland Park, Florida, 
prior to January 1, 1975, shall receive an increase in the member's multiplier to permit the 
member to retire immediately with the same benefit as if the member had completed 
twenty-five (25) years of service with this plan. Any member, employed prior to January 1, 
1975, and electing this option, must make an election within one hundred twenty (120) 
days of the effective date of the ordinance adopting this subsection (a)(1)b. [Ord. No. O-
2001-011]. The member must submit an irrevocable letter of resignation as a part of the 
election of this benefit. A member receiving this benefit voluntarily waives any benefits 
payable from any other retirement plan of the city as well as any right to participate in any 
deferred retirement option plan (DROP) that may be offered by the city. 
c. ?Notwithstanding any other provision of the system, effective March 1, 2013, for firefighters 
hired on or after March 1, 2013 and firefighters who, on March 1, 2013, are not within 
seven (7) years of the normal retirement date provided in sec. 9-63 (a)(1)a., the normal 
retirement date will be the first day of the month coincident with or next following 
completion of the earlier of: (i) the attainment of age fifty-five (55) and the completion of ten 
years of continuous service, or (ii) the attainment of age fifty-two (52) and the completion of 
twenty-five (25) years of continuous service. The normal retirement date for firefighters 
who, on March 1, 2013, are within seven (7) years of the normal retirement date provided 
in section 9-63 (a)(1)a shall be as provided in sec. 9-63(a)(1)a. 
(2) ?Normal retirement benefit. 
a. ?Normal form of benefit. A member retiring hereunder on his normal retirement date shall 
receive his monthly normal retirement benefit commencing on his normal retirement date 
and continuing thereafter during his lifetime with a period certain of ten (10) years. 
b. ?Amount. 
1. ?The normal retirement benefit for firefighters who terminate city employment prior to 
the effective date of this ordinance, and police officers/deputy sheriffs shall be three 
(3) percent of the member's average monthly earnings for each year of continuous 
service, subject to a maximum benefit of seventy-five (75) percent of average monthly 
earnings. For the purposes of compliance with chapters 175 and 185, if such member 
completes more than thirty-seven and one-half (37½) years of service, accrual of 
benefits shall recommence at the rate of two (2) percent for each year of creditable 
service. 
2. ?For firefighters who are actively employed on or after the effective date of this 
ordinance, the amount of benefit payable at normal retirement date shall be three (3) 
percent of the member's average monthly earnings for the first ten (10) years of 
continuous service, four (4) percent of average monthly earnings for the next ten (10) 
years of service, and three (3) percent of average monthly earnings thereafter; subject 
to a maximum benefit of eighty-five (85) percent of average monthly earnings. For the 
purposes of compliance with Chapter 175, if such a firefighter completes more than 
forty-two and one half (42½) years of service, accrual of benefits shall recommence at 
the rate of two (2) percent for each year of creditable service. 
3. ?Notwithstanding any other provision of the system, effective March 1, 2013, for 
firefighters who are hired on or after March 1, 2013 and firefighters who, on March 1, 
2013, are not within seven (7) years of the normal retirement date provided in 
subsection 9-63 (a)(1)a., the amount of benefit payable at normal retirement shall be 
the member's accrued benefit as of March 1, 2013 and two and one-quarter (2.25) 
percent of the member's average monthly earnings for each year of continuous 
service after March 1, 2013, subject to a maximum benefit of seventy (70) percent of 
average monthly earnings. For firefighters who, on March 1, 2013, are within seven 
(7) years of the normal retirement date provided in subsection 9-63 (a)(1)a, the 
amount of benefit payable at normal retirement shall be as provided in subsection 9-
63 (a)(2)b.2, subject to a maximum benefit of eighty-five (85) percent of average final 
compensation. Provided, in no event shall the benefit of any member employed prior 
to March 1, 2013 be less than the member's accrued benefit percentage as of March 
1, 2013, and in no event shall the normal retirement benefit of any member be less 
than two (2) percent of the member's average monthly earnings for all years of 
continuous service. 
c. ?Cost-of-living adjustment created. A cost-of-living benefit is hereby created to be provided 
in the form of a thirteenth monthly retirement payment to each beneficiary and retiree of the 
plan. Payment shall only be made in those years in which an actuarial gain has been 
determined to exist by the board of trustees, following consultation with the actuary to the 
board. 
d. ?Determination of actuarial gains. The actuary for the retirement fund shall perform an 
annual calculation to determine on the basis of all actuarial factors used to measure the 
plan whether or not the plan has sustained an actuarial gain or loss. In any year in which 
the board of trustees, following consultation with the actuary, determines that no actuarial 
gain has occurred, no benefit shall be payable notwithstanding the availability of 
unexpended funds from a prior year. 
e. ?Creation of a cost-of-living adjustment (COLA) fund. Following the determination of 
actuarial gain, a fund is hereby created, within the assets of the retirement system, which 
shall consist of one-half (½) of the value of the actuarial gain. The remaining actuarial gain 
shall be used to reduce future costs of the retirement system. The COLA fund shall be co-
mingled with other assets of the system but shall be measured for accounting purposes as 
a separate fund within the retirement system for the exclusive purpose of providing benefits 
under this section. No benefit may be paid from the COLA fund which exceeds the amount 
of annual income received by the fund. Notwithstanding the availability of funds, no benefit 
shall be paid from the fund in excess of the formula established in this subsection. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of the system, no actuarial gain or portion thereof shall 
be allocated to the COLA fund on or after March 1, 2013. 
f. ?Distribution of benefits; limitations. In any year in which the board determines that a 
distribution may be made in accordance with the provisions of this section, a cost-of-living 
benefit shall be paid in the form of a thirteenth monthly pension payment to each retiree or 
beneficiary. The payment shall be equal to three (3) percent of the annual retirement 
benefit multiplied by the number of years that the employee has been retired up to a 
maximum benefit equal to fifteen (15) percent of the member's annual pension payment. In 
the event that the available funds are less than the projected liability under the formula 
established in this section, the board of trustees may, in its exclusive discretion, decline to 
make any COLA payment for that year or make a lesser COLA payment based on a pro 
rata distribution of available funds. Notwithstanding any other provision of the system, 
firefighters hired on or after March 1, 2013 and firefighters who, on March 1, 2013 are not 
within seven (7) years of the normal retirement date provided in subsection 9-63 (a)(1)a, 
shall not be eligible for the COLA benefit under this section. 
g. ?Nonguarantee of benefits. By acceptance of any cost-of-living benefit under this section, 
each retiree and beneficiary acknowledges that they have no right, title or interest in any 
such benefits except as may be determined by the board of trustees. The payment of a 
cost-of-living benefit in any year shall not create any right, title or interest in any person to 
the payment of a cost-of-living benefit in any other year. The board of trustees reserves the 
exclusive right to alter the manner of payment of the cost-of-living benefit or to decline the 
payment of such benefit in any year in which the board, in the exercise of its fiduciary 
responsibility and its sole discretion, determines it is in the best interest of the plan to 
forego such payment. 
h. ?Rule-making authority. The board of trustees shall have authority to make such uniform 
rules as it deems appropriate to facilitate the payment of benefits under this section. 
(3) ?Delayed payment. A member retiring on his normal retirement date may request, by submitting 
his written application to the board, that the commencement of his monthly normal retirement 
benefit payments be delayed until a date which is the first day of any future month, but no later 
than April 1 of the calendar year following the member's attainment of age seventy and one-half 
(70½) at which time benefit payments shall commence in accordance with the provisions of 
Internal Revenue Code section 401(a)(9) and the regulations thereunder. If the commencement 
of payment of a member's monthly normal retirement benefit is delayed to a designated future 
date as provided under subsection (b) of this section, the monthly benefit payable at such future 
date shall be the amount of the member's monthly normal retirement benefit actuarially adjusted 
to reflect the member's age as of such designated date. Such adjusted monthly normal 
retirement benefit shall be payable to the member commencing as of the designated date. 
(b) ?Deferred retirement. 
(1) ?Approval and conditions for deferred retirement. A member who is eligible for normal retirement 
may elect to continue his employment with the city beyond his normal retirement date by 
submitting his written election to the board. 
(2) ?Deferred retirement benefit. The amount of monthly deferred retirement benefit payable to a 
member as of his deferred retirement date will be calculated the same as his normal retirement 
benefit as described under section 9-63(a)(2) of the system except the member's average 
monthly earnings and continuous service will be determined as of the member's deferred 
retirement date. 
(c) ?Early retirement benefits. 
(1) ?Early retirement date . 
a. ?A firefighter who, on March 1, 2013 is within seven (7) years of the normal retirement date 
provided in subsection 9-63 (a)(1)a, and any police officer/deputy sheriff may retire on the 
first day of any month following the earlier of the member's fiftieth (50th) birthday and the 
completion of ten (10) years of continuous service or twenty (20) years of continuous 
service. Effective March 1, 2013, a firefighter who is hired on or after March 1, 2013 and a 
firefighter who, on March 1, 2013 is not within seven (7) years of the normal retirement 
date provided in 9-63 (a)(1)a may retire on the first day of any month following the earlier of 
the member's fiftieth (50th) birthday and the completion of ten (10) years of continuous 
service. 
(2) ?Early retirement benefit . A member retiring hereunder on his early retirement date shall 
receive either a deferred or an immediate monthly retirement benefit as follows: 
a. ?Deferred early retirement benefit. A deferred monthly retirement benefit which shall 
commence on his normal retirement date and shall be continued on the first day of each 
month thereafter during his lifetime with a period certain of ten (10) years. The amount of 
such deferred monthly early retirement benefit shall be determined in the same manner as 
for retirement at his normal retirement date, except that continuous service and average 
monthly earnings shall be determined as of his early retirement date; or, 
b. ?Immediate early retirement benefit. An immediate monthly retirement benefit, which shall 
commence on his early retirement date and shall continue on the first day of each month 
thereafter during his lifetime with a period certain of ten (10) years. The immediate early 
retirement benefit payable shall be as determined in subsection a., above, but reduced by 
three (3) percent for each year that benefit commencement precedes the member's 
applicable normal retirement date. 
(d) ?Disability benefits. 
(1) ?Service-connected disability. 
a. ?Amount. Any firefighter who, on March 1, 2013 is within seven (7) years of the normal 
retirement date provided in subsection 9-63 (a)(1)a, or any police officer/deputy sheriff who 
incurs a service-connected injury, disease or disability, which injury, disease or disability 
permanently incapacitates him, physically or mentally, from regular and continuous duty 
within his department ("disability"), shall receive in equal monthly installments disability 
benefits in an amount equal to the greater of benefits payable under any other provision of 
this system to which the member may then be entitled, fifty (50) percent of the member's 
average monthly earnings in effect at the date of disability, or the accrued benefit at the 
date of disability (payable as a ten-year certain and life benefit), or forty-two (42) percent of 
average monthly earnings (payable as a ten-year certain and life benefit) on the date of 
disability. It is the intent of this provision that a service-connected disability benefit be tax 
exempt under the provisions of section 104 of the Internal Revenue Code. Any firefighter 
member who, on March 1, 2013 is not within seven (7) years of the normal retirement date 
provided in 9-63 (a)(1)a, and any firefighter hired on or after that date, who incurs a 
service-connected injury, disease or disability, which injury, disease or disability 
permanently incapacitates him, physically or mentally, from regular and continuous duty 
within his department ("disability"), shall receive disability benefits in accordance with the 
provisions of section 175.191, Florida Statutes. 
b. ?Normal form of disability benefit. Unless a member elects otherwise, the normal form of 
disability benefit payable hereunder shall be an annuity payable for life with ten (10) years 
certain which shall be actuarially equivalent to an annuity payable for life based upon the 
foregoing percentages of average monthly earnings. A member may designate a 
beneficiary for any disability benefits which are payable subsequent to his death, if any. If 
none shall have been designated, such payments shall be made to his surviving spouse, if 
any; if none, then to his surviving children in equal shares; if none, then to his estate. 
(2) ?Non-service-connected disability. 
a. ?Ten (10) or more years of continuous service. Any firefighter member who, on March 1, 
2013 is not within seven (7) years of the normal retirement date provided in subsection 9-
63 (a)(1)a, has completed at least ten (10) years of continuous service and receives a non-
service-connected injury, disease or disability, which permanently incapacitates him 
physically or mentally from employment within his department, shall receive disability 
benefits in accordance with the provisions of F.S. § 175.191. Any firefighter member who, 
on March 1, 2013 is within seven (7) years of the normal retirement date provided in 
subsection 9-63 (a)(1)a, or any police officer/deputy sheriff member, who has completed at 
least ten (10) years of continuous service and receives a non-service-connected injury, 
disease or disability, which permanently incapacitates him physically or mentally from 
employment with the police or fire department, shall receive the greater of: 
1. ?Benefits payable under any other provision of the system to which the member may 
then be entitled; 
2. ?Equal monthly installments in an amount equal to twenty-five (25) percent of his 
average monthly earnings as in effect at the date of disability; or 
3. ?The accrued benefit payable on the date of disability. 
b. ?Less than ten (10) years of continuous service. Any member who has completed less than 
ten (10) years of continuous service and terminates employment due to a non-service-
connected disability shall only be entitled to termination benefits available under subsection 
9-63(f) of this system. 
(3) ?Determination of disability. All issues and determinations relating to eligibility for initial payment 
or continuance of disability benefits shall be determined by the board, taking into consideration 
the recommendations of the medical board, and based upon the methods and procedures 
established by the board. The determination by the board shall be conclusive as to all issues 
pertaining to disability. All such determinations will be applied uniformly and consistently to all 
members in similar circumstances. 
(4) ?Reduction for other disability benefits. The benefit provided in this section may not be offset by 
Social Security, worker's compensation, city-provided disability insurance as permitted by law. 
(5) ?Benefits payable at and after normal retirement date. 
a. ?Service-connected disability. A member who had previously become disabled due to a 
service-connected disability and who has reached his normal retirement date shall be 
entitled to receive a benefit which is the same as his monthly normal retirement benefit 
determined as of his normal retirement date, but based on the member's earnings as of his 
date of disability and his continuous service which shall include service for the period of his 
disability. 
b. ?Non-service-connected disability. A member who had become disabled due to a non-
service-connected disability and who has reached his normal retirement date shall 
continue to receive the same non-service-connected disability benefit which he was 
receiving prior to his normal retirement date, payable during his remaining lifetime. 
(6) ?Credited service while disabled. A disabled member's period of service-connected disability 
shall be credited to him as continuous service upon his recovery provided he immediately 
returns thereafter as an actively employed employee. 
(7) ?No duplication of benefits. Except to the extent that an employee will receive service credit for 
time spent on disability, if the employee resumes active service prior to normal retirement age, 
as expressly provided in this subsection 9-63(d), there shall be no duplication of benefits upon 
the subsequent death of a member after disability benefits commence. Disability benefits shall 
be payable until the earliest of the member's death, recovery from disability or normal retirement 
date. 
(e) ?Preretirement death benefits. 
(1) ?Service-connected death. A death benefit shall be payable commencing in the month following 
death on behalf of any member who, prior to the commencement of termination, disability or 
early, normal or deferred retirement benefit payments under this system, dies as a direct result 
of service-connected death. Except as provided in subsection (e)(3) of this section 9-63, such 
death benefit shall be payable as follows but for a member with ten or more years of service, it 
shall not be less than the amount of the member's accrued benefit payable for ten years certain 
and life at the member's normal retirement date or reduced for early payment: 
a. ?If spouse. If there shall be a surviving spouse at the time of the member's death, there shall 
be paid to such spouse until said spouse's death, a death benefit payable in equal monthly 
installments, in an amount equal to fifty (50) percent of the member's average monthly 
earnings as in effect as of the date of the member's death with ten (10) years certain; or 
b. ?No spouse. If there shall be no surviving spouse at the time of the member's death, there 
shall be paid a death benefit payable in equal monthly installments, an amount equal to 
twenty (20) percent of the member's average monthly earnings for each unmarried child of 
such member until such child shall have reached the age of eighteen (18) years, and a 
same amount for each unmarried child from age eighteen (18) until age twenty-two (22) 
who is a full time student in a fully accredited high school, college or university. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the total death benefit payable pursuant to this subsection 
shall be subject to an overall family limitation of fifty (50) percent of such member's 
average monthly earnings as in effect as of the date of such member's death for all such 
children combined. In that event, each such child's portion of the death benefit shall be 
determined on a pro rata basis. The nonstudent child's portion of the death benefit shall 
terminate on the earlier of such child's death, marriage or the attainment of age eighteen 
(18); the benefit of a child who is a student shall terminate on the earlier of death, marriage 
or the attainment of age twenty-two (22). Legally adopted children shall be treated as 
natural children. 
(2) ?Non-service-connected death. A death benefit shall be payable commencing in the month 
following death on behalf of any member who, prior to the commencement of termination, 
disability or early, normal or deferred retirement benefit payments under this system, dies other 
than as a direct result of a service-connected death. Except as provided in subsection (e)(3) of 
this sec. 9-63, such death benefits shall be payable as follows, but shall not be less than the 
amount of a vested member's accrued benefit payable, or for a member with ten or more years 
of service it shall not be less than the amount of the member's accrued benefit payable for ten 
years certain and life at the member's normal retirement date or reduced for early payment: 
a. ?If spouse. If there shall be a surviving spouse at the time of the member's death, there shall 
be paid to such spouse until said spouse's death, a death benefit payable in equal monthly 
installments, in an amount equal to twenty-five (25) percent of the member's average 
monthly earnings as in effect as of the date of the member's death with ten (10) years 
certain; or 
b. ?No spouse. If there shall be no surviving spouse at the time of the member's death, there 
shall be paid a death benefit payable in equal monthly installments, an amount equal to ten 
(10) percent of the member's average monthly earnings for each unmarried child of such 
member until such child shall have reached the age of eighteen (18) years, and a same 
amount for each unmarried child from age eighteen (18) until age twenty-two (22) who is a 
full time student in a fully accredited high school, college or university. Notwithstanding the 
foregoing, the total death benefit payable pursuant to this subsection shall be subject to an 
overall family limitation of twenty-five (25) percent of such member's average monthly 
earnings as in effect as of the date of such member's death for all such children combined. 
In that event, each such child's portion of the death benefit shall be determined on a pro 
rata basis. The nonstudent child's portion of the death benefit shall terminate on the earlier 
of such child's death, marriage or the attainment of age eighteen (18); the benefit of a child 
who is a student shall terminate on the earlier of death, marriage or the attainment of age 
twenty-two (22). Legally adopted children shall be treated as natural children. 
(3) ?Notwithstanding any other provision of the system, effective March 1, 2013, if any firefighter 
who, as of March 1, 2013 was not within seven (7) years of the normal retirement date provided 
in subsection 9-63 (a)(1)a, and any firefighter hired on or after that date, dies prior to retirement 
but after completing ten (10) years of continuous service, his or her beneficiary shall only be 
entitled to the benefits otherwise payable to the firefighter at early or normal retirement age. 
(4) ?No optional form of benefits available. Payment of pre-retirement death benefits hereunder 
shall be in lieu of any other form of benefit payment otherwise available pursuant to the system; 
no optional benefit shall be available for any pre-retirement death benefit. 
(f) ?Termination benefits and vesting. If a member ceases to be an employee as defined in this chapter, 
the member shall be entitled to receive the following termination benefits: 
(1) ?With less than five (5) years of continuous service: A refund of member's contributions plus 
interest (as defined in section 9-61 of this system) payable at such time as the member so 
elects. No optional form of benefit shall be available hereunder. Such refund shall be made as 
soon as reasonably possible subsequent to termination of employment. 
(2) ?With five (5) years or more of continuous service: 
a. ?If no member contributions are withdrawn. The benefit accrued under this system to such 
member's date of termination, payable commencing at what would otherwise be his normal 
retirement date, and in the form of a life annuity or other actuarially equivalent optional 
benefit commencing at his normal or early retirement date, respectively, but based upon 
the following vesting schedules: 
1. ?Police officers/deputy sheriffs 
Year of Continuous Service 
Vested Percentage 
5 but less than 10 
25% 
10 or more 
100% 
 
2. ?Firefighters . Effective March 1, 2013, firefighters shall become 100 percent vested in 
their accrued benefit upon attaining ten (10) years of continuous service; provided that 
firefighters hired prior to March 1, 2013 with at least five (5) years of continuous 
service on March 1, 2013, shall retain their vested status as of that date. Any 
firefighter partially vested prior to March 1, 2013, must complete ten (10) years of 
continuous service to become 100% vested in their accrued benefit. There shall be no 
partial vesting for any firefighter hired on or after March 1, 2013 or any firefighter with 
less than five (5) years of continuous service on that date. 
3. ?Payment of benefits. The payment of any benefits to a firefighter or police officer prior 
to attainment of what would have been his normal retirement age shall be reduced by 
the early retirement factors in subsection 9-63(c)(2)b. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if 
a member shall die after termination of employment but prior to the commencement of 
benefits at normal or early retirement age, respectively, the member's designated 
beneficiary shall receive a refund of the member's contributions plus interest (as 
defined in section 9-61 of this system) payable at such time as the beneficiary so 
elects on a form prescribed by the board. In the absence of a written notification of 
beneficiary, the member's estate shall be considered the designated beneficiary. The 
refund shall be made as soon as reasonably possible subsequent to the receipt of a 
request for benefits. Notwithstanding any other provision of this plan, if a member has 
reached the maximum accrued benefit under the plan, the member shall be deemed 
one hundred (100) percent vested regardless of the number of years of service and 
membership in the plan shall cease. If a member remains employed, after plan 
membership has ceased and becomes disabled in the line of duty, the member shall 
be entitled to the disability benefits provided for in this plan or the accrued benefit, 
whichever shall be greater. Notwithstanding any other provision of this plan, if on July 
5, 1995, any member has accrued benefits in excess of seventy-five (75) percent, the 
member shall be deemed one hundred (100) percent vested in the benefits accrued 
based on the formula in effect at the time of accrual of the benefits. In the case of 
such an event, membership in the plan shall cease and no further benefits may be 
accrued. If the member remains employed by the city and becomes disabled in the 
line of duty, the member shall be eligible for the disability benefits provided for under 
this plan, or the accrued benefit, whichever shall be greater. 
b. ?If member contributions are withdrawn. A refund of such member's contributions plus 
interest (as defined in section 9-61 of this system) payable at such time as the member so 
elects. No optional form of benefit shall be available hereunder. Such refund shall be made 
as soon as reasonably possible subsequent to termination of employment. A refund of 
contributions of a firefighter hired on or after March 1, 2013, or a firefighter with less than 
ten (10) years of continuous service as of March 1, 2013, shall not include interest. 
(3) ?Transfer of certain members. Any member of this system who ceases to be an employee as 
defined in this chapter but who remains with the city or county in some other capacity or who, 
prior to membership in this system had city or county service resulting in an aggregate total of 
five (5) or more years of continuous employment with the city or county shall have all benefits 
accrued under this system preserved, provided the member does not withdraw the accumulated 
employee contributions. Any accrued benefit shall be payable at the normal retirement date set 
forth in this system. No benefit shall be payable under the system, however, during any period 
of continued employment with the city or county in any capacity, unless the employee has 
retired from the system or transferred to the Florida Retirement System (FRS). 
(g) ?Return of member contributions. The present value of any benefit provided by this section, whether 
or not service-connected, shall, except as provided herein, be at least equal to the amount of the 
member's individual contributions to the system plus interest (as defined in section 9-61 of this 
system). The payment of any other form of benefit pursuant to this section shall be in lieu of a refund 
of the said member's contributions under this subsection. Effective March 1, 2013, the present value 
of the benefit of a firefighter hired on or after March 1, 2013, or a firefighter with less than ten (10) 
years of continuous service on March 1, 2013 shall be at least equal to the member's individual 
contributions to the system without interest. 
(h) ?Overall limitations on amount of benefits. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, and in addition 
to any other limitations set forth in the system, a member's benefit under this system, including the 
right to any optional benefit provided by the system, shall not exceed one hundred (100) percent of 
the amount of such member's "compensation" as defined in Internal Revenue Code section 415 
(1986), and Treasury Regulation 1.415-2(d) which are hereby specifically incorporated by reference 
as part of the system. 
(i) ?Early retirement incentive. 
(1) ?Notwithstanding any provision in this article to the contrary, an early retirement incentive is 
hereby created for eligible members as defined in this subsection. 
(2) ?Eligible members for participation in the early retirement incentive shall have completed twenty 
(20) years of service and shall have attained age forty-seven (47) as of December 31, 1995. 
(3) ?Each year purchased, service and/or age, shall be at the rate of eight and one-half (8½) 
percent of the member's base and longevity pay. When a member requires a combination of 
years of age and years of service, the amount purchased shall be the greater of service or age 
required to meet maximum retirement requirements. In effect, a year of service and a year of 
age shall be counted as one (1) year as calculated currently in subsection 9-65(a). The payment 
to the city shall be eight and one-half (8½) percent of member's base and longevity pay per 
year, multiplied by the total number of years purchased. Payment shall be made to the city prior 
to retirement. 
a. ?Notwithstanding the above provision, nothing in this section shall allow a member to 
increase his or her retirement benefits above the following: 
1. ?Age fifty-three (53): Normal retirement age without any penalty or actuarial reduction. 
2. ?Maximum pension benefit or seventy-five (75) percent unless eligible for a higher 
percentage as provided in subsection (f)(2), above. 
(4) ?Members retiring under this subsection (i) shall not be subject to any early retirement penalty or 
actuarial reduction but shall be treated as normal retirement. 
(5) ?Members that meet the minimum eligibility requirements of this subsection (i) shall submit a 
written request (on a form provided by the city) to apply for purchase of years of service or age 
or both under subsection (i)(3), above. Each member satisfying the minimum eligibility 
requirements shall submit the written request to the city clerk within sixteen (16) calendar days 
from the date of final adoption of this subsection (i) by the city commission. The failure to submit 
the proper written request to the city clerk by 5:00 p.m. on the sixteenth day subsequent to the 
final adoption of this subsection (i) (March 20, 1996) shall forever preclude the applicant from 
applying for early retirement incentive under this subsection. 
(6) ?The city manager, police chief, fire chief and the pension board administrator shall: 
a. ?Review all requests received by the city clerk on a timely basis and in proper form for 
purposes of ensuring that all eligibility requirements have been satisfied. All requests 
determined not to satisfy the requirements of this subsection (i) shall be rejected and the 
member/employee shall not be eligible for early retirement incentive. 
b. ?Develop and publish a tentative schedule of retirements based on the number of 
applications and based on the staffing needs of the police and fire departments. 
c. ?Post the tentative schedule and meet individually and/or collectively with the applicants for 
discussion and input. 
d. ?Revise tentative retirement schedule based on the police department, fire department and 
applicant's needs. The city manager, in his sole and exclusive discretion, shall make the 
final retirement schedule. In no instance will the retirement schedule extend more than six 
(6) months from the date of the final adoption of this subsection (i) (March 20, 1996). 
e. ?Publish the final schedule and officially notify the pension board for their action and 
administrative processing. 
(7) ?Effective upon March 20, 1996, and for the period of sixteen (16) days thereafter (the 
retirement election window), a participant with at least twenty (20) years of service as of 
December 31, 1995, and who meets all other eligibility requirements, may elect to retire during 
the early retirement election window and shall accrue benefits, not to exceed the maximum 
allowed under this system, according to the uniform formula established. The uniform formula 
for determining final benefit shall be the number of years of service worked multiplied by an 
accrual benefit factor. The accrual benefit factor shall be defined as a maximum benefit level 
divided by actual years or part thereof of credited service. For purposes of this section, 
maximum benefit level is defined in subsection (a)(2)b., above, as seventy-five (75) percent of 
average monthly earnings. In the case of William Gagliardo, the maximum benefit level shall be 
defined as eighty-two and one-quarter (82¼) percent of average monthly earnings. In the case 
of William Schiffman Jr., the maximum benefit level shall be defined as seventy-nine and one-
half (79½) percent of average monthly earnings. No member participating in the retirement 
election window shall receive a benefit less than the minimum as prescribed by F.S. 175.351 
and F.S. 185.35. 
(j) ?Participation in the Florida Retirement System. Effective September 1, 2018, or as soon thereafter as 
administratively feasible, the city shall join the Florida Retirement System (FRS) for firefighters, and 
this system shall be closed to new members. Firefighters hired on or after the date the city joins FRS 
shall become compulsory members of the Florida Retirement System and shall not be eligible for 
membership in this system. Firefighters hired before the date the city joins FRS who are contributing 
members of this system on the date the city joins FRS may elect to participate in FRS or continue 
participating in this system, in accordance with FRS statutes and rules. The member contributions 
and accrued benefits of contributing firefighter members who are employed on the date the city joins 
FRS and elect to join the Florida Retirement System shall be handled as follows: 
(1) ?Members with less than five (5) years of credited service in this system on the date the city 
joins FRS shall receive a refund of their member contributions without interest, or the value of 
their accrued benefit if greater, and shall not receive any other benefits from this system. Such 
members may roll over the refund of member contributions to purchase service credit under the 
Florida Retirement System in accordance with FRS statutes and rules. 
(2) ?Members with five (5) or more years of credited service in this system on the date the city joins 
FRS may elect to receive a refund of their member contributions without interest, or the value of 
their accrued benefit if greater, and following such election shall not receive any other benefits 
from this system. Such members may roll over the refund of member contributions to purchase 
service credit under the Florida Retirement System in accordance with FRS statutes and rules. 
Alternatively, such members may elect to keep their contributions in this system and receive 
their vested accrued benefit upon termination of employment on or after the early or normal 
retirement date. The benefit payable from this system shall be based on the member's credited 
service and average final compensation at the time the member joins FRS. 
(3) ?Notwithstanding any other provision of this system, firefighter members who were employed 
but not within seven (7) years of the normal retirement date on March 1, 2013 and elect to join 
FRS on the date the city joins FRS: 
a. ?Shall receive a 3.0 percent benefit multiplier for each year of credited service from March 1, 
2013 through the day before the date the city joins FRS. 
b. ?Shall be eligible to participate in the deferred retirement option plan (DROP) in accordance 
with section 9-70, except as otherwise provided in this paragraph, upon reaching age fifty-
five (55) with ten (10) or more years of credited service, or age fifty-two (52) with twenty-
frive (25) or more years of credited service. Such members who enter the DROP shall 
receive a monthly payment into their DROP account equal to their monthly pension benefit 
based on average monthly earnings and years of credited service on the date they join 
FRS. The maximum DROP participation period for such members shall be eight (8) years 
or until the member attains age sixty (60), whichever occurs first. 
c. ?Alternatively, such members who do not participate in the DROP shall be eligible to receive 
an in-service distribution upon reaching age fifty-five (55) with ten (10) or more years of 
credited service, or age fifty-two (52) with twenty-five (25) or more years of credited 
service, and retirement from the system and separation from city employment. The in-
service distribution shall be equal to the monthly pension benefit based on average 
monthly earnings and years of credited service on the date the member joins FRS. For the 
purpose of this paragraph, "separation from city employment" means a termination of all 
city employment for a period of one business day. The in-service distribution provided in 
this paragraph shall be payable for a maximum of eight (8) years or until the member 
attains age sixty (60), whichever occurs first. 
d. ?Members who retire from the system and are subsequently reemployed in accordance with 
paragraph c. above shall upon reemployment be compulsory members of the Florida 
Retirement System.

Sec. 9-64. - Optional forms of benefits. 
(a) ?General rule. A member entitled to an early, normal or deferred retirement shall have the right to 
elect to have benefits payable under the optional benefits set forth in this section. The option chosen 
may be changed by the member until the issuance of the first retirement check. Thereafter, the 
election of an option is irrevocable. The present value of a member's option shall be the actuarial 
equivalent of all other options available to that member. A member shall make an election of option 
by written request to the board made at least thirty (30) days prior to the commencement of benefits. 
The request shall be retained in the board's files. 
(b) ?Optional forms of benefits. The normal form of retirement is the ten (10) years certain and life 
thereafter. In addition, the following optional forms are available: 
(1) ?Joint and last survivor option . A disabled or retiring member may elect to receive a decreased 
retirement monthly benefit during his lifetime and have such decreased monthly benefit (or a 
designated fraction thereof) continued after his death to and during the lifetime of the spouse or 
other designated beneficiary, so long as the present value of the monthly payments to the 
spouse and beneficiaries shall not exceed fifty (50) percent of the value of the monthly 
payments to the member and his spouse and/or beneficiary. The election of this optional benefit 
shall automatically become null and void if the spouse or other designated beneficiary dies 
before the member's actual commencement of the member's joint and last survivor benefit 
hereunder. 
(2) ?Life annuity option. Prior to commencement of benefits hereunder, a member may elect to 
receive a monthly benefit with monthly payments payable for his lifetime only. No further 
benefits shall be payable to such member's spouse or beneficiary subsequent to such 
member's death pursuant to this option. The election of this optional benefit shall automatically 
become null and void if the member dies before the member's actual commencement of the 
member's life annuity benefit hereunder. 
(Ord. No. O-75-15, § 4, 12-3-75; Ord. No. O-95-10, § 1, 7-5-95) 


Sec. 9-65. - Contributions to the trust fund. 
(a) ?Member contributions. The member contribution for firefighters who terminate city employment prior 
to the effective date of this ordinance, and police officers/deputy sheriffs, shall be eight and one-half 
(8½) percent of basic wages and longevity. Upon the effective date of this ordinance, the member 
contribution rate for firefighters shall be ten (10) percent of basic wages and longevity. The city shall 
pick up rather than deduct member contributions. Any contributions so picked up shall be considered 
as employer contributions pursuant to section 414(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code. Any amount 
so picked up shall be considered as employee contributions for the purposes of state law. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of the system, effective March 1, 2013, the member 
contributions for firefighters who are hired on or after March 1, 2013 and firefighters who, on March 
1, 2013, are not within 7 years of the normal retirement date provided in sec. 9-63 (a)(1)a, shall be 
eight percent (8%) of basic wages and longevity. The member contributions for firefighters who, on 
March 1, 2013 are within seven (7) years of the normal retirement date provided in section 9-63 
(a)(1)a shall be ten percent (10%) of basic wages and longevity. 
(b) ?State, county and city contributions. 
(1) ?State contributions. Any monies previously received or receivable by reason of laws of the 
State of Florida, for the express purpose of funding and paying for retirement benefits for police 
officers and firefighters of the city shall, no more than five (5) days after receipt, be deposited in 
the fund comprising part of this system, and no benefits shall be payable as arising from such 
funds except as provided in this article. All premium tax revenues received pursuant to F.S. ch. 
175, shall be used to reduce the city's required contributions to the system. 
(2) ?County contributions. The county shall contribute to this system, in accordance with the city 
county fire service agreement as defined in this chapter, on behalf of those county employees 
who are members of this system, the same amount it would have contributed to the Florida 
Retirement System had said employees not elected to remain as active members of this 
system, which amount shall be promptly deposited into this system. A portion of the county 
contribution shall be regarded as a member contribution, as provided in subsection (a), above. 
(3) ?City contributions. Subject to the provisions of subsection (a), above, the city shall make 
quarterly contributions to the trust fund in the amount that would soundly fund the system. 
(c) ?Miscellaneous provisions . All monies which have been funded by the member's, county's and city's 
contributions, and monies from all outside sources such as private contributions or those 
contributions made by the State of Florida or any other firms or corporations or companies, invested 
into any basic or secondary pension plan, including the system fund, for the retirement of any 
employee who shall be included in this system, including any interest gathered by these monies, 
shall be transferred into this fund to be known as "the Oakland Park Police and Firefighters 
Retirement Fund." 
(d) ?Forfeitures . To the extent that it is not required for the funding of any vested or retirement benefits, 
monies remaining in the fund which had previously been contributed in order to fund such benefits 
for terminated members shall serve only to reduce current and future contributions under this 
system. 
(Ord. No. O-75-15, § 5, 12-3-75; Ord. No. O-76-23, § 1, 9-15-76; Ord. No. O-82-14, § 3, 7-7-82; 
Ord. No. O-83-23, § 3, 12-21-83; Ord. No. O-86-16, § 2, 5-21-86; Ord. No. O-95-10, § 1, 7-5-
95; Ord. No. O-2000-011, § 3, 6-21-00; Ord. No. O-2007-019, § 2, 6-20-07; Ord. No. O-2013-
004, § 3, 2-20-13; Ord. No. O-2018-018 , § 4, 8-1-18) 


Sec. 9-66. - Administration of fund. 
(a) ?Board of trustees. The administration and responsibility for the proper operation of the retirement 
system and for making effective the provisions of this article are hereby vested in a board of trustees 
consisting of five (5) members (effective August 1, 1991) as follows: 
(1) ?Two (2) public members (excluding employees) to be appointed by the city commission, none 
of whom may be a city commission member, as hereinafter provided; 
(2) ?Two (2) members who shall be elected from the police department and the fire department, 
who shall be members of the system. Broward County firefighters who are members of the 
system shall be treated as members of the fire department for the purposes of voter eligibility 
and eligibility to serve as a trustee. 
(3) ?The fifth member to be selected by the above four (4) members and approved by a majority 
vote of all four (4) other board members. 
(b) ?Trustee's terms. City-appointed trustees shall serve at the pleasure of the city commission but shall 
be subject to reappointment every two (2) years. Employee-elected trustees shall serve a term of two 
(2) years. The fifth member of the board shall serve a term of two (2) years. A trustee shall hold 
office until a successor is appointed or elected. 
(c) ?Election procedure. The election of the police and firefighter and member trustees shall be by 
majority vote of all active members of each of said respective departments, who come within the 
purview of this article under procedures, and at meetings to be held as designated by the city 
manager of which meetings all qualified members entitled to vote shall be notified in person or by 
mail ten (10) days in advance of said meeting. Members employed by the county shall vote by mail 
ballots under procedures designated by the city manager. The candidate receiving the highest 
number of votes for each office shall be declared elected and shall take office immediately upon 
commencement of the term of office for which elected or as soon thereafter as he shall qualify 
therefor. An election shall be held not more than thirty (30) days and not less than ten (10) days prior 
to the commencement of the terms for which trustees are to be elected. The board shall meet, 
organize, and by majority vote elect one (1) of their members as chairman, one (1) member as vice-
chairman, and one (1) member as secretary each year, within ten (10) days after trustees are 
elected and duly qualified. 
Effective October 1, 2002 the active police officer seat may be held by either an active deputy sheriff who 
is a member of the plan or a retired police officer or deputy sheriff who shall be elected by the active 
deputy sheriffs who are members of the plan. Whenever the active membership of deputy sheriffs shall 
fall below ten (10), the active police officer seat may be held by either an active deputy sheriff or a retired 
police officer or deputy sheriff who is a member of the plan and who shall be elected by the retirees and 
active deputy sheriff membership of the plan. If there are no active or retired members remaining in the 
plan or capable of serving, the remaining board members may elect an individual to serve in the active 
member seat. 
(d) ?Vacancies. If a vacancy occurs in the office of trustee, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired 
term in the same manner as the office was previously filled. 
(e) ?No compensation. The trustees shall serve without compensation, but they may be reimbursed from 
the fund for all necessary expenses which they may actually expend through service on the board. 
(f) ?Duties and oath. Each trustee shall, within ten (10) days after his appointment or election, take an 
oath of office before the city clerk of the city that so far as it develops upon him, he will diligently and 
honestly administer the affairs of the said board, and that he will not knowingly violate, or willingly 
permit to be violated, any of the provisions of the law applicable to the retirement system. Such oath 
shall be subscribed to by the members making it, certified by said clerk, and filed in the office of said 
clerk. 
(g) ?Voting. Each trustee shall be entitled to one (1) vote on the board. Three (3) affirmative votes shall 
be necessary for a decision by the trustees at any meeting of the board. The chairman shall have the 
right to one (1) vote only. 
(h) ?Ability to promulgate rules and regulations. Subject to the limitations of this article, the board shall 
from time to time establish uniform rules and regulations for the administration of funds created by 
this article and for transactions of its business, including provisions for expulsion of a member for 
provisions as provided in F.S. 112.501(2). 
Cross reference— Attendance policy for city boards. 
(i) ?Pension board attorney and board administrator. The board shall employ an attorney who shall 
advise them prior to the board entering into agreements, contracts or action on retirements. In 
addition to the secretary elected by the board, the board shall further employ a board administrator, 
not a board member, who shall prepare agendas, minutes, computations, motions and other required 
documentation for the board. If the board administrator is a city employee, the time that may be 
allocated to board matters shall be at a reasonable level. If the time required by the board for the 
administrator to complete board matters becomes excessive, then it shall be the decision of the city 
manager to seek appropriate remedy with either the trustee or the city commission. One of the 
appropriate remedies may be that the fund shall reimburse the general fund for the excessive 
employee time. The board shall be authorized to pay the attorney and the board administrator a 
reasonable compensation from the trust fund. 
(j) ?Removal of trustee. Any trustee who neglects the duties of his office as determined by the board 
may be removed by four (4) concurring votes among the board. 
(k) ?Duties and responsibilities. The duties and responsibilities of the board of trustees shall include, but 
not necessarily be limited by, the following: 
(1) ?To construe the provisions of the system and determine all questions arising thereunder, in 
accordance with this article and state law. 
(2) ?To determine all questions relating to eligibility and participation. 
(3) ?To determine and certify the amount of all retirement allowances or other benefits hereunder. 
(4) ?To establish uniform rules and procedures to be followed for administrative purposes, benefit 
applications and all matters required to administer the system. 
(5) ?To distribute at regular intervals to employees information concerning the system. 
(6) ?To receive and process all applications for participation and benefits. 
(7) ?To authorize all payments whatsoever from the fund and to notify the disbursing agent, in 
writing and to issue drafts upon the fund, of approved benefits payments and other expenditures 
arising through operation of the system and fund. All drafts shall be consecutively numbered, be 
signed by the board chairman and secretary, and shall state upon their face the purpose for 
which they are drawn. 
(8) ?To have performed actuarial studies and actuarial valuations, which valuations will be complete 
at least every two (2) years commencing from the last actuarial valuation of the plan, and make 
recommendations regarding any and all changes in the provisions of the system. Upon request 
of the city, the trustees shall direct the actuary to perform all calculations necessary to cost 
collective bargaining proposals. The cost of said proposals shall be reimbursed to the fund by 
the city. 
(9) ?To have performed an annual independent audit of the system and fund. 
(10) ?To recommend to the City of Oakland Park civil service board procedures and standards 
relative to the medical examination of new and/or continuing employees. 
(Ord. No. O-75-15, § 6, 12-3-75; Ord. No. O-82-14, § 4, 7-7-82; Ord. No. O-83-7, § 1, 1-19-83; 
Ord. No. O-88-21, § 4, 7-20-88; Ord. No. O-95-10, § 1, 7-5-95; Ord. No. O-2002-025, § 1, 9-18-
02) 


Sec. 9-67. - Finances and fund management. 
(a) ?Trust fund establishment. As part of the system there is hereby established the fund, into which 
shall be deposited all of the contributions and assets whatsoever attributable to the system. 
(b) ?Custody of assets. The actual custody and supervision of the fund, and the assets thereof, shall be 
vested in the board. Payment of benefits and disbursements from the fund shall be made by the 
disbursing agent on authorization from the board. 
(c) ?Administration of the fund. The board shall institute, maintain, or defend any litigation required for 
the preservation of the trust fund or in connection with the administration of the trust fund. The fund 
shall be obligated to pay on behalf of the board all expenses and/or liabilities incurred as a result of 
institution, maintenance or defense of any litigation related to the fund. The board may hire and 
appoint such person, agents, or entities, including corporate fiduciaries, as in its discretion may be 
required or advisable to enable it to perform custodial and investment duties hereunder; provided 
further, the board may enter into agency, investment, advisory and custodial agreements for the 
purpose of securing investment and custodianship services for the system and fund. The board shall 
appoint an auditor who shall submit reports and recommendations to the trustees for each year. 
However, the city manager, utilizing general fund monies, may obtain independent financial analysis 
and evaluation of fund activities and make periodic reports to the city commission. 
(d) ?Records and reports. All funds and securities of the system may be commingled to the fund, 
provided that accurate records are maintained at all times reflecting the financial composition of the 
fund, including accurate current accounts and entries as regards the following: 
(1) ?Current amounts of accumulated contributions of members, on both an individual and 
aggregate account basis; 
(2) ?Receipts and disbursements; 
(3) ?Benefit payments; 
(4) ?Current amounts clearly reflecting all monies, funds and assets whatsoever attributable to 
contributions and deposits from the city; 
(5) ?All interest, dividends and gains or losses whatsoever; and 
(6) ?Such other entries as may be properly required so as to reflect a clear and complete financial 
report of the fund. 
(e) ?Investment of fund assets. Subject to subsection (h) below, the board shall have the following 
investment powers and authority: 
(1) ?To invest and reinvest the fund in such securities or in such property, real or personal, 
wherever situated, as it shall deem advisable, including, but not limited to, insurance company 
investment contracts, stocks (common or preferred), bonds and mortgages, and other 
evidences of indebtedness or ownership, although the same may not be of the character 
permitted for trustees' investment by the laws of the State of Florida. The board shall be vested 
with full legal title to said fund subject, however, and in any event, to the authority and power of 
the city commission to amend or terminate this trust; provided, that no amendment or fund 
termination shall ever result in the use of any assets of this fund for any purpose except for the 
payment of regular expenses, benefits and purposes as set forth in this system. The income 
thereof, without distinction between principal and income, shall be held and administered by the 
board or its agent in the fund, and the board shall not be required to segregate or invest 
separately any portion of the fund. 
(2) ?The board may retain in cash or unproductive of income such amount of the fund as it may 
deem advisable, having regard for the cash requirements of the system. 
(3) ?Neither the board nor any person or entity shall be liable for the making, retention or sale of 
any investment or reinvestment made as herein provided, nor for any loss or diminishment of 
the fund, except that due to his or its own negligence, willful misconduct or lack of good faith. 
(4) ?The board may cause any investment in securities held by it to be registered in or transferred 
into its name as trustee or into the name of such nominee as it may direct, or it may retain them 
unregistered and in form permitting transferability, but the books and records shall at all times 
show that all investments are part of the fund. 
(5) ?The board is empowered, but is not required, to vote upon any stocks, bonds or securities of 
any corporation, association, or trust, and to give general or specific proxies or powers of 
attorney with or without power of substitution; to participate in mergers, reorganizations, 
recapitalizations, consolidations, and similar transactions with respect to such securities; to 
deposit such stock or other securities in any voting trust or any prospective or like committee, 
with the trustee, or with depositories designated thereby, or amortize or fail to amortize any part 
or all of the premium or discount resulting from the acquisition or disposition of assets; and 
generally, to exercise any of the powers of an owner with respect to stocks, bonds or other 
investments comprising the fund which it may deem to be to the best interest of the fund to 
exercise. 
(6) ?The board shall not be required to make any inventory or appraisal or report to any court, nor to 
secure any order of court for the exercise of any power herein contained. 
(7) ?Where any action which the board is required to take or any duty or function which it is required 
to perform, either under the terms herein or under the general law applicable to it as trustee 
under this article, can reasonably be taken or performed only after receipt by it from a member, 
the city or any other entity of specific information, certification, direction or instructions, the 
board shall be free of liability in failing to take such action or perform such duty or function until 
such information, certification, direction or instruction has been received by it. 
(8) ?Any overpayments or underpayments from the fund to a member or beneficiary caused by 
errors of computation shall be adjusted with interest at a rate per annum approved by the board. 
Overpayments shall be charged against payments next succeeding the correction. 
Underpayments shall be made up from the trust fund. 
(9) ?The board shall sustain no liability whatsoever for the sufficiency of the fund to meet the 
payments and benefits herein provided for. However, the board shall periodically review the 
actuarial studies for the system and consult with the system's actuary to make sure that the 
funding of the plan, including the sufficiency of the payments being made to the fund by the city, 
is being maintained on an actuarially sound basis. The board shall be entitled to rely 
conclusively upon all reports, opinions, tables, valuations and computations furnished by the 
actuary for this purpose. 
(10) ?In any application to or proceeding or action in the courts, only the city and the board shall be 
necessary parties, and neither the county, any member or other person having an interest in the 
fund shall be entitled to any notice of service or process. Any judgment entered in such a 
proceeding or action shall be conclusive upon all persons. 
(f) ?Board may employ agents. Any of the foregoing powers and functions reposed in the board may be 
performed or carried out by the board through duly authorized agents, provided that the board at all 
times maintains continuous supervision over the acts of any such agent and provided further that 
legal title to said fund shall always remain in the board. 
(g) ?Administrative changes. No change in any of the operating rules of the system shall be made 
without the approval of a majority of the board. 
(h) ?Investment guidelines. With regard to the investment of the fund in stocks, bonds, mortgages and 
other evidence of indebtedness or ownership, the board shall formally adopt investment guidelines to 
be followed with regard to security standards, proportion of the fund to be held in individual securities 
or category of investment, and any other similar items as determined by the board. 
(Ord. No. O-75-15, § 7, 12-3-75; Ord. No. O-83-7, § 2, 1-19-83; Ord. No. O-95-10, § 1, 7-5-95) 


Sec. 9-68. - Amendment or termination of the system. 
(a) ?Amendment . The city commission shall have the right at any time to modify, alter or amend the 
system in whole or in part; provided, however, that the city shall not have the power to amend the 
system in such manner as to cause or permit any portion of the fund held for members under the 
system to be diverted to purposes other than for the exclusive benefit of such members and their 
beneficiaries, or to reduce any benefits or amounts already vested in the members according to the 
provisions hereof, and provided further, that no such amendment shall have the effect of revesting in 
the city any portion of the fund, except such amount as may, due to an erroneous actuarial 
computation, remain in the fund after the satisfaction of all liabilities under the system. In the event of 
a merger or consolidation of services which results in members of the system being employed by the 
Broward Sheriff's Office, the employees so affected shall have the option of remaining in this plan or 
participating in the Florida Retirement System (FRS). In no event shall an employee's rights be 
diminished or impaired in violation of F.S. § 112.0515. 
(b) ?Termination. The city reserves the right to terminate the system and its contributions thereunder at 
any time, the termination to be effective at the close of business on a date to be designated by the 
city. If the city terminates the system, or if it is otherwise terminated or contributions to it completely 
discontinued, the board shall continue to administer the fund in accordance with the provisions 
hereof, such that the benefits of each member on such date of termination or discontinuance are 
nonforfeitable and shall be one hundred (100) percent vested to the extent then funded. Upon 
termination of the plan, preference in the distribution of assets shall first be given to retired members 
and their beneficiaries; then to fulfilling obligations to vested members, whether or not in service, 
then to the return of contributions of nonvested members and then to the payment of any 
administrative obligations of the plan. Following the payment to the last living member of the plan 
and satisfaction of all other debts and obligations of the plan, any assets remaining shall revert to the 
city and to the state in the same proportion as their contributions were made to the plan. The police 
plan shall remain in effect until the final benefit payment has been made to the last participant or 
beneficiary and shall then be terminated in accordance with F.S. § 185.37. 
(Ord. No. O-75-15, § 8, 12-3-75; Ord. No. O-76-23, § 1, 9-15-76; Ord. No. O-82-7, § 1, 3-17-82; 
Ord. No. O-95-10, § 1, 7-5-95; Ord. No. O-2000-012, § 3, 6-21-00 Ord. No. O-2002-025, § 2, 9-
18-02) 


Sec. 9-69. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a) ?Medical board . The city manager shall designate a medical board, to be composed of three (3) 
physicians appointed as follows: One (1) by the board of trustees, one (1) by the city manager, and 
one (1) by the mayor with commission approval, who shall arrange for and pass upon all medical 
examinations required under the provisions of this article, shall investigate all essential statements or 
certificates made by or on behalf of a member in connection with an application for disability or 
retirement, and shall report in writing to the board its conclusions and recommendations upon all 
matters referred to it. The payment for such services shall be determined by the board. 
(b) ?Rights of discharged members . Members entitled to a pension shall not forfeit the same upon 
dismissal from the department, but shall be treated as having terminated employment and entitled to 
benefits as herein provided. 
(c) ?Recovery from disability . If a member who has been retired on a disability benefit regains his health 
sufficiently to be able to perform duties in the police department, fire department or the county fire or 
county emergency medical services department, the board shall require said member to resume 
employment with the respective department at the earliest time at which there is a suitable position 
available, and discontinue the pension. The city agrees to comply with the provisions of the 
Americans With Disabilities Act. 
(d) ?Nonassignability . No benefit provided for in this plan shall be assignable or subject to garnishment 
for debt or for other legal process. This restriction shall not apply to orders providing for alimony, 
child support or medical payments to a former spouse or to children entered by a court of competent 
jurisdiction. A member who is the subject of a dissolution of marriage or divorce proceeding and 
whose vested benefit in this plan is subject to division as marital property shall be required to submit 
any such order to the board of trustees for review prior to entry by the court. The cost of the review 
or correction of any order distributing a member's interest in this plan shall be borne by the member. 
(e) ?Death benefits . Benefits granted to members shall be paid to them for life, and shall not be revoked 
nor in any way diminished except as provided in this article. 
(f) ?Pension validity . The board of shall have the power to examine the facts upon which any pension 
shall heretofore have been granted under any prior or existing law, or shall hereafter be granted or 
obtained erroneously, fraudulently, or illegally for any reason. Said board is empowered to purge the 
pension rolls of any person heretofore granted a pension under prior or existing law or hereafter 
granted under this article, if the same is found to be erroneous, fraudulent or illegal for any reason, 
and to reclassify any pensioner who has [been] heretofore under any prior or existing law, or who 
shall hereafter under this article be, erroneously, improperly or illegally classified. 
(g) ?Incompetents. In the event that any beneficiary of payments under this plan shall be under the age 
of eighteen (18) years, the board shall make payment to properly appointed guardian. The board 
shall require the guardian to produce such proof of guardianship as the board shall deem necessary 
and proper. If the board shall receive information that any member or beneficiary in receipt of 
benefits under the plan is incapable of personally receiving and giving a valid receipt for such 
payments, the board may, after notice and hearing, make payments to a spouse or other person 
who, in the opinion of the board, is capable of receiving payments on behalf of the member or 
beneficiary. Any payments so made shall be a complete discharge of any liability under the system 
for such payment. 
(h) ?Distribution of marital assets. 
(1) ?In the event that a member of the system shall be the subject of a dissolution of marriage 
action and the member's interest in the plan is subject to distribution, said distribution shall take 
place in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(2) ?When a member is the subject of a dissolution of marriage action, the member shall promptly 
inform the board of said action and the board shall provide to the member and the nonmember 
spouse a draft order distributing the member's interest in accordance with the provisions of the 
system. 
(3) ?Said order shall provide for the creation of a trust account in the name of the member and 
former spouse into which the member's retirement check shall be direct deposited. The trustee 
of the account shall distribute between the member and the former spouse their relative interest 
in the benefit. 
(4) ?No person shall be permitted to receive a payment from the system while the member is still 
employed. No person who is not authorized to be a survivor under the terms of the plan shall 
have a survivorship interest in any member's benefit. 
(5) ?In the event that the board shall have to intervene in any dissolution of marriage proceeding to 
correct any order providing for a distribution of benefits not consistent with the terms of the 
system, the member agrees to bear the cost of the board's action, including attorney's fees. 
(i) ?Miscellaneous. 
(1) ?Actuarial data . The board will furnish the actuary with all data required for necessary actuarial 
computations under the plan. 
(2) ?Wage-control laws . No payment of any benefit, contribution or other sum which would 
constitute a violation of any applicable wage-control law shall be made hereunder. 
(Ord. No. O-75-15, § 9, 12-3-75; Ord. No. O-83-23, § 4, 12-21-83; Ord. No. O-95-10, § 1, 7-5-
95) 


Sec. 9-70. - Deferred retirement option plan. 
(a) ?A deferred retirement option plan ("DROP") is hereby created. 
(b) ?Eligibility to participate in the DROP is based upon eligibility for normal service retirement at age 
forty-two (42) with twenty (20) years of creditable service. 
(c) ?The maximum period of DROP participation for firefighters who, on March 1, 2013, are within seven 
(7) years of the normal retirement date provided in subsection 9-63 (a)(1)a and all police 
officers/deputy sheriffs is five (5) years. The maximum period of DROP participation for firefighters 
hired on or after March 1, 2013 and firefighters who, on March 1, 2013, are not within seven (7) 
years of the normal retirement date provided in subsection 9-63 (a)(1)a is three (3) years. Members 
entering the DROP must submit an irrevocable letter of termination or resignation, effective not later
