    Electronic goods: Televisions, stereos, radios, microwave ovens, and computers. 
    Garbage: All waste accumulations of animal, fruit or vegetable matter that attend the preparation, 
use, cooking, dealing in or storage of meat, fowl, fish, fruits and vegetables, or other containers originally 
used for foodstuffs, except for coconuts. 
    Hazardous waste: Solid waste or a combination of solid wastes, which, because of its quantity, 
concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics, may cause, or significantly contribute to, 
an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness or may pose a substantial present or 
potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly transported, disposed of, stored, 
treated, or otherwise managed. 
    Improved property: Property on which a building or other improvements have been placed or 
constructed, which improvements result in such property generating solid waste or being capable of 
generating solid waste. 
    Level of service: The frequency of service events per week and/or the size and type of container. 
    Oversized burnable wastes: Items which are burnable but which cannot readily be collected in the 
normal mechanized compaction truck or disposed of in the conventional refuse incinerator; also, items 
which cannot be easily crushed having bulk in excess of ten (10) cubic feet or a maximum single 
dimension exceeding eight (8) feet in length, exceeding eight (8) inches in diameter, or fifty (50) pounds in 
weight. 
    Oversized nonburnable wastes: Wastes, which are largely of metallic construction such as 
refrigerators, stoves, metal furniture, washing machines, bed springs and other similar type wastes. 
    Premises: Any land area or a portion thereof and the buildings and structures thereon used for any 
purpose which will generate or has the capability of generating solid waste. 
    Public works: The public works department of the City of Oakland Park. 
    Radio frequency identification transponder (RFID tag): A device placed on all city-owned dumpsters 
that has a number encoded in it that uniquely identifies each dumpster. 
    Receptacle: A city-provided dumpster or cart. 
    Recyclables materials: Those materials which are capable of being recycled which would otherwise 
be disposed of as solid waste. 
    Residential property: All improved property containing no more than four (4) dwelling units. 
    Refuse: Both garbage and rubbish as defined herein and all putrescible and nonputrescible solid 
wastes, except body waste, household trash, commercial trash, yard trash, tree trimmings, debris and 
metal cans other than bimetal cans used as beverage cans. However, items under this section shall not 
include oversized burnable and oversized nonburnable waste. 
    Residential dwelling unit: A building, or portion thereof, which is located upon residential property 
and lawfully used for residential purposes, consisting of one (1) or more rooms arranged, designed, used, 
or intended to be used as living quarters for one family unit only. For purposes of this chapter, excludes 
multi-family buildings with more than four (4) dwelling units. 
    Resource recovery system: A place for disposing of solid waste as designated by the city. 
    Rubbish: All nonputrescible solid wastes, consisting of both combustible and noncombustible 
wastes. 
    Service event: Each time a receptacle is emptied of the solid waste contained therein. 
    Solid waste: Solid waste as defined by section 403.703, Florida Statutes, as amended, and includes 
without limitation, garbage, yard trash, rubbish, refuse, or other discarded material, including solid, liquid, 
semi-solid, or contained gaseous material, resulting from normal housekeeping activities but excluding 
hazardous waste, bio-hazardous waste and special waste. 
    Special waste: Solid waste that requires special handling and management including, but not limited 
to, asbestos, whole tires, used tires, used oil, lead-acid batteries, and bio-hazardous wastes and shall 
include items that exceed size limitations for yard trash. 
    Swale: That area immediately adjacent to the road between the highway driving surface and the 
adjacent property line. 
    Yard trash: Vegetative matter resulting from normal yard and landscaping maintenance such as tree 
and shrub trimmings and or grass clippings. 
    White goods: Refrigerators, clothes washing machines, clothes dryers, stoves, ovens, water heaters 
and dishwashing machines. 
(Code 1960, § 8-4; Ord. No. O-82-19, § 1, 8-4-82; Ord. No. O-88-22, § 1, 8-3-88; Ord. No. O-
88-30, § 1, 9-21-88; Ord. No. O-90-17, §§ 3, 4, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-92-25, § 2, 12-2-92; Ord. 
No. O-94-17, § 2, 11-2-94; Ord. No. O-96-3, § 2, 3-6-96; Ord. No. O-98-18, § 2, 8-19-98; Ord. 
No. O-98-24, § 2, 10-21-98; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03; Ord. No. O-2010-016, § 2, 5-
5-10; Ord. No. O-2011-016, § 2, 7-20-11) 
Cross reference— Sanitation department established, § 2-1. 


Sec. 13-2. - Inspections to enforce article. 
    The health officer of the county and his authorized representatives, the director and other duly 
authorized inspectors as may be designated by the city manager are hereby authorized to inspect any 
premises in the city for the purpose of seeing that the requirements of this article are being complied with, 
and it shall be unlawful for any person to resist or interfere with such representatives or inspectors by 
word, deed or act in the performance of such inspection. 
(Code 1960, § 8-15; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 5, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-92-25, § 3, 12-2-92; Ord. No. 
O-96-3, § 3, 3-6-96) 


Sec. 13-3. - General requirements for receptacles. 
(a) ?Every person in possession, charge or control of any premises where solid waste is created or 
accumulated, and, in the case of multiple dwelling units, the owner of the premises, at all times, shall 
provide solid waste service in accordance with the requirements of this chapter, utilizing city-
provided receptacles for service provided by the city. The use of private garbage cans for city service 
is not authorized. 
(b) ?In the case of multiple occupancies, where all dwelling units or other units are owned by the same 
person and the properties are contiguous, subject to approval of the director, the owner may be 
allowed one (1) dumpster of sufficient size and capacity to serve all the units, providing that it shall 
be accessible to each unit. 
(c) ?All persons in possession, charge or control of a commercial establishment are required to have 
access to a dumpster supplied by the city. Joint use may be authorized by the director as provided in 
section 13-11. 
(d) ?Subject to the approval of the director, persons charged in this section with the duty of providing 
dumpster service may arrange for cart service. 
(Code 1960, § 8-5; Ord. No. 564, § 1, 1-5-72; Ord. No. O-82-19, § 2, 8-4-82; Ord. No. O-92-25, 
§ 4, 12-2-92; Ord. No. O-96-3, § 4, 3-6-96; Ord. No. O-98-18, § 3, 8-19-98; Ord. No. O-98-24, § 
3, 10-21-98; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03) 


Sec. 13-4. - Permit to engage in refuse collection business. 
    The permitting and regulation of roll-off, compactor and cardboard recycling shall be governed by 
section 7-4 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. O-98-24, § 4, 10-21-98) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-98-24, § 4, adopted Oct. 21, 1998, repealed the former § 13-4, 
which pertained to garbage cans for moored or docked boats, and replaced it with a new § 13-4 
to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 


Sec. 13-5. - Covering and maintenance of receptacles; replacement or removal of defective receptacles. 
(a) ?The lids of carts or dumpsters shall be kept tightly closed at all times other than when solid waste is 
being deposited therein or removed therefrom. Lids of dumpsters may be secured with a locking 
mechanism or device of the type approved by the director. The city will, upon request, supply and 
install locking mechanisms on dumpsters. 
(b) ?Carts and dumpsters used for the deposit of solid waste for collection by the city public works 
department shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and in good repair so that collection 
therefrom shall not injure the person collecting the contents thereof. 
(c) ?Every person in possession, charge or control of any premises, and, in the case of multiple 
occupancies, the owner of the premises, shall be responsible for complying with this section. 
(Code 1960, § 8-5; Ord. No. 564, § 1, 1-5-72; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 7, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-92-
25, § 5, 12-2-92; Ord. No. O-96-3, § 6, 3-6-96; Ord. No. O-98-18, § 5, 8-19-98; Ord. No. O-98-
24, § 5, 10-21-98; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03) 


Sec. 13-6. - Unlawful removal from receptacles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than those removing the entire contents thereof for disposal, 
to remove any solid waste or other like materials from any cart, dumpster or other container after it has 
been placed therein. 
(Code 1960, § 8-8; Ord. No. O-92-25, § 6, 12-2-92; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03) 


Sec. 13-7. - Removing, misusing, damaging, etc., solid waste receptacles. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or cause to be removed from any street or sidewalk in 
the city any receptacle furnished by the city for the deposit of solid waste or recyclable items. It shall 
be unlawful for any person to sit upon or deface any such receptacle or cause it to be used in any 
way, which will make it inaccessible for the receipt of solid waste or recyclable items. It shall be 
unlawful for any person to place, store or cause to be placed or stored, any goods, merchandise, 
lumber, trash or any other material near any such receptacle in such a manner as to interfere with or 
preclude the use of such receptacle for the purpose which it is intended to serve. 
(b) ?Any customer that allows or causes damage to the radio frequency identification transponder (RFID 
Tag) on the city-provided dumpster assigned to his/her account shall be charged a fee of sixty-five 
dollars ($65.00) to have a new RFID tag installed by the public works department. 
(c) ?Any damage to carts or dumpsters, other than normal wear and tear, is the responsibility of the 
customer who shall be charged accordingly for repair or replacement of the receptacle. 
(Code 1960, § 8-19; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 8, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03) 


Sec. 13-8. - Placement for collection and removal after collection. 
(a) ?All solid waste carts and recycling containers to be emptied by the public works department shall be 
placed at the locations designated by the city before 7:00 a.m. and removed by 11:00 p.m. on the 
collection days designated by the department. Solid waste carts and recycling containers may be 
placed in public rights-of-way for collection in a manner which does not impede the safe flow of 
vehicular or pedestrian traffic. All solid waste carts and recycling containers, if visible from the right-
of-way, shall be stored behind the front, or side of the building provided service, where lot conditions 
allow for such storage. Containers which are not removed from the collection locations by the time 
allowed in this section are subject to removal and proper placement by the service provider. The 
customer will be charged for the service provider's removal service. A service fee, on file in the city 
clerk's office, for each such removal service provided by the service provider shall be assessed 
against the owner or occupant of the property and shall be collected in the manner provided by 
section 13-11.5. The fee shall be supplemental to any other penalties provided for violation of this 
section. 
(b) ?Special solid waste collections or services may be arranged with the public works department 
whereby solid waste will be collected from locations at variance with this section. The type of special 
collections, services and charges are subject to approval by the director. 
(Code 1960, §§ 8-5—8-7; Ord. No. 564, § 1, 1-5-72; Ord. No. O-88-30, § 2, 9-21-88; Ord. No. 
O-90-17, § 9, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-92-25, § 7, 12-2-92; Ord. No. O-96-3, § 7, 3-6-96; Ord. No. 
O-98-18, § 6, 8-19-98; Ord. No. O-98-24, § 6, 10-21-98; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03; 
Ord. No. O-2009-010, § 2, 4-15-09; Ord. No. O-2010-016, § 3, 5-5-10) 


Sec. 13-9. - Collectors to have safe and convenient access to premises. 
    Tenants, lessees, occupants, or owners of premises shall provide collectors a safe and convenient 
access to solid waste receptacles. All vicious animals shall either be confined or the solid waste 
receptacles placed where collectors may empty them without threat of attack from such animals. Where 
collections are made from private alleys and access ways, such approaches shall be maintained in such 
a manner as not to be a hazard to public works department personnel or equipment. Failure to comply 
with this section, after notification by the public works department, will cause service to be discontinued 
until the condition is corrected. 
(Code 1960, § 8-5; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 10, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-96-3, § 8, 3-6-96; Ord. No. O-
2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03) 


Sec. 13-10. - Mandatory residential solid waste collection service, fees and deposits therefor. 
(a) ?Collection of garbage shall be made by the public works department not less than two (2) times per 
week at residential dwelling units. 
(b) ?Basic residential service will be one (1) cart per residential dwelling unit with a pick-up by the city 
not exceeding the contents of the cart. However, a customer may also request one (1) additional cart 
per unit for an additional monthly fee. All carts remain the property of the city. 
(c) ?There is no administrative fee in conjunction with residential solid waste collection service. 
(d) ?Mandatory residential service fees and deposits are established per residential dwelling unit, 
including single family residences, duplexes, triplexes and quadplexes as follows: 
(1) ?Basic cart service fee per unit is by annual assessment in accordance with chapter 20, article 
IV, solid waste services assessments. 
(2) ?Additional second cart service fee per unit per month shall be nine dollars and five cents 
($9.05) effective October 1, 2017. 
(3) ?Deposit per cart—(second cart service only): 
a. ?Property owner account ..... $17.00 
b. ?Tenant account ..... 34.00 
(e) ?In the event the city experiences increased solid waste disposal costs, it shall increases cart fees in 
the following manner: 
(1) ?When tipping fee rates increase, cart fees will be adjusted by the financial services department, 
when necessary, to cover the increase by applying a pass-through adjustment cost that covers 
the additional cost to the solid waste system. 
(f) ?Notwithstanding the provisions set forth herein, where applicable, the city shall impose a solid waste 
service assessment in accordance with article IV, section 20-151 through section 20-203 of the Code 
of Ordinances as may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1960, §§ 8-20.2—8-20.4; Ord. No. 535, § 1, 5-5-71; Ord. No. 601, § 1, 9-5-73; Ord. No. 
O-74-17, § 1, 9-4-74; Ord. No. O-75-8, § 1, 8-20-75; Ord. No. O-75-16, § 1, 12-17-75; Ord. No. 
O-76-12, § 1, 5-19-76; Ord. No. O-80-28, § 1, 11-5-80; Ord. No. O-82-19, § 3, 8-4-82; Ord. No. 
O-84-6, § 1, 2-15-84; Ord. No. O-84-25, § 1, 11-7-84; Ord. No. O-86-28, § 1, 10-15-86; Ord. 
No. O-87-34, § 1, 10-21-87; Ord. No. 88-30, § 3, 9-21-88; Ord. No. 89-11, § 2, 9-20-89; Ord. 
No. O-90-17, § 11, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-92-25, § 8, 12-2-92; Ord. No. O-94-17, §§ 3—5, 11-2-

Sec. 13-11. - Mandatory commercial solid waste collection service, fees and deposits therefor. 
(a) ?Each owner of a commercial establishment located in the city shall subscribe to a regularly 
scheduled solid waste collection service provided or permitted by the city. 
(b) ?For purposes of this chapter, each multi-family residential structure having more than four (4) 
dwelling units and each warehouse, storefront, bay, or office, shall be considered a commercial 
establishment. It will be permissible to share dumpster service under one of the following conditions 
subject to the written approval of the director: 
(1) ?The owner of a building may allow commercial establishments within the building to share a 
dumpster. 
(2) ?The owner of multiple buildings lying within a single property may allow the sharing of a 
dumpster among the occupants of those buildings. 
(3) ?The owner of a commercial establishment may allow other businesses in the same building to 
share a dumpster. 
(c) ?Basic commercial cart service provided by the city shall be a pickup of one (1) cart per dwelling unit, 
warehouse, storefront, bay or office twice per week. 
(1) ?All carts shall be supplied by the public works department and shall remain the property of the 
city. 
(2) ?A customer may request one (1) additional cart per unit. 
(3) ?It shall be unlawful for any person other than the customer, or the customer's agents, to deposit 
solid waste in the customer's cart unless designated for public use. 
(d) ?Dumpster service provided by the city will be one or more dumpsters per account picked up on a 
regular schedule of one (1) to five (5) times per week. 
(1) ?All dumpsters shall be supplied by the public works department and shall remain the property 
of the city. 
(2) ?Garbage (putrescible waste) generated by commercial establishments shall be picked up at a 
minimum of twice per week. 
(3) ?It shall be unlawful for any person other than the customer, or the customer's agents, to deposit 
solid waste in the customer's dumpster unless designated for public use. 
(e) ?An administrative fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be charged to open a commercial cart service 
account if water service is not also provided. If the account is opened in conjunction with a water 
service account, an administrative fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), covering both services, shall be 
charged. An administrative fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per dumpster shall be charged to open up a 
new dumpster service account if water service is not also provided. If the account is opened in 
conjunction with water service, an administrative fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) plus fifty dollars 
($50.00) per dumpster, covering both services, shall be charged. 
(f) ?Commercial cart service fees and deposits. Each commercial establishment and each dwelling unit 
within multi-family buildings with more than four (4) dwelling units shall be charged as a unit. 
(1) ?Basic cart service fee per unit, per month shall be twenty-six dollars and seventy-five cents 
($26.75) effective October 1, 2018. 
(2) ?Additional second cart service and recycling fee per unit, per month shall be) seventeen dollars 
and forty-seven cents ($17.47) effective October 1, 2018. 
(3) ?Deposit per cart: 
a. ?Property owner account ..... $60.00 
b. ?Tenant account ..... $200.00 
(g) ?Commercial dumpster service fees and deposits. 
(1) ?The service fee for dumpster accounts is based on a volume and frequency system using a 
per-cubic-yard rate to determine the monthly dumpster service fee by utilizing the following 
formula: 
a. ?(Size of dumpster × frequency of collection) × 4.33 weeks = Total cubic yards per month × 
per-cubic-yard rate = Monthly dumpster service fee. 
1. ?The per-cubic-yard rate of six dollars and seventy-five cents ($6.75) shall be effective 
October 1, 2018. 
(2) ?If by customer request, or if needed to effect collection, dumpsters are required to have casters 
installed; the customer shall be charged a one-time fee of eighty dollars ($80.00) per dumpster. 
(3) ?If a dumpster must be manually moved by public works personnel to allow for collection from 
the dumpster, there shall be a recurring roll-out fee of thirteen dollars and sixty-five cents 
($13.65) effective October 1, 2018 per dumpster, per service event. 
(4) ?Deposits per dumpster: 
a. ?Deposit requirement:

(h) ?For commercial cart service, in the event the city experiences increased solid waste disposal costs, 
it will seek to offset those increases in those circumstances, and using those procedures, as 
described in subsection 13-10(e) for residential cart fees. For dumpsters, the per-cubic-yard service

(Ord. No. O-96-3, § 12, 3-6-96; Ord. No. O-96-12, § 2, 9-4-96; Ord. No. O-96-16, § 3, 10-2-96; 
Ord. No. O-98-18, § 8, 8-19-98; Ord. No. O-98-24, § 8, 10-21-98; Ord. No. O-1999-01, § 2, 2-3-

Sec. 13-11.5. - Solid waste collection service, establishment and discontinuance of service, invoicing and 
delinquency. 
(a) ?A request for commencement, transfer or termination of solid waste service by the customer 
requires proof of being either an owner of, or tenant at, the service location. 
(b) ?All invoices for solid waste service, other services or other charges or penalties due the city, shall be 
rendered monthly and shall be due when rendered. 
(c) ?Fees for requests for account history printouts shall be in accordance with section 2-13. 
(d) ?Bills are due when rendered and shall be considered as received by the customer when delivered or 
mailed to the service address or such other address as provided in writing by customer. Non-receipt 
of bills by customer shall not release or diminish obligation of customer with respect to payment 
thereof, unless bills have been returned to the city for incorrect addresses. Each invoice shall 
become delinquent if not paid within twenty-five (25) days after the invoice date. All fees, excluding 
penalties, that remain unpaid at the end of twenty-five (25) days from the invoice date shall be 
subject to a penalty of one and one-half (1.50) percent on the outstanding balance. If any invoice is 
not paid within forty (40) days after the invoice date and if the account also receives water service 
from the city, the furnishing of water to the account shall be suspended. If the account does not 
receive water service from the city, the furnishing of solid waste service to the account shall be 
suspended. When an account remains in arrears ninety (90) days after the invoice date, the account 
shall be closed and the existing deposit applied to the arrears. Any account holder whose account 
becomes delinquent shall be subject to all laws, federal, state and local, allowing for the collection of 
the full amount of the delinquent account plus all costs and fees associated with the city's collection 
efforts. However, nothing contained herein shall limit the city's authority to approve "payment plans" 
for the extended payment of solid waste charges, so long as such extended terms are both 
reasonable and appropriate, in the sole discretion of the city, and are based upon customer 
hardship. 
(e) ?To re-establish solid waste service after having had service suspended due to delinquency, all 
delinquent amounts, fees and deposits as described below for all delinquent accounts (solid waste, 
water, sewer and stormwater) must be paid in full in advance. Upon payment of all required 
amounts, solid waste service will be restored with the next regularly scheduled collection date. 
Where in the judgment of the city manager it appears that the amount of such deposit is not sufficient 
to indemnify the city against the possible loss or the collection of charges, the city manager may, in 
his or her discretion, require a deposit equal to twice the amount of the largest actual or reasonably 
anticipated monthly or quarterly bill (however the account is billed). 
(1) ?All delinquent amounts, including penalties and interest as applicable, on all delinquent 
accounts, including solid waste, water, sewer and stormwater. 
(2) ?To restart suspended or terminated solid waste service, there shall be a fee of twenty-five 
dollars ($25.00) per account. 
a. ?If one (1) or more carts were removed due to suspension or termination of service, there 
shall be an additional fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) to replace the carts. 
b. ?If one (1) or more dumpsters were removed due to suspension or termination of service, 
there shall be an additional fee of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) per dumpster to 
replace the dumpsters. 
(3) ?The fee to restore water service, if applicable, as defined in chapter 22. 
(4) ?All deposits for water, solid waste and sewer services, as applicable, shall be restored to 
required amounts if these deposits were previously applied against delinquent accounts. 
(5) ?No credit will be given for any period less than one (1) month of discontinued service when 
solid waste service is discontinued under this section due to nonpayment. 
(f) ?In the event the account holder is also the property owner and shall fail or refuse to pay the full 
amount due, following ninety (90) days from the invoice date a notice of lien in favor of the City of 
Oakland Park may be recorded in the Official Records of Broward County, Florida. The notice of lien 
shall contain a sworn statement showing the amount and date of said bill and the legal description of 
the property against which the lien is assessed. The recordation of the notice of lien shall constitute a 
lien on the real property and shall remain in full force and effect for the amount due in principal, 
interest, and penalties, plus costs of court, if any, until final payment is made. The amount due shall 
bear interest at the legal rate beginning from the date of the assessment of the lien. The notice of 
lien, as recorded in the Official Records of Broward County, shall be prima facie evidence of the debt 
to the City of Oakland Park and may be foreclosed as mortgages are foreclosed in the circuit court. 
(g) ?Collection fee. In the event the city sends a delinquent account to a collection agency for collection, 
a collection fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be added to the account. 
(h) ?Application of customer payments. When a customer of the city's utilities systems has a combined 
utilities services billing, customer payments will be applied sequentially to water tax, penalties, 
stormwater, solid waste, sewer, other possible services and lastly water. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03; Ord. No. O-2007-035, § 2, 12-12-07; Ord. No. O-2010-
016, § 6, 5-5-10) 


Sec. 13-12. - Unlawful collection and removal. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than authorized agents and employees of the city or 
persons holding a current permit issued under section 7-4 of this Code, to collect and remove solid waste 
within the city. 
(Code 1960, § 8-20.1; Ord. No. 566, § 1, 1-19-72; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03) 


Sec. 13-13. - Designation and required use of dumps. 
(a) ?All solid waste must stay within the resource recovery system in accordance with article IV of this 
chapter. 
(c) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, or cause to be dumped, any solid waste upon any 
property other than a designated location. 
(Code 1960, §§ 8-9, 8-20; Ord. No. O-92-25, § 10, 12-2-92; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-
03) 


Sec. 13-14. - Littering prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep, throw or otherwise deposit, or cause to be swept, 
thrown or otherwise deposited, any solid waste into or on any public street, alley, sidewalk, park or 
waterway or on the property of another persons or property which is in the possession of another person 
within the city, or to permit any solid waste to accumulate in such a manner that it may be carried and 
deposited into or on any of the above places by action of the rain or wind. 
(Code 1960, §§ 8-17, 8-18, 21-2; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03) 


Sec. 13-15. - Disposal of construction and demolition debris, dirt, stumps, other items not accepted for 
collection during regularly scheduled bulk trash collection. 
    Debris, such as, but not limited to, lumber, plaster, roofing materials, and concrete, resulting from the 
demolition, construction, repair or remodeling of any building or appurtenance on private property, auto 
parts, marine parts, dirt, rocks, sod, tree stumps and tree trunks, limbs and branches over eight (8) inches 
in diameter or eight (8) feet in length or longer, shall not be accepted for collection during regularly 
scheduled bulk trash collection. These items will only be removed by the city for a fee as a special pickup 
at the request of the customer. However, in no circumstances will hazardous or bio-hazardous materials, 
which may be included in or be a part of the above materials, be picked up. 
(Code 1960, § 8-10; Ord. No. O-88-30, § 6, 9-21-88; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 14, 10-3-90; Ord. No. 
O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03; Ord. No. O-2006-025, § 2, 11-15-06) 


Sec. 13-16. - Disposal of debris from new construction prior to occupancy. 
    The city shall not be responsible for the collecting or hauling of rubbish, trash, limbs, brush or other 
debris from private property preliminary to, during or subsequent to the construction of new buildings of 
whatever type prior to occupancy. It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property or the 
contractor responsible for the accumulation of the debris, to see that such debris is properly removed in 
accordance with section 13-12. All construction debris must be properly stored in containers that will not 
allow it to be blown or otherwise deposited onto other properties or city right-of-way. 
(Code 1960, § 8-11; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03; Ord. No. O-2007-035, § 2, 12-12-07) 


Sec. 13-17. - Disposal of rubbish of tree surgeons, fence companies, similar work. 
    It shall be the responsibility of all fence companies, tree surgeons, nurseries and landscaping 
contractors, or any individual or company doing work on private property, to remove from the premises all 
rubbish resulting from such work. 
(Code 1960, § 8-13) 


Sec. 13-18. - Disposal of dead animals; animal excreta not to be placed in receptacles. 
    No dead animals or animal excreta shall be placed in carts, bulk pickup or in dumpsters regardless 
of how packaged. 
(Code 1960, § 8-12; Ord. No. O-82-19, § 5, 8-4-82; Ord. No. O-98-24, § 9, 10-21-98; Ord. No. 
O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03; Ord. No. O-2006-025, § 2, 11-15-06) 
Cross reference— Animals and fowl generally, Ch. 4. 
State Law reference— Disposal of dead animals, § 823.041, Fla. Stats. 


Sec. 13-19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, adopted Nov. 19, 2003, repealed former section 13-
19 in its entirety which pertained to the collection of cartons, crates, boxes, etc., and derived 
from the following: Code 1960, § 8-14; Ord. No. O-88-29, § 1, 9-21-88; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 15,

10, 10-21-98. 


Sec. 13-20. - Walking dog or cat; defecation on property of others or upon city property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person walking a dog or cat to allow the dog or cat to defecate upon the 
private property of others or upon any city property, including public thoroughfare, sidewalk, passageway, 
bypath, play area or park, unless the animal excrement is removed by the person. Provided, however, 
that nothing contained herein shall apply to seeing-eye dogs in the company of blind persons. 
(Ord. No. O-88-20, § 1, 7-20-88; Ord. No. O-98-24, § 11, 10-21-98; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 
11-19-03) 


Sec. 13-21. - Segregation of recyclable items. 
(a) ?Segregation required. Paper products, aluminum and metal food and beverage cans, plastic 
containers, glass and aseptic food and beverage containers shall be segregated from all other solid 
waste material by residential solid waste customers. Aluminum and bimetal beverage cans and glass 
food and beverage containers shall be placed in household recycling containers provided by the city 
and placed out for collection when full on the front curb or swale before 7:00 a.m. on the days 
designated by the department. Newspapers and other paper products shall be securely bundled with 
string or twine or placed in a paper grocery bag and placed out for collection according to the same 
schedule as the other recyclable items. At such time the city expands its recycling program to include 
additional items; they shall be subject to this section. 
(b) ?Placement. The collection point shall be either in the swale at the edge of the paved right-of-way 
directly in front of the property from which the recyclable items were generated or at a place 
authorized by the director. 
(c) ?Charge for replacement of container. The city shall charge the actual cost of replacement of any 
recycling container provided by the city. 
(d) ?Unauthorized collection. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person, firm or corporation not 
authorized by the director to collect or remove any recyclable item which has been specifically 
placed for collection in the recycling program as provided by this section. It is not the intent of this 
section to prohibit any nonprofit organization from soliciting newspapers, cans or bottles for the 
purpose of resource recovery and recycling. 
(e) ?Definitions. 
(1) ?Paper products shall be considered a periodical, usually daily or weekly, printed on "newsprint" 
and may include the normal percentage of rotogravure and colored insert sections included with 
the newspaper. Also included shall be catalogs, telephone books, magazines, junk mail, brown 
paper bags, office paper, soft-covered books, file folders, soda and beer cartons, and crushed 
food boxes. Expressly prohibited are plastic bags, glass, metal and garbage. Adequate 
precautions shall be made to prevent newspaper and other paper products from being scattered 
by the elements. 
(2) ?Aluminum and metal cans shall mean aluminum and metal cans only. No other cans, foil or 
other metals shall be included. 
(3) ?Glass foods and beverage containers shall mean whole glass jars and bottles designed to 
contain grocery items such as ketchup, mustard, pickle and mayonnaise jars, soft drink, beer, 
wine and liquor bottles and medicine bottles. Removal of labels, caps or neck rings is not 
required. Glass should be reasonably free of food and beverage residue. No window glass, 
mirror glass or other glass shall be included. 
(4) ?Plastic. #1, and 2, categories of plastic, aseptic containers and milk containers shall be 
included. 
(5) ?Aseptic containers shall mean containers designed to accommodate approximately four (4) to 
eight (8) fluid ounces. 
(6) ?Commingle. All recyclables shall be placed together in recycling containers except 
newspapers. 
(Ord. No. O-88-29, § 2, 9-21-88; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 16, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-92-25, § 11, 12-
2-92; Ord. No. O-94-1, §§ 2—4, 1-19-94; Ord. No. O-94-17, § 7, 11-2-94; Ord. No. O-2003-015, 
§ 2, 11-19-03; Ord. No. 2007-035, § 2, 12-12-07) 


Sec. 13-22. - Bulk trash collection services. 
    The city shall provide the following bulk trash collection services: 
(1) ?Unlimited bulk trash pickup: For residential single-family homes, duplexes, triplexes, and 
condominiums, the city shall complete a scheduled monthly collection of an unlimited amount of 
bulk trash items as defined in section 13-1 and in accordance with the rules in section 13-
22(a)(3). There is no additional charge for this service. Customers are prohibited from placing 
items eligible for bulk pickup collection in the swale area more than forty-eight (48) hours prior 
to the city-published schedule. Violations will be prosecuted in accordance with sections 13-32 
and 13-33 of the City Code. 
(2) ?White goods pickups: For residential single-family homes, duplexes, triplexes, and 
condominiums, the city will complete a scheduled monthly collection of oversized non-burnable 
wastes as defined in section 13-1 and in accordance with the rules in section 13-22(a)(3). 
Collection will take place during the regularly scheduled bulk trash pickup. There is no additional 
charge for this service. Customers are prohibited from placing items eligible for collection under 
this bulk pickup program in the swale area more than forty-eight (48) hours prior to the city-
published schedule. Violations will be prosecuted under sections 13-32 and 13-33 of the City 
Code. 
(3) ?Bulk trash collection rules: 
a. ?All bulk items, including items such as furniture (couches, chairs, tables, mattresses, etc.), 
carpeting, tree trimming and appliances (white goods) shall be placed curbside in a neat 
and orderly manner no later than 7:00 a.m. on the Monday of the week designated by the 
public works department. Due to the volume to be collected, collection may occur later than 
the first day but no later than the 5th day of the designated date of collection. 
b. ?All loose items, except appliances, other bulky household items, or trees and large 
landscape material, shall be bagged, tied securely and shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds 
each. 
c. ?Tree trimmings and branches shall not exceed eight (8) feet in length or eight (8) inches in 
diameter. All shrubbery cuttings, small twigs and leaves must be bagged. Bags shall not 
exceed fifty (50) pounds each. 
d. ?Glass shall be wrapped in newspaper and placed in secure weatherproof containers. 
e. ?All containers containing bulk trash shall be taken by the city. No container should be used 
that the customer wishes to retain. 
f. ?White goods (appliances) and metal items shall be put out and collected at the same time 
as the remainder of the bulk trash. However, they shall be placed separately from the 
remainder of the bulk trash to facilitate alternate collection procedures. Doors shall be 
removed from appliances and valves shall be removed from propane tanks. 
g. ?The city shall not collect bio-hazardous waste and household hazardous (paints, gas, oil, 
insecticides, pesticides and other chemicals) waste. Disposal information may be obtained 
from the public works department. 
h. ?The city shall not collect construction or demolition debris,, tree stumps, auto or marine 
parts, sand, dirt, rocks, sod, and bags exceeding ) fifty (50) pounds. 
i. ?Bulk trash shall be placed at least four (4) feet from city-provided solid waste receptacles; 
away from fences, poles, fire hydrants and parked cars and not under low hanging trees or 
overhead wires. 
j. ?Household garbage shall not be placed out nor collected as bulk trash. Residential solid 
waste receptacles shall be placed out on regular residential solid waste service days and 
away from bulk trash items. 
k. ?Bulk trash must be generated by the customer at the residential unit where the bulk trash is 
collected and shall not be collected if generated by other than the resident of the residential 
unit. 
l. ?Items left in front of vacant land or vacant homes shall not be collected. 
m. ?Condominiums must place their collective bulk materials in one location of the common 
property as determined by the solid waste division and the condo association. 
(4) ?Residents who include items for bulk trash pickup that are not within permissible bulk trash 
categories, as described in section 13-22(a)(3) and defined in section 13-1, shall be notified by 
code enforcement that they shall not receive bulk trash pickup. Residents shall then be given 
two (2) days to either remove all items from the designated pickup locations to sheltered 
storage sites pending disposition or to arrange with the city for special pickups, for a fee, as 
described in the next subsection. If items remain after two (2) and a special pickup has not been 
requested, the city shall nevertheless pick up the items. The resident shall be charged based on 
special pickup rates, plus any additional cost for labor and equipment that may be necessary to 
complete the collection. An administrative fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) will also be 
added to the collection charge for notification, processing and final compliance inspection. 
However, if items remain which are hazardous materials no pickup shall be made, until the 
appropriate corrective action has been made by the property owner. 
(5) ?Special pickup: Upon individual customer request through customer service, the city will 
arrange for the collection of bulk trash items, as defined in section 13-1, or other items as 
defined in section 13-15. There is a minimum fee of fifty-five dollars ($55.00) effective January 
1, 2008, fifty-seven dollars and seventy-five cents ($57.75) effective October 1, 2008, and sixty 
dollars ($60.00) effective October 1, 2009 for the first two (2) cubic yards plus twenty-two dollars 
and fifty cents ($22.50) effective January 1, 2008, twenty-three dollars and thirty-one cents 
($23.31) effective October 1, 2008 and twenty-four dollars and twenty-four cents ($24.24) 
effective October 1, 2009 per cubic yard for each cubic yard over the first two (2) cubic yards. In 
the event a special collection is the result of code enforcement action, all extra costs to collect 
and properly dispose of materials will also be charged to the utility account for the property 
along with a one hundred-dollar ($100.00) administrative fee. 
(Ord. No. O-98-24, § 12, 10-21-98; Ord. No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03; Ord. No. O-2003-015, 
§ 2, 11-19-03; Ord. No. O-2006-025, § 2, 11-15-06; Ord. No. O-2007-035, § 2, 12-12-07; Ord. 
No. O-2014-004, § 2, 5-7-14) 


Sec. 13-23. - Placement and screening of refuse and recycling mechanical, dumpster, compaction, and 
roll-off containers. 
(a) ?All refuse and recycling mechanical, dumpster, compaction, and roll-off containers shall be placed 
for storage in a location approved by the public works director, or designee. No such container shall 
be placed for storage in a right-of-way, but with the approval of the public works director or designee, 
may be temporarily placed in a right of way if necessary for collection. 
(b) ?All permanently located refuse or recycling mechanical, dumpster, compaction, or roll-off containers 
in use within the city limits shall be screened from view of any public right-of-way or alleyway by April 
15, 2010, as follows: 
(1) ?Screening shall be on at least three (3) sides and shall consist of wood, vinyl-coated chain-link 
fence with slats, brick, stone, concrete or similar material of a quality approved by the public 
works director. The unscreened side shall not be visible from a public right-of-way, alleyway or 
residential zoning district. The screening shall encompass the full height, length, and width of 
the container, and shall meet land development code requirements. All screenings shall be 
maintained for function, safety, and appearance. 
(2) ?Gates intended for service access shall provide an opening width of at least ten (10) feet for 
each mechanical container, and shall be designed to remain open when collection service is 
provided. Gates shall be required when the service entrance of the screening enclosure faces a 
public right-of-way, alleyway or is visible from a residential zoning district. 
(3) ?Where a gate in the screening structure faces a public right-of-way, alleyway or is visible from a 
residential district, the gate shall be closed except when collection service is provided. The 
service provider may close any gate left open in violation of this subsection. A service fee, on 
file in the city clerk's office, for each such closure service provided by the service provider shall 
be assessed against the owner or occupant of the property and shall be collected in the manner 
provided by section 13-11.5. The fee shall be supplemental to any other penalties provided for 
violation of this section. 
(4) ?All screening structures shall be reasonably accessible for collection service vehicles and shall 
not be located within the right-of-way of any public street or alleyway. 
(5) ?Refuse containers which are the subject of this ordinance shall be located as far as practical 
from abutting residential property lines. 
(c) ?When existing site conditions do not lend themselves to a location that conforms with the 
requirements of this section, the development review committee is authorized to grant waivers from 
the required number of required parking spaces, minimum pervious area requirements, or 
landscaping, buffering, and/or setback requirements of the land development code in order to 
accommodate the location of an existing refuse or recycling mechanical, dumpster, compaction, or 
roll-off container in conformance with paragraph (b) above. In considering which, if any, waivers to 
grant, the development review committee shall consider the number, extent and relative importance 
of existing and resulting non-conformities to proper site functioning and compatibility with adjacent 
uses. Appeal of a rejected waiver request may be made to the public works director or other 
designee of the city manager within ten (10) days of written notification of the rejected waiver. 
(d) ?In circumstances where it is not physically possible for a property to accommodate a refuse or 
recycling mechanical, dumpster, compaction, or roll-off container and the required screening 
enclosure; and where the granting of waivers is deemed unacceptable by the development review 
committee; and where the container is situated in a public right of way, service shall be changed 
from dumpster to cart service. 
(e) ?The city commission, following review and recommendation by the development review committee, 
at a duly noticed public hearing may grant exceptions to the container screening enclosure 
requirements of this section, and allow the container service to remain, where specific lot conditions 
make compliance impractical, the visibility of the container from a roadway is minimal, or the safety 
of the collection vehicle or the public in general would be compromised by the construction of the 
screening enclosure. 
(f) ?Temporary mechanical, dumpster, compaction or roll-off containers used for the collection of refuse 
or recycling during special events for a period of less than seven (7) days are exempt from the 
container screening requirements contained in this section. 
(g) ?Refuse or recycling mechanical or dumpster containers on wheels which are stored out of the public 
view, except during collections, are exempt from the screening requirement of this section. 
(h) ?Temporary mechanical, dumpster, compaction or roll-off containers used for the collection of refuse 
or recycling during construction activities are exempt from the container screening requirements 
contained in this section. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-010, § 2, 4-15-09) 


Secs. 13-24—13-30. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - ACCUMULATIONS OF REFUSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Order to remove fire hazards generally, § 6-14; procedure prescribed by this article 
applicable to removal of stagnant water and dense growths of vegetation, § 8-7. 


Sec. 13-31. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "refuse" shall mean all putrescible and nonputrescible solid 
wastes, except body waste, including but not limited to the following specified and all other similar wastes: 
Garbage, household trash, commercial trash, industrial and market waste, yard trash, tree trimmings, 
debris, metal cans other than bimetal cans used as beverage cans, rubbish, tin cans, papers, ashes, 
street cleanings and dead animals. 
    "Swale area" shall mean that area immediately adjacent to the road between the driving surface of 
the highway and the adjacent private property line. 
(Code 1960, § 8-21; Ord. No. O-86-2, § 2, 2-5-86; Ord. No. O-88-29, § 3, 9-21-88) 


Sec. 13-32. - Prohibited and declared to be a nuisance. 
(a) ?No person who is the owner of private property or who is in possession of private property shall 
permit any refuse to be placed, stored or accumulated on such property including the abutting swale 
area, unless the same is authorized by ordinance or has been previously specially authorized by the 
chief code enforcement officer for collection purposes only. 
(b) ?Any owner of property within the city shall be responsible for cleaning and clearing the swale areas 
abutting said real property of weeds, dead trees, undergrowth, rubbish, debris, trash, brush and 
unsanitary matter accumulated thereon; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit either 
the storage of refuse in authorized receptacles for collection by authorized collectors or the 
placement of bulk trash in the swale area for a reasonable time, which time is not to exceed forty-
eight (48) hours before the start of scheduled bulk trash collection. Empty receptacles shall be 
removed from the swale area not later than 11:00 p.m. the day of collection. 
(c) ?Any unauthorized accumulation of refuse on any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place or 
property, or upon any private property or abutting swale area within the city is hereby declared to be 
a public nuisance. 
(Code 1960, §§ 8-22, 8-23; Ord. No. O-86-2, § 3, 2-5-86; Ord. No. O-90-6, § 2, 3-21-90; Ord. 
No. O-2003-015, § 2, 11-19-03) 


Sec. 13-33. - Notice to remove. 
(a) ?If the chief code enforcement officer or his authorized agent, finds any violation of section 13-32 or 
any other applicable sections of the Code of Ordinances, he shall notify the record property owner of 
such violation in writing by posting notice on the property or by certified mail at the last known 
mailing address of the property owner that the violation shall be remedied within two (2) days of date 
of notice excluding Sunday and legal holidays. The notice shall further provide that in the event the 
property owner does not remove the refuse within the prescribed time, the city may remove or have 
the refuse removed and assess the actual cost thereof, including expenses, as a lien against the 
property. 
(b) ?If the mailing address of the owner is not known, and the property is unoccupied, and the owner has 
no agent in the city, the notice provided for above shall be posted upon the property as notice to the 
owner thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 8-24; Ord. No. O-86-2, § 4, 2-5-86; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 17, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-
94-4, § 2, 1-19-94; Ord. No. O-2001-022, § 2, 7-18-01; Ord. No. O-2014-004, § 3, 5-7-14) 


Sec. 13-34. - Hearing after notice to remove. 
(a) ?Within three (3) days after the mailing or other service of the notice provided for in section 13-33, 
the person to whom the notice was directed, or their duly authorized agent, may request a hearing 
before the special master for the purpose of showing that the violation complained of by the code 
enforcement officer does not in fact exist, or why such violation should not be remedied by the city at 
the expense of such person. 
(b) ?The hearing shall be held as soon as practicable after the filing of the request therefor, and the 
person to whom the notice is directed shall be advised of the time and place of the hearing at least 
five (5) days in advance thereof. At any such hearing, the city and the person to whom the notice has 
been directed may introduce such witnesses and evidence as is deemed necessary and proper by 
the code enforcement board. 
(Code 1960, § 8-25; Ord. No. O-86-2, § 5, 2-5-86; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 18, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-
94-4, § 3, 1-19-94) 


Sec. 13-35. - Removal by city—Generally. 
(a) ?If the violation described in the notice provided for in this article has not been remedied within three 
(3) days after the service thereof, or in the event that a request for a hearing is timely filed and the 
existence of the violation is affirmed, the chief code enforcement officer shall forthwith cause the 
violation to be remedied by the city at the expense of the property owner. 
(b) ?Costs to owner. If the city removes or causes the removal of refuse from property pursuant to this 
article, the actual cost thereof shall be billed to the owner by mail at his last known mailing address 
or at such other address indicated by the owner in responding to the notice authorized by this article. 
The bill shall state that the amount due must be paid within thirty (30) days of the billing date, which 
date shall be reflected on said bill. In the event that a water service account is maintained on the 
property, charges shall be added to the water account and shall be reflected on the bill. 
(Code 1960, § 8-26; Ord. No. O-86-2, § 6, 2-5-86; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 19, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-
94-4, § 4, 1-19-94) 


Sec. 13-36. - Same—Lien for expenses. 
(a) ?Such expense shall become and constitute a lien and charge upon such property which shall be 
payable, with interest at the rate of eight (8) percent per annum from the date of such certification 
until paid. Such expense and charge shall be a first and prior lien against such property, subject only 
to the lien for taxes due the county and state. 
(b) ?Upon failure of the owner of the property to pay the lien provided for above, it may be enforced with 
all applicable laws. 
(Code 1960, § 8-26; Ord. No. O-86-2, § 7, 2-5-86; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 20, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-
94-4, § 5, 1-19-94; Ord. No. O-96-3, § 13, 3-6-96; Ord. No. O-2014-004, § 3, 5-7-14) 


Sec. 13-37. - Finality of findings under article. 
(a) ?A finding of the chief code enforcement officer that a condition in violation of section 13-32 does, in 
fact, exist shall be final, except for the hearing provided for in section 13-34, and may be subject to 
review by any court. 
(b) ?Any finding of the code enforcement board under this article with reference to any property shall be 
final and conclusive. 
(Code 1960, § 8-27; Ord. No. O-86-2, § 10, 2-5-86; Ord. No. O-94-4, § 7, 1-19-94) 
Editor's note— Section 6 of Ord. No. O-94-4, adopted Jan. 19, 1994, repealed § 13-37 in its 
entirety. Formerly, § 13-37 pertained to hearing as to lien and derived from § 8-27 of the 1960 
Code and § 8 of Ord. No. O-86-2, adopted Feb. 5, 1986. Sections 7—9 of Ord. No. O-94-4 
renumbered §§ 13-39—13-41 as §§ 13-37—13-39 as herein set out. 


Sec. 13-38. - Penalty. 
(a) ?Recording and foreclosure of lien. In the event the owner shall fail or refuse to pay the full amount 
due for the removal of the refuse, following thirty (30) days from the date of the bill, a notice of lien in 
favor of the City of Oakland Park may be recorded in the Official Records of Broward County, 
Florida. The notice of lien shall contain a sworn statement showing the actual cost for the removal of 
the refuse, the date of removal and the legal description of the property against which the lien is 
assessed. The recordation of the notice of lien shall constitute a lien and privilege on the property 
and shall remain in full force and effect for the amount due in principal and interest, plus costs of 
court, if any, until final payment is made. The amount due shall bear interest at the legal rate 
beginning from the date of the assessment of the lien. The notice of lien, as recorded in the Official 
Records of Broward County, shall be prima facie evidence of the debt to the City of Oakland Park 
and may be foreclosed as mortgages are foreclosed in the circuit court. 
(b) ?A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs 
or continues. 
(Code 1960, § 8-29; Ord. No. O-86-2, § 11, 2-5-86; Ord. No. O-94-4, § 8, 1-19-94) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 13-37. 


Sec. 13-39. - Vacant or unimproved property; removal of refuse or other inappropriate obstruction 
required. 
(a) ?The owner of vacant or unimproved property within the city shall have the responsibility to ensure 
that his property remains free from any and all refuse or other inappropriate obstruction from said 
property and shall, within ten (10) days after receiving written notice from the city that the property is 
in violation of this section, remove any and all refuse or any other inappropriate obstruction from said 
property including the abutting swale area. The written notice mailed to said owner in accordance 
with the provisions of this section shall indicate that with notice and absent compliance by the owner 
with the provisions of section 13-41, the city shall have the right to enter upon the property and 
remove any and all refuse or inappropriate obstructions and/or mow such property not more than six 
(6) times per year. If the vacant or unimproved property has refuse or inappropriate obstructions, 
charges will be levied pursuant to subsection (d). 
(b) ?The city will mow or hire an independent contractor to mow vacant lots that are free of refuse and 
inappropriate obstructions up to six (6) times each calendar year. In addition, if said vegetative 
growth, regardless of the frequency of cutting, grows to a height of twelve (12) inches or more on 
vacant property, the city may mow or hire an independent contractor to mow the unobstructed 
growth and charge said work to the property owner. 
(1) ?The city may cause the mowing of vacant lots on a regularly scheduled basis so as to maintain 
the health and safety of neighboring property owners and property values. All costs and 
expenses incurred by the city for the mowing of vacant lots and/or removal of refuse, garbage 
and improperly graded landfill shall be charged to the property owner. The failure to pay the city 
all sums due upon receipt of an itemized statement, shall result in the matter being referred to 
the city code enforcement board for appropriate action. 
(2) ?If, in the event a lot cannot be mowed due to inappropriate obstructions, including refuse, 
garbage and improperly graded landfill, and after the property owner receives written notice to 
remove the inappropriate obstruction and fails to do so within ten (10) days of receiving the 
written notice, it shall be deemed a violation of the Code of Ordinances. 
(c) ?Notice, where required by the provisions of this section, may be accomplished by posting a notice 
stating the date of the posting and the time within which materials referred to shall be removed, and 
by mailing, postage prepaid, a copy of such notice to the last known address of such owner, agent or 
other person above described. 
(d) ?In the event any person required by the terms of this section to remove refuse, or other 
inappropriate obstruction shall fail to do so the same, the city may cause such removal to be done by 
a private contractor and shall forthwith charge all related expense necessary for such service to the 
legal owner of the property. If out of necessity, the city incurs expenses related to the required clean-
up by a private contractor, such costs shall be charged to the property owner. 
(e) ?Reserved. 
(f) ?Reserved. 
(g) ?Where there exists vacant property that has unique ecological fauna and flora within the environs of 
said property, the community development director or his designee will determine if said property 
shall be maintained pursuant to the terms of this section. 
(h) ?Upon issuance of a building permit by the city for the development of a tract of vacant unimproved 
land, the exemption referenced in subsection (g) shall be removed and the property shall be subject 
to all provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. O-84-5, § 1, 2-1-84; Ord. No. O-86-2, § 12, 2-5-86; Ord. No. O-86-3, § 1, 2-5-86; Ord. 
No. O-87-30, § 1, 9-16-87; Ord. No. O-90-17, § 21, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-91-16, § 2, 11-6-91; 
Ord. No. O-94-4, § 9, 1-19-94) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 13-37. 


Secs. 13-40—13-50. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL DISTRICT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-87-15, adopted Apr. 1, 1987, did not specifically amend this Code; hence 
inclusion of sections 2 and 3 as Art. III, §§ 13-51 and 13-52 was at the discretion of the editor. Broward 
County Ordinance Number 87-3 and the Interlocal Agreement are not set out herein but are available for 
inspection in the office of the city clerk. 


Sec. 13-51. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the definitions contained in the Interlocal Agreement shall apply 
unless otherwise specifically stated in this section. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in 
the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular and words in the 
singular number include the plural. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(a) ?Contract communities. The term "contract communities" shall refer to the municipal corporation 
or corporations existing under the laws of the State of Florida located within the county that from 
time to time enter into the Interlocal Agreement. 
(b) ?County. The word "county" shall refer to Broward County, Florida, a political subdivision of the 
State of Florida. 
(c) ?District. The word "district" shall refer to the Broward Solid Waste Disposal District created by 
the county pursuant to Ordinance Number 87-3. 
(d) ?Interlocal Agreement. The term "Interlocal Agreement" shall refer to that certain Interlocal 
Agreement, dated November 25, 1986, by and among the county and the contract communities, 
as amended or supplemented from time to time pursuant to the provisions of the Interlocal 
Agreement. 
(e) ?Resource recovery board. The term "resource recovery board" shall refer to the governing 
board of the special district. 
(Ord. No. O-87-15, § 2, 4-1-87) 


Sec. 13-52. - Approval of creation of district. 
(a) ?The creation of the district and the establishment of the resource recovery board as the governing 
board of the district and the terms and conditions of Ordinance Number 87-3, approved by the Board 
of County Commissioners on March 10, 1987, are hereby approved thereby evidencing the election 
of the City of Oakland Park, Florida, to become a member of the district. 
(b) ?The resource recovery board shall have such powers and rights as are granted to it pursuant to the 
Interlocal Agreement and Ordinance Number 87-3 adopted by the Board of County Commissioners 
on March 10, 1987. 
(Ord. No. O-87-15, § 3, 4-1-87) 


Secs. 13-53—13-60. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IV. - SOLID WASTE RESOURCE RECOVERY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-87-16, adopted Apr. 1, 1987, did not specifically amend this Code; hence
