OVERTIME PARKING (Curbside) 
(Ord. No. O-17-12, § 11, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-35. - Stopping, standing or parking prohibited in specified places. 
(a) ?No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other 
traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic control device, in or on any of the 
following places: 
(1) ?Any private alley, drive, driveway, parking area or other privately owned property without the 
consent of the owner of the property or person in charge thereof whether such property is used 
exclusively by the owner or for the use and convenience of customers or guests; 
(2) ?Other than on the righthand side of any two-way street; 
(3) ?On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
(4) ?On a sidewalk; 
(5) ?Within an intersection, or within twenty-five (25) feet of any part of said intersection; 
(6) ?On a crosswalk; 
(7) ?Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb 
immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless the division of road operations of the 
department of transportation indicates a different length by signs or markings; 
(8) ?Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing, or parking 
would obstruct traffic; 
(9) ?Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel; 
(10) ?On any railroad tracks; or 
(11) ?At any place where official signs prohibit stopping, standing or parking, or prohibits parking for 
a prescribed period of time. 
(b) ?In all areas of the city which are zoned so as to permit the operation of new and used car lots, it 
shall be unlawful for any person, as owner or operator of the lot, to park or display any automobiles, 
trucks, trailers, or other automotive equipment closer to the street or sidewalk than the established 
building setback line. 
(c) ?No person shall move a vehicle not owned by, or in charge of, such person into any such prohibited 
area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. 
(d) ?No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle within any area designated as a zone for emergency 
vehicles. 
(e) ?No person shall stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or 
discharge a passenger or passengers: 
(1) ?In front of a public or private driveway; 
(2) ?Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant; 
(3) ?Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; 
(4) ?Within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any flashing signal, stop sign or traffic control signal 
located at the side of a roadway; 
(5) ?Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street 
opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five (75) feet of said entrance (when 
property signposted); or 
(6) ?At any place where official signs prohibit standing. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 1, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-36. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
(a) ?The chief of police, with the approval of the city commission, is hereby authorized to erect signs 
indicating no parking upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property, when such parking 
would, in his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous condition. 
(b) ?When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon that side of a street adjacent to any 
school property, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated area. 
(Code 1960, § 19-94) 


Sec. 21-37. - Standing or parking on left side of one-way streets. 
    The chief of police, with the approval of the city commission, is authorized to erect signs upon the 
lefthand side of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles, and when such signs 
are in place, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon such lefthand side in violation of any such sign. 
(Code 1960, § 19-95) 


Sec. 21-38. - Standing or parking on one-way roadways. 
    In the event a street includes two (2) or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one (1) 
direction upon any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the lefthand side of such 
one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. The chief of police, with 
the approval of the city commission, is authorized to determine when standing or parking may be 
permitted upon the lefthand side of any such one-way roadway and to erect signs giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 19-96) 


Sec. 21-38.1. - Unattended motor vehicle. 
(a) ?No person shall leave a motor vehicle unattended with the ignition key in the vehicle. Enforcement 
personnel finding such a motor vehicle are authorized to remove such key from such vehicle and to 
post a notice in such vehicle stating where the key may be recovered. 
(b) ?The registered owner of a vehicle found in violation of this section shall be held prima facie 
responsible for any such violation. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 3, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-38.2. - All night parking prohibited. 
    No person, except physicians or other persons on emergency calls, shall park a vehicle on any street 
marked to prohibit all night parking for a period of time longer than thirty (30) minutes between the hours 
of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. of any day. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 6, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-38.3. - Parking not to obstruct traffic. 
    No person shall park any vehicle upon any paved portion of a street as defined by section 19-2 of the 
Code of Ordinances of the City of Oakland Park for any reason other than an emergency, mechanical 
failure of the vehicle or while performing utility maintenance or garbage removal, except on minor streets 
as defined in section 19-2, provided he shall not park in such a manner as to leave less than ten (10) feet 
of the width of the paved portion of the street for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and except as 
specifically permitted and marked by the city for parking. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 4, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-38.4. - Stopping, standing or parking in alleys. 
(a) ?No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in a business district, except for the 
expeditious loading or unloading of materials, and in no event for a period of more than twenty (20) 
minutes, and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any other alley in such a manner, or 
under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for the 
free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(b) ?No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the 
driveway or entrance to any abutting property. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 5, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-39. - Stopping, standing or parking near hazardous or congested places. 
(a) ?The chief of police, with the approval of the city commission, is hereby authorized to determine and 
designate by proper signs, places not exceeding one hundred (100) feet in length in which the 
stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would 
cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(b) ?When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized herein no person 
shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1960, § 19-97) 


Sec. 21-40. - Parking on private property without consent of owner. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in any private alley, drive, driveway, parking area 
or other privately owned property without the consent of the owner of the property, whether such property 
is used exclusively by the owner or for the use and convenience of customers or guests. 
(Code 1960, § 19-90) 


Sec. 21-41. - Parking of vehicles in car lots; observance of setback requirements. 
    In all areas of the city which are zoned so as to permit the operation of new and used car lots, it shall 
be unlawful for any person, as owner or operator of the lot, to park or display any automobiles, trucks, 
trailers or other automotive equipment, closer to the street or sidewalk than the established building 
setback line. The area between the street or sidewalk and the established building setback line shall not 
be paved or improved except for the purpose of ingress and egress to such car lot. 
(Code 1960, § 19-111) 


Sec. 21-42. - Handicapped parking; definitions, prohibitions. 
(a) ?The following words and phrases, when used in the following sections of this article shall have the 
meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context otherwise requires: 
(1) ?Designated parking space: Any parking space posted with an above grade sign with the 
caption "PARKING BY DISABLED PERMIT ONLY" or bearing the international symbol of 
accessibility or bearing both such symbol and caption. Such parking places shall be designed 
and located as follows: 
a. ?All spaces shall have accessible thereto a curb ramp or curb cut, when necessary to allow 
access to the building served, and shall be so located that users will not be compelled to 
wheel behind parked vehicles. 
b. ?Diagonal or perpendicular parking places shall be a minimum of twelve (12) feet wide. 
c. ?Parallel parking places shall be located at either the beginning or end of a block or adjacent 
to alley entrances. Curbs adjacent to such places shall be of a height which will not 
interfere with the opening and closing of motor vehicle doors. 
(2) ?Handicapped or disabled person. Severely physically disabled individuals who have permanent 
mobility problems that substantially impair their ability to ambulate and who have been issued 
an exemption entitlement parking permit. 
(3) ?Motor vehicle . Any vehicle which is self-propelled by any means whatsoever. 
(4) ?Public parking space . Any parking space on public or private property which the owner, lessee 
or person in control of such property provides for use by members of the public other than 
employees of such owner, lessee or person, including, but not limited to, parking spaces at 
shopping centers, stores, offices, motels, malls, restaurants and marinas. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park any motor vehicle or bicycle in any public 
parking space designated for the handicapped within Oakland Park, Florida, unless such person is a 
handicapped person as defined in this section or such vehicle displays a disabled parking permit. It 
shall further be unlawful for any person, whether a disabled vehicle owner, disabled passenger or 
person who owns a disabled parking permit, to obstruct the path of travel to a designated parking 
space, curb cut, curb ramp, or access aisle for disabled persons by standing or parking a vehicle 
within any such designated area. 
(c) ?Any person who is chauffeuring a disabled person shall be allowed, without need for an 
identification parking permit, momentary parking in any such parking space for the purpose of 
loading or unloading a disabled person. No penalty shall be imposed upon the driver for such 
momentary parking. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, §§ 24, 25, 8-17-77; Ord. No. O-85-31, § 1, 12-4-85; Ord. No. O-2004-014, § 
2, 6-2-04) 


Sec. 21-43. - Designation and use of loading zones. 
(a) ?The chief of police [the public safety director] with the approval of the city commission, is hereby 
authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and 
maintain appropriate signs indicating the same and stating the hours during which the provisions of 
this section are applicable. 
(b) ?No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time except for the 
expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading 
zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective, and then 
only for a period not to exceed five (5) minutes. 
(c) ?No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the 
expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a 
freight curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. In 
no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed thirty (30) minutes. 
(d) ?The driver of a vehicle may stop temporarily at a place marked as a freight curb loading zone for the 
purpose of, and while actually engaged in, loading or unloading passengers when such stopping 
does not interfere with any motor vehicle used for the transportation of materials which is waiting to 
enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1960, §§ 19-100—19-102; Ord. No. O-77-12, §§ 8, 9, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-44. - Designation and use of bus stops and taxicab stands. 
(a) ?The chief of police [the public safety director] with the approval of the city commission, is hereby 
authorized and required to establish bus stops and taxicab stands and stands for other passenger 
common-carrier motor vehicles on such public streets in such places and in such number as he shall 
determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every bus stop, taxicab 
stand or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
(b) ?No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab 
in a taxicab stand when such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, 
except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and 
while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere 
with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1960, §§ 19-28, 19-103, 19-104; Ord. No. O-77-12, § 13, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-45. - Buses and taxicabs parking in place other than bus stop or taxicab stand. 
    The operator of a bus or taxicab shall not stop, stand or park upon any street in any business district 
or any place other than at a bus stop or taxicab stand, respectively, except that this provision shall not 
prevent the operator of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping, 
standing or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the 
expeditious loading or unloading of passengers. 
(Code 1960, § 19-105; Ord. No. O-77-12, § 12, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-46. - Moving and impounding of vehicles. 
(a) ?Enforcement personnel are hereby authorized to cause to be removed and impounded a vehicle to 
the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or maintained by the police 
department or by the city, or to move or cause to be moved such vehicles, or to require the driver or 
person in charge of the vehicle to move the same to a position which would not be an obstruction or 
in violation of any ordinance, under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated: 
(1) ?When any vehicle is left unattended upon any street, bridge, causeway or viaduct, or in any 
subway or tunnel, where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic. 
(2) ?When a vehicle upon a street is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic, or the 
person in charge of the vehicle is, by reason of physical injury, incapacitated to such an extent 
as to be unable to provide for its custody and removal. 
(3) ?When a vehicle is found being operated upon the streets and is not in proper condition and 
there is no parking available for the owner or operator to store the vehicle until such time as he 
can arrange its safe removal. 
(4) ?When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street and is so parked illegally as to constitute a 
definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic. 
(5) ?When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street continuously for more than twenty-four (24) 
hours and may be presumed to be abandoned. 
(6) ?When the driver of such vehicle is taken into custody by the police department and such 
vehicle would thereby be left unattended upon a street. 
(7) ?When removal is necessary in the interest of public safety because of fire, flood, storm or other 
emergency reason. 
(b) ?Whenever enforcement personnel removes a vehicle from a street as authorized in this section, and 
the enforcement personnel know or is able to ascertain the name and address of the owner thereof, 
such enforcement personnel shall, as soon as practicable, give or cause to be given notice to such 
owner of the fact of such removal, and the reasons therefore, and of the place to which such vehicle 
has been removed. 
(c) ?Whenever enforcement personnel removes a vehicle from a street under this section, and does not 
know and is not able to ascertain the name of the owner, or for any other reason is unable to give the 
notice to the owner as hereinbefore provided, and in the event the vehicle is not returned to the 
owner within a period of ten (10) days, then and in that event the enforcement personnel shall 
immediately send or cause to be sent written report of such removal by mail to the motor vehicle 
commission, and shall file a copy of such notice with the proprietor of any authorized garage in which 
the vehicle may be stored. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle, the date, 
time and place from which removed, the reasons for such removal, and the name of the garage or 
place where the vehicle is stored. 
(d) ?The charges for towing or removal of any vehicle under this section and storage charges shall be 
fixed by the city commission, such charges to be based upon a computation of all actual expenses 
entering into the current cost of such services. Such charge shall be posted for public inspection in 
the police department of the city and in any authorized garage. 
(e) ?No vehicle impounded in an authorized garage as herein provided shall be released therefrom until 
the charges for towing such vehicle into the garage, and storage charges, have been paid. 
(Code 1960, §§ 19-99, 19-99.1; Ord. No. 2010-029, § 2, 10-20-10) 


Sec. 21-46.1. - Vehicle ownership. 
    With respect to any parking citations issued by the department of public safety for violation of 
Chapter 316, Florida Statutes, there shall be a presumption that the vehicle involved was operated or 
parked by the person in whose name such vehicle was registered on the date of the violation. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 23, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-46.2. - Fines, penalties and removal. 
(a) ?Violation of parking regulations shall be punishable by a fine of ten dollars ($10.00) if paid within ten 
(10) calendar days, and twenty dollars ($20.00) if paid after ten (10) days but prior to initiation of 
prosecution in county court, except as provided in subsection (d) herein. Failure to pay such fines or 
any other violation of the parking regulations shall be punishable as provided by law. 
(b) ?Any unattended vehicle creating a traffic hazard or found in a restricted parking zone as set forth in 
section 21-34.2 may, in addition to the fines provided herein, be removed and the expense of said 
removal be charged to the owner of the vehicle. 
(c) ?Violations of parking regulations in designated handicapped parking spaces shall be punishable by 
the maximum fine as allowed by state law. 
(d) ?Violations of parking regulations on public or private property in a space which has been designated 
as a fire zone or fire lane shall be punishable by a fine of fifteen dollars ($15.00) if paid within ten 
(10) calendar days, and thirty dollars ($30.00) if paid after ten (10) days but prior to initiation of 
prosecution in county court. Failure to pay such fine or any other violation of the parking regulations 
shall be punishable as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 21, 8-17-77; Ord. No. O-85-31, § 2, 12-4-85; Ord. No. O-88-11, § 1, 5-18-
88) 


Sec. 21-46.3. - Appeal. 
(a) ?Anyone wishing to contest the notice of violation may appeal to the public safety director as follows: 
(1) ?For defective meter: By mailing the notice of violation to the City of Oakland Park, Public Safety 
Department, 3650 N. E. 12th Avenue, Oakland Park, Florida, 33334; with a notation of the type 
of defect encountered. If upon inspection by the division, the meter is found not to be defective, 
the violator will be noticed of the fact and given further opportunity to pay the fine or appeal. 
(2) ?For any other violation: By requesting an administrative hearing before a hearing officer 
designated by the director of public safety within ten (10) days from the date of the notice of 
violation. Such appeal should state the number of the notice of violation and the date issued. 
Appeals under this section shall be heard within thirty (30) days and decided within thirty (30) 
days thereafter. 
(3) ?Fines must be paid within ten (10) days after written notice of the determination is mailed, to 
the appellant, and said notice shall so indicate thereon. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 22, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-46.4. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five 
hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in the county jail for a term not to exceed sixty (60) days, or 
by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 26, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-47. - Administrative hearing board. 
(a) ?Created; membership . The administrative hearing board is hereby created, consisting of three (3) 
members. The membership of the board shall include one (1) representative appointed from the 
city's public safety department, one (1) representative appointed from the city manager's office, and 
one (1) member of the general public who is a registered voter of the city and who shall be appointed 
to the board by a majority vote of the city commission. 
(b) ?Qualifications of members . Members of the board shall be qualified members appointed by their 
respective departments or the city commission, who possess outstanding reputations for integrity 
and responsibility in order to fairly and efficiently enforce the municipal regulations of the City of 
Oakland Park. 
(c) ?Terms of office . All members of the board shall serve at the will of the respective department or the 
city commission that appointed that particular member to the board. 
(d) ?Organization; operation of board. 
(1) ?The members of the board shall elect a chairman, a vice chairman, and a secretary, who shall 
serve the board. 
(2) ?Two (2) members of the board shall constitute a quorum necessary to hold a meeting or take 
any action. 
(3) ?A majority vote of the board membership present and voting at a duly constituted meeting shall 
be sufficient to overrule or modify any actions or decisions of a member of the public safety 
department relative to the issuance of a municipal parking ticket, action taken on false alarms or 
to take any other action within the scope of the powers and duties of the board. 
(4) ?Members shall serve with no compensation; however, they shall be entitled to reimbursement 
and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their professional duties, on approval 
by the city commission. 
(5) ?No member of the board shall sit as a voting member in any hearing on a matter in which he 
has a personal or financial interest. 
(6) ?The chairman or vice chairman may call meetings of the board, and the meetings may be 
called by written notice signed by two (2) members of the board. 
(7) ?Minutes and records shall be kept of all meetings of the board, and all meetings shall be public. 
(8) ?All hearings shall be open to the public, and any person whose interest may be affected by the 
board determination shall be given the opportunity to be heard in person or through his attorney. 
(9) ?Witnesses may be sworn and subpoenaed by the board in a like manner as they are 
subpoenaed by the court or courts in the county in which this Code is adopted. 
(10) ?The hearing shall be informal and need not be conducted according to technical rules relating 
to evidence and witnesses. Any relevant evidence shall be admitted if it is the type of evidence 
on which responsible persons are accustomed to rely in the conduct of serious affairs, 
regardless of the existence of any common law or statutory rules which might make improper 
the admission of such evidence over objections in civil actions. 
(11) ?The rules of privilege shall be effective to the same extent that they are now or hereafter may 
be recognized in civil actions, and irrelevant and unduly repetitious evidence shall be excluded. 
(12) ?The board may establish rules and regulations for its own procedure. 
(e) ?Duties and powers of the board . The board shall have the following duties, functions, powers and 
responsibilities: 
(1) ?Hear and review actions concerning the issuance of municipal parking violations by the city's 
public safety department; 
(2) ?Affirm, modify or reverse any decision of the public safety official relative to the issuance of a 
municipal parking ticket upon application for review; 
(3) ?Hear and review actions concerning the issuance of citations by the city's public safety 
department relative to false alarms; 
(4) ?Hear and review actions relative to revocation of alarm permits; 
(5) ?Hear and review other matters assigned by ordinance of the city; 
(6) ?The board will, through its secretary, keep a record of all exhibits, instruments, papers and 
transcripts of its proceedings; 
(7) ?Revoke permits issued by the city for the operation and maintenance of an alarm system. 
(f) ?Appeals . An aggrieved party may appeal a final administrative order of the board to the County 
Court of the Seventeenth Judicial Circuit in Broward County, Florida. 
(Ord. No. O-88-31, § 2, 9-21-88; Ord. No. O-89-27, § 2, 12-20-89) 


Sec. 21-48. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - PARKING METERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-77-12, §§ 14—20, adopted Aug. 8, 1977, did not specifically amend the 
Code, hence codification herein as Div. 2, §§ 21-49—21-55, is at the editor's discretion. 


Sec. 21-49. - Authority of public safety director to install, operate and maintain parking meters. 
(a) ?The public safety director is hereby authorized to install or have installed sufficient parking meters in 
such parking meter zones as now exist or may from time to time be authorized by resolution of the 
city commission of the City of Oakland Park, Florida. Such parking meters shall be placed upon the 
curb alongside of or next to individual parking places to be designated as hereinafter provided. Each 
parking meter shall be so set as to show for display a signal that the parking space assigned to it is, 
or is not, in use. 
(b) ?The public works director shall provide for the installation, regulation, control, operation and use of 
the parking meters provided for herein and shall see to it that such meters are maintained in good 
workable condition. Each parking meter shall be so set as to display a signal indicating the amount of 
time for which parking is allowed upon the deposit of a coin of the United States of America. 
    Each meter shall when properly set as hereinafter provided for, continue in operation from the 
time of depositing such coin until the expiration of the period fixed herein as the parking limits for the 
part of the parking meter zone upon which such meter is placed. Each parking meter shall also be so 
arranged that upon the expiration of such parking limits it will indicate by mechanical operation and 
proper signal that the lawful parking periods have expired. 
(c) ?The public works director shall determine whether additional parking meter zones upon the streets, 
boulevards and avenues of this city are needed or whether existing meters may be removed, as may 
be required from time to time with the approval of the city commission of the City of Oakland Park. 
Parking meters for additional parking meter zones shall be installed, as provided in this section, after 
purchase approved by the city commission. 
(d) ?The public works director shall from time to time recommend to the city commission for the City of 
Oakland Park, Florida the removal of parking meters and the substitution of an attendant cashier to 
collect charges for parking on city-owned or -operated parking lots. Upon enactment of an 
appropriate ordinance by the city commission of the City of Oakland Park, parking meters may be 
removed and an attendant-cashier parking system substituted therefor under such conditions as set 
out in said ordinance. 
(e) ?Parking rates shall be set by resolution of the city commission of the City of Oakland Park. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 14, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-50. - Overtime parking. 
(a) ?When any vehicle is parked in any space alongside of, next to, or in front of which is located a 
parking meter, the owner, operator, manager or driver of such vehicle shall, upon entering the 
parking space, immediately deposit the proper coin in the parking meter alongside of, next to, or in 
front of the parking space, and shall set the meter in accordance with the instructions contained 
thereon. The parking space may then be used by such vehicle during the parking limits provided 
herein. If the vehicle shall remain parked in such parking space beyond the period allowed for the 
deposit of such coin, the parking meter shall display a sign indicating illegal parking, and in that 
event such vehicle shall be considered parked overtime. The parking of a vehicle overtime in any 
such part of a street where any such meter is located shall be a violation of this section. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his 
name, or under his control, to be parked overtime or beyond the lawful periods of time as above set 
forth. 
(c) ?It shall be the duty of the public safety director, the public works director or their designated 
representatives to enforce the provisions of this section and to issue notice of violations for all 
violations. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 15, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-51. - Presumption of overtime parking and ownership of vehicle. 
(a) ?The fact that the time device on any parking meter is not in operation shall be presumptive evidence 
that the person who parked the vehicle then found standing in the parking space adjacent to such 
meter failed to deposit a coin as required therein, or has permitted his vehicle to remain in such 
parking space for a period of time greater than that permitted for the coin deposited. The indication 
by such meter of illegal parking shall be presumptive evidence of overtime parking. 
(b) ?Any parking violation under this section shall raise the presumption that the vehicle involved was 
operated by the person in whose name such vehicle was registered. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 16, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-52. - Time limit and rate for curb parking meters. 
(a) ?Each curb parking meter shall contain a legend showing the type of coin to be deposited, the 
parking time allowed for each coin so deposited and the hours during which a coin must be 
deposited. 
(b) ?The operator using such space shall immediately deposit such coin upon parking in the designated 
area. In case of violation it shall be the duty of enforcement personnel to take the number of the 
parking meter and the state vehicle tag number and report such violation. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 17, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-53. - Use of slugs, etc., in meters. 
    No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slug, device or substitute 
for a coin of the United States of America. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 18, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-54. - Injuring or tampering with meters. 
    No person shall deface, injure, tamper with, break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking 
meter installed under the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 19, 8-17-77) 


Sec. 21-55. - Disposition of funds derived from meters. 
    The coins required to be deposited in parking meters as provided herein are hereby levied and 
assessed as fees for the sole purpose of providing for the cost of proper supervision and regulation of 
parking vehicles in the parking meter zones, and to cover the cost of purchase, supervision, protection, 
installation, operation, maintenance, control and use of parking meters described herein, and repairs and 
painting of signs on streets adjacent thereto. All monies so received shall be used to pay cost of operation 
and supervision, with any balance to be paid into the general fund, as appropriate. 
(Ord. No. O-77-12, § 20, 8-17-77) 


Secs. - 21-56, 21-57. Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - BICYCLES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate operation of bicycles, § 316.008(1)(h), Fla. Stats.; 
bicycle regulations, § 316.2065, Fla. Stats. 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Sec. 21-58. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "bicycle" shall mean and include every device propelled by 
human power upon which any person may ride, having two (2) tandem wheels either of which is over 
sixteen (16) inches in diameter, and including any device generally recognized as a bicycle though 
equipped with two (2) or more front or two (2) or more rear wheels. The word "owner," as used in this 
article, shall be held to include minors who have the use and control of a bicycle with the knowledge and 
consent of their parents or guardians. 
(Code 1960, § 19-156) 


Sec. 21-59. - Dealers to file reports. 
    Every person engaged in the business of buying or selling new or secondhand bicycles shall make a 
weekly report to the chief of police of every bicycle purchased or sold by such dealer, giving the name 
and address of the person from whom purchased, or to whom sold, a description of such bicycle by name 
or make, the frame number thereof, and the number of license plate, if any, found thereon. 
(Code 1960, § 19-169) 


Sec. 21-60. - Inspection by police. 
    Every bicycle operated upon the streets and public highways of the city shall be subject to inspection 
by the police department at any time to ascertain serial numbers, license plate numbers and other 
identification marks. 
(Code 1960, § 19-166) 


Sec. 21-61. - Parking. 
    No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb or in a 
rack to support the bicycle, or at the curb, in such a manner as to afford the least obstruction to 
pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1960, § 19-178) 


Sec. 21-62. - Selling, buying, etc., when serial number destroyed, removed, altered, etc. 
(a) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any bicycle with knowledge that the 
manufacturer's serial number for such bicycle has been destroyed, removed, covered, altered or 
defaced. 
(b) ?It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly buy, sell, receive, dispose of, conceal or have in his 
possession, any bicycle from which the manufacturer's serial number or any other distinguishing 
number or identification mark has been removed, covered, altered or destroyed for the purpose of 
concealment or misrepresenting the identification of such bicycle. 
(Ord. No. 560, §§ 1, 2, 12-1-71) 


Sec. 21-63. - Report to police when serial number destroyed, removed, altered, etc. 
    Every person to whom any bicycle is offered for sale, storage or dismantling, from which the 
manufacturer's serial number or the registration number has been destroyed, removed, defaced or 
otherwise mutilated or altered, shall immediately notify the police department of all pertinent facts and 
circumstances within such person's knowledge. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 3, 12-1-71) 


Sec. 21-64. - Parents and guardians not to authorize or permit violations of article. 
    The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any 
such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1960, § 19-181) 


Secs. 21-65—21-67. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 


Sec. 21-68. - Required. 
    No person who resides within this city shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street or upon any public 
path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, unless such bicycle is currently licensed in accord with 
this division. 
(Code 1960, § 19-161) 


Sec. 21-69. - Application. 
    Application for a license for a bicycle shall be filed by the resident owner of the bicycle, within ten 
(10) days after he acquires the bicycle or brings it into the city. 
(Code 1960, §§ 19-158, 19-159) 


Sec. 21-70. - Fee. 
    The police department is hereby authorized and directed to charge a fee of one dollar ($1.00) for the 
licensing of each bicycle. All such fees shall be delivered or paid to the city clerk to be deposited to the 
general fund of the city. 
(Code 1960, § 19-157) 


Sec. 21-71. - Inspection of bicycle before issuance. 
    The chief of police, or any officer assigned such responsibility, shall inspect each bicycle before 
licensing the same and shall refuse a license for any bicycle which he determines is in an unsafe 
mechanical condition. 
(Code 1960, § 19-166) 


Sec. 21-72. - Issuance. 
    The chief of police, or any officer assigned such responsibility, upon receiving proper application 
therefor, is authorized to issue a bicycle license. Such officer shall not issue a license for any bicycle 
when he knows or has reasonable grounds to believe that the applicant is not the owner of or entitled to 
the possession of such bicycle. 
(Code 1960, § 19-162) 


Sec. 21-73. - License plate. 
(a) ?The chief of police, or any officer assigned such responsibility, upon issuing a bicycle license shall 
also issue a license plate bearing the license number assigned to the bicycle and the name of the 
city. No bicycle shall be ridden in the city, unless such license plate is attached thereto. 
(b) ?No person shall remove a license plate from a bicycle during the period for which issued, except 
upon a transfer of ownership or in the event the bicycle is dismantled and no longer operated upon 
any street in this city. 
(c) ?In the event a bicycle license plate is lost, it will be necessary for the owner to apply as for a 
renewal. 
(d) ?Upon the sale or other transfer of a licensed bicycle, the licensee shall remove the license plate and 
shall either surrender the same to the chief of police or may, upon proper application but without 
payment of additional fee, have such plate assigned to another bicycle owned by the applicant. 
(Code 1960, §§ 19-158, 19-164, 19-165, 19-167) 


Sec. 21-74. - Expiration and renewal. 
    The initial license issued under this article shall expire on the first day of October next following the 
date of issuance. Such license shall be renewed, within sixty (60) days prior to its expiration, by payment 
of a fee of one dollar ($1.00), which renewal license shall be valid for two (2) years. 
(Code 1960, §§ 19-158, 19-162) 


Sec. 21-75. - Suspension. 
    The chief of police shall have authority to suspend the license of, and remove the registration plate 
from, any bicycle operated contrary to the provisions of this article or state law. Such suspension and 
removal shall continue for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days. 
(Code 1960, § 19-160) 


Sec. 21-76. - Compliance with division by rental agencies. 
    A rental agency shall not rent or offer any bicycle for rent unless the bicycle is licensed and a license 
plate is attached thereto as provided in this division. 
(Code 1960, § 19-168) 


Sec. 21-77. - Records to be kept. 
    The chief of police shall keep a record of the number of each bicycle license, the date issued, the 
name and address of the person to whom issued, the number on the frame of the bicycle for which 
issued, and a record of all bicycle license fees collected by him. 
(Code 1960, § 19-163)

the city and each consumer of or applicant for water supply from the city. 
(Code 1960, § 20-1)

(a) ?All plumbing from the water meter or street line inward shall be done by the owner of the property or

Sec. 22-8.1. - Purchased Water Pass Through Adjustment (PWPTA). 
(1) ?The PWPTA is a volumetric charge based on the cost of water purchased by the city from the City 
of Fort Lauderdale or any other wholesale supplier. The pass-through charge will be applied to all 
billable potable water consumption. 
(2) ?Determination of charge. The city shall calculate the pass-through adjustment and implement any 
changes in the charge consistent with the effective date of any change in the cost of purchased 
water as billed by the city from the City of Fort Lauderdale or any other wholesale water supplier. 
The city may implement the pass-through charge during any portion of the fiscal year as a result of 
material events, which may affect the financial condition of the utility system. Such material events 
may include, but not be limited to: (i) a rate adjustment enacted by the City of Fort Lauderdale or any 
other wholesale water supplier; (ii) implementation of an unforeseen surcharge or additional billing 
adjustment by the City of Fort Lauderdale or any other wholesale supplier. 
(3) ?The PWPTA shall be calculated in accordance with the following formula: 
PWPTA = ((BC × M) + (UC × BU)) × (1+T) / WS 
PWPTA 
= 
The purchased water pass-through charge expressed on a dollars per thousand gallons basis 
which is to be added to each water consumption block or usage charge that is currently in 
effect as of the date of the pass-through application. 
BC 
= 
The per unit change in any base costs or charges that are billed by any wholesale water 
supplier to the city through a large user or similar agreement that is not based on metered 
water consumption measured at the point of delivery between the wholesale water supplier 
and the city. 
M 
= 
The number of months in the fiscal year — (12). 
UC 
= 
The per unit change in any usage or volumetric charges that are billed by any wholesale 
water supplier to the city through a large user or similar agreement that is based on metered 
water consumption measured at the point of delivery between the wholesale water supplier 
and the city. 
BU 
= 
The actual billed water usage (consumption) as invoiced by the respective wholesale water 
supplier to the city which is increasing the usage or volumetric rates for service that occurred 
during the city's most recently completed fiscal year expressed in thousands of gallons. 
T 
= 
Any applicable taxes or surcharges which may be imposed upon the city from time to time by 
jurisdictions having regulatory authority which are directly related to the purchases of water 
from the wholesale water suppliers providing potable water to the city on a sales-for-resale 
basis. 
WS 
= 
The actual billed water sales as metered by the city to all classes of customers or users during 
the city's most recently completed fiscal year expressed in thousands of gallons. 
 
(e) ?Where in the judgment of the city manager or designee it appears that the amount of such deposit is 
not sufficient, the city manager may, using his or her discretion, require a deposit equal to twice the 
amount of the largest actual or reasonably anticipated monthly or quarterly bill (however the account 
is billed). 
(Ord. No. O-2009-027, § 2, 11-18-09; Ord. No. O-2010-015, § 3, 5-5-10) 


Sec. 22-8.2. - Annual Consumer Price Index (CPI) adjustment. 
(1) ?The city will adjust rates every year beginning October, 1 2013 (beginning of fiscal year 2014). The 
annual rate index adjustment should be based on: i) the percentage change in the Consumer Price 
Index for all Urban Areas (CPI-U) as published by the United States Department of Labor from July 1 
of the preceding calendar year until June 30 of the current calendar year applied to the level of 
operating expenses as generally defined by commonly accepted accounting principles for the most 
recently completed fiscal year, divided by ii) the total sales revenues from monthly water and sewer 
rates for the most recently completed fiscal year, exclusive of wholesale water and wastewater 
purchases incurred during such fiscal year. 
(2) ?Calculations will be completed by applying the prior fiscal year operating expenses less actual cost 
of purchased water and wastewater equals the "Net Operating Expenses." The Net Operating 
Expenses times the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index for all Urban Areas as 
published by the United States Department of Labor from July 1 of the preceding calendar year until 
June 30 of the current calendar year ("CPI-U") equals the "Index Adjustment Amount." The Index 
Adjustment Amount divided by the prior fiscal year revenues from the sum of the monthly base 
charges and the consumption charges equals the "Price Index Rate Adjustment" (rounded and 
carried to the 1/100 place) to be applied to the applicable water and wastewater monthly user 
charges. The annual index rate adjustment is calculated as follows: 
Fiscal Year Operating Expenses - Cost of Water and Wastewater Purchased = Net Operating 
Expenses 
(Net Operating Expenses) × (CPI-U) = Index Adjustment Amount 
Index Adjustment Amount  
 
Prior Fiscal Year Revenue From Monthly User Charges 
= 
Price Index  
Rate Adjustment 
 
(Ord. No. O-2009-027, § 2, 11-18-09)

Sec. 22-11. - Safe and convenient access to water meters. 
    Tenants, lessees, occupant or owners of premises shall provide safe and convenient access to water 
meters. The area around meter boxes shall be maintained such that meter boxes will at all times be 
readily visible and accessible for reading and servicing without requiring crawling and other extraordinary 
efforts to gain access. All vicious animals shall be confined such that they provide no threat of attack 
when meters are to be read or serviced. 
(1) ?Access to water meter must be maintained so as to provide unobstructed access to city 
employees. Any obstruction due to trees, shrubs, debris, dirt, etc. will be removed by account 
holder. If the city removes obstructions, after notice to the account holder, actual city costs will 
be billed to the account holder on his/her next monthly utility bill. 
(Code 1960, § 20-7; Ord. No. O-74-8, § 2, 5-15-74; Ord. No. O-2003-013, § 2, 11-19-03; Ord. 
No. O-2010-015, § 4 5-5-10) 


Sec. 22-12. - Water service, establishment and discontinuance of service, invoicing and delinquency. 
(a) ?A request for commencement, transfer or termination of water service by the customer requires 
proof of being either an owner of, or tenant at, the service location. 
(b) ?Bills are due when rendered and shall be considered as received by the customer when delivered or 
mailed to the water and sewer service address or such other address as provided in writing by 
customer. Non-receipt of bills by customer shall not release or diminish obligation of customer with 
respect to payment thereof, unless the customer's bills have been returned to the city for incorrect 
addresses. Each invoice shall become delinquent if payment is not received in utility and billing 
services division within twenty-five (25) days after the invoice date. All fees, excluding penalties, that 
remain unpaid at the end of twenty-five (25) days from the invoice date shall be subject to a penalty 
of one and one-half (1.50) percent. If the bill is not paid within forty (40) days of the invoice date, the 
furnishing of water to the delinquent account shall be suspended. When an account remains in 
arrears ninety (90) days from the invoice date, the account will be closed and the existing deposit 
applied to the arrears. Any account holder whose account becomes delinquent shall be subject to all 
laws, federal, state, and local, allowing for the collection of the full amount of the delinquent account 
plus all costs and fees associated with the city's collection efforts. However, nothing contained herein 
shall limit the city's authority to approve "payment plans" for the extended payment of water charges, 
so long as such extended terms are both reasonable and appropriate, in the sole discretion of the 
city, and are based upon customer hardship. 
(c) ?Fees for requests for account history printouts shall be in accordance with section 2-13. 
(d) ?Application of customer payments. When a customer of the city's utilities systems has a combined 
utilities services billing, customer payments will be applied sequentially to water tax, penalties, 
stormwater, solid waste, sewer, other possible services and lastly water. 
(e) ?To re-establish water service after having service suspended due to delinquency, all delinquent 
amounts, fees and deposits as described below for all delinquent accounts (water, sewer, solid 
waste and stormwater) must be paid in full in advance. Upon payment of all required amounts, water 
service will be restored as soon as possible the same or next business day, or, if not possible during 
normal working hours, after normal working hours if the customer elects to pay the after-hours fee 
described below. Required payment amounts include: 
(1) ?All delinquent amounts, including penalties and interest as applicable, on all delinquent 
accounts, including water, sewer, solid waste and stormwater. 
(2) ?The water turn-on fee of forty dollars ($40.00) and an additional one hundred dollars ($100.00) 
if an employee must be called in after hours. 
(3) ?The fee to restore solid waste service, if applicable, as described in chapter 13. 
(4) ?When service has been disconnected at the water main by the city, an additional fee equal to 
the meter size tap and set fee, as described in section 22-5, shall be charged. 
(5) ?The water service deposit, as described in section 22-8, and solid waste service deposit, if 
applicable and as described in chapter 13, shall be restored to required levels if these deposits 
were previously applied against delinquent accounts. 
(f) ?In the event the account holder is also the property owner and shall fail to pay the full amount due, 
following ninety (90) days from the invoice date a notice of lien in favor of the City of Oakland Park 
may be recorded in the Official Records of Broward County, Florida. The notice of lien shall contain a 
sworn statement showing the amount and date of said invoice and the legal description of the 
property against which the lien is assessed. The recordation of the notice of lien shall constitute a 
lien and privilege on the property and shall remain in full force and effect for the amount due in 
principal, interest, and penalties, plus costs of court, if any, until final payment is made. The amount 
due shall bear interest at the legal rate beginning from the date of the assessment of the lien. The 
notice of lien, as recorded in the Official Records of Broward County, shall be prima facie evidence of 
the debt to the City of Oakland Park and may be foreclosed as mortgages are foreclosed in the 
circuit court. 
(g) ?As described in chapter 15, sewer fees are in part based on water consumption. In instances of 
leaks where the lost water does not enter the sewer system and when pools are filled, adjustment to 
sewer fees may be authorized as described below and in section 15-4.5. 
(1) ?Should water consumption of an unusually large volume be recorded by an accurate meter, 
which consumption is the result of a leak in the consumer's water system, and such 
consumption results in a loss of water which does not enter the sewer system, the director or 
designee, upon receipt of a sworn affidavit from the customer stating that the water did not enter 
the sewer system and a sworn affidavit from a licensed plumber that a leak in the customer's 
water system has been repaired, may authorize reducing sewer fees by the amount determined 
by the city to be attributable to the leak. 
a. ?Adjustments shall retroactively apply back to December 1, 2009, on the water portion of the 
utility bill, once the repair is completed following the required affidavits as stated above are 
met. Adjustments will be made based on the customer's previous six-month average water 
consumption (if available) applicable block rate charge in relation to the billed amount of 
water consumption to which the adjustment may be applied, following approval of the 
director or designee. 
(2) ?When a signed statement by a contractor having a valid business tax receipt or by a property 
owner is provided to the city giving the dimensions and volume in gallons of a pool that has 
been filled and the amount of water added to the pool, the water consumption rate attributable 
to filling the pool shall be the upper block rate consistent with the customer's prior six (6) 
months average monthly consumption, providing more than seventy-five (75) percent of the 
water is replaced. Only one adjustment may be made in any twelve-month period. 
(h) ?Collection fee. In the event the city sends a delinquent account to a collection agency for collection, 
a collection fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be added to the account. 
(Code 1960, §§ 8-20.4, 20-8; Ord. No. O-74-8, § 3, 5-15-74; Ord. No. O-83-19, § 5, 8-17-83; 
Ord. No. O-84-26, § 5, 11-7-84; Ord. No. O-85-2, § 2, 1-16-85; Ord. No. O-88-26, § 4, 9-21-88; 
Ord. No. O-90-15, § 6, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-92-10, § 4, 4-15-92; Ord. No. O-1999-016, § 2, 9-1-
99; Ord. No. O-2003-013, § 2, 11-19-03; Ord. No. O-2009-027, § 2, 11-18-09; Ord. No. O-2010-
015, § 5, 5-5-10) 


Sec. 22-13. - Testing meters; adjusting bills; account history; meter reading by appointment. 
(a) ?All water meters shall be carefully tested before they are installed. Should any customer question 
the accuracy of the water meter through which service is provided, the customer may request that 
the meter be removed and tested. The fee for testing each meter includes testing it in the presence 
of the customer or his duly authorized agent if requested by the customer and is as follows: 
Meter Size

If the test shows that the meter has been over-registering more than two (2) percent, the fee shall be not

Sec. 22-15. - Right of entry of water department employees. 
    Any duly authorized employee or officer of the water department shall have the right to enter the 
premises of water consumers at any reasonable time for the purpose of reading meters or examining the 
pipes and fixtures. 
(Code 1960, § 20-10) 


Sec. 22-16. - Right of city to cut off water for alterations or repairs; city not liable for bursting of pipes or 
failure of supply. 
    The city, in the operation of supplying water, reserves the right to shut off the water temporarily 
whenever necessary for the purpose of making alterations or repairs. It is expressly stipulated by and 
between the city and the consumers of water that no claim shall be made against the city for or on 
account of the bursting of any main or service pipe, or on account of accidental failure of the water 
supply. 
(Code 1960, § 20-11) 


Sec. 22-17. - Unauthorized use or tampering. 
(a) ?Any unauthorized use of or tampering with any component of the city water system may result in 
water service suspension, a penalty of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and/or arrest. 
(b) ?Damage by unauthorized use or tampering to any component of the city water system shall be the 
responsibility of the account holder. The city will repair these components, and actual costs shall be 
billed to the account holder. 
(Ord. No. O-88-26, § 6, 9-21-88; Ord. No. O-92-10, § 5, 4-15-92; Ord. No. O-2003-013, § 2, 11-
19-03) 


Sec. 22-18. - Backflow prevention and cross-connection control. 
(a) ?Definitions . Unless otherwise defined herein, the following terms are defined in the American Water 
Works Association manual "Backflow Prevention and Cross-Connection Control," (AWWA M14) and

(b) ?Backflow-prevention assembly(s) required. 
(1) ?Approved backflow-prevention assemblies are required to be installed on all connections to the 
public potable water system. The effective date(s) of enforcement are established as: 
a. ?Commercial/industrial (new work); concurrent with building permit or plumbing permit prior 
to certificate of occupancy. 
b. ?Commercial/industrial (retrofit); concurrent with any change in use or occupancy but not 
later than October 1, 1993. 
c. ?Fire suppression systems (new work); concurrent with plumbing permit. 
d. ?Fire suppression systems (retrofit); not later than October 1, 1994. 
e. ?Residential—Single-family and all multifamily (new work); concurrent with building permit or 
plumbing permit prior to certificate of occupancy. 
f. ?Residential—Multifamily greater than three (3) stories (retrofit); not later than October 1, 
1994. 
g. ?Residential—Single-family and multifamily three (3) stories or less (retrofit); concurrent with 
application for physical connection or reconnection of water service. 
(2) ?Water service will not be installed, connected, reconnected or maintained by the city to any 
premises unless the water supply is protected as required by the provisions of this section, or as 
may be required by state laws and regulations. 
(3) ?Water service shall be discontinued by the city to any premises if a backflow-prevention 
assembly required by this section is not installed, tested and maintained, or if it is found that a 
backflow-prevention assembly has been removed or bypassed, or if an unprotected cross-
connection exists on the premises. Water service shall not be restored until such conditions or 
defects are corrected. 
(c) ?Type of backflow-prevention assembly required. The type of backflow-prevention assembly required 
for a specific installation shall depend upon the degree of hazard or potential hazard which may exist 
as determined by the city's director or plumbing inspector. The following are typical but shall not be 
limited to: 
(1) ?Commercial/industrial: Reduced-pressure principle assembly. 
(2) ?Fire suppression systems: Detector, double-check valve assembly. 
(3) ?Residential, multifamily: Double-check valve assembly. 
(4) ?Residential, individually metered: Dual-check valve assembly. 
(d) ?Access to customers' premises. The customers' premises shall be open at all reasonable times to 
authorized representatives of the city's director or building departments for the inspection of 
backflow-prevention assembly(s) or to determine the existence of cross-connections or other 
plumbing hazards, including violations of these regulations. 
(e) ?Installation, testing and maintenance. 
(1) ?Installation, repair or replacement of backflow-prevention assemblies shall be performed only 
by persons licensed and certified to perform such work and shall require a plumbing permit 
issued by the city's building department. Annual testing and recertification of backflow devices 
shall be performed by certified backflow prevention device technicians who have registered with 
the City of Oakland Park and have provided the required, current licenses and insurance. 
(2) ?The backflow-prevention device technician shall make certified reports of such work to the 
customer and the building department. Recertification forms will prominently display the serial 
number of the device being tested, the device type, size, test performed, test result and location 
as well as the meter number of the water supply. These forms are to be submitted to the 
building department with an administrative fee of forty dollars ($40.00) for each device being 
recertified. 
(3) ?Each backflow-prevention assembly, except as exempted in subsection (f)(2) shall be 
inspected and tested annually. The inspection and test shall be the property owner's 
responsibility and at his expense. Recertification is due on the anniversary of the last approved 
test date. Failure to have backflow devices recertified by the due date will result in a late fee of 
ten dollars ($10.00) for each week or part thereof that recertification is overdue up to a 
maximum of thirty dollars ($30.00). If three weeks passes and device is still not recertified, the 
utilities department will be instructed to have the water service discontinued until such time as 
the backflow device has been recertified and all fees have been paid. Code enforcement will be 
instructed to issue a notice of violation to the party responsible for the management of the 
property. 
(f) ?Residential service . For the purpose of this subsection, residential service is defined as: Individually 
metered water service to any single-family home served by a 5/8 - to ¾-inch or a 1-inch metered 
service; individually metered water service to any duplex (2) unit residence or triplex (3) unit 
residence served by a 5/8 - to ¾-inch or a 1-inch metered service; master-metered water service to 
any duplex (2) unit residence or triplex (3) unit residence served by a 5/8 - to ¾-inch or a 1-inch 
metered service. 
(1) ?Physical connection or reconnection of the above-defined residential water service(s) shall 
require the installation of a dual-check valve assembly. 
(2) ?Dual-check valve assemblies installed concurrently with reconnection of residential service (as 
defined) are exempt from the annual testing requirement of subsections (e)(1) and (3) above. 
(g) ?Responsibility. The director or his designee has been charged with the responsibility for the 
protection of the public potable water distribution system from contamination or pollution due to 
backflow or back-siphonage of contaminants or pollutants through the water service connection. The 
plumbing inspector has been charged with the responsibility of administering the Florida Building 
Code as it relates to chapter 29 entitled "plumbing systems." If, in the judgment of the director, the 
plumbing inspector, or their designees, an approved backflow-prevention assembly is required at the 
consumer's water service connection for the safety of the public potable water system, the director or 
the plumbing inspector or their designees shall give notice in writing to said customer to install such 
approved backflow-prevention assembly(s) at specific location(s) on the customer's premises. The 
customer shall, immediately and at his own expense, install such approved assembly(s); and failure, 
refusal, or inability on the part of the customer to install, have tested or maintain said assembly(s) 
shall constitute a ground for discontinuance of water service to the premises until such assembly(s) 
have been properly installed. 
(Ord. No. O-89-8, § 2, 6-21-89; Ord. No. O-93-6, §§ 2—5, 6-2-93; Ord. No. O-2003-001, § 9, 2-
19-03; Ord. No. 2004-005, § 2, 2-18-04; Ord. No. O-2010-015, § 6, 5-5-10) 


Sec. 22-19. - Water shortage; water shortage emergency; curtailment, restriction on certain uses of 
water. 
(a) ?Definitions . For the purpose of this section, the following terms, phrases, words and their 
derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words 
used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the singular, and words in the 
singular include the plural. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(1) ?City is the City of Oakland Park, Florida. 
(2) ?Water shortage or water shortage emergency is the declaration of such by the governing board 
or the executive director of the South Florida Water Management District pursuant to Chapter 
373, Florida Statutes. 
(3) ?Water is water taken from any groundwater system, surface water system including lakes, 
wells, canals or any similar bodies of water and public water supply. 
(b) ?Applicability . The provisions of this section shall apply to all users of water within the corporate 
limits of the city. 
(c) ?Declaration; curtailment, restriction of certain uses . The city finds that a water shortage exists when 
a water shortage or water shortage emergency is declared by the South Florida Water Management 
District which includes the corporate limits of the city. Certain nonessential uses of water shall be 
restricted or curtailed during the existence of a water shortage or water shortage emergency. These 
shall include all regulations and restrictions as adopted and imposed by the South Florida Water 
Management District. 
(d) ?Enforcement. Every certified law enforcement officer and code enforcement officer of the city shall, 
in connection with all other duties imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this law. The 
provisions of this section shall become activated and made enforceable only upon the separate 
adoption of a resolution of the city commission of the City of Oakland Park accepting and supporting 
an order of the governing board of the South Florida Water Management that a water shortage exists 
and water use restrictions are in effect in affected areas. 
(1) ?The enforcing officer shall issue a warning notice or monetary citation for any violation of the 
announced Phase 1 or 2 water use restrictions. A first violation shall result in a fine of fifty 
dollars ($50.00) payable to the City of Oakland Park by the violator. A second violation shall 
result in a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) payable to the city by the violator. Further 
violations shall result in a notice to appear to a City of Oakland Park Special Magistrate issued 
by a code enforcement officer to the violator. 
(2) ?Fines shall be doubled upon announcement of Phase 3 or 4 water use restrictions. 
(3) ?Appeal of the first or second violation citations may be made to a City of Oakland Park Special 
Magistrate within ten (10) days of the issuance of the citation. 
(4) ?Payment of fines shall be made to the City of Oakland Park. 
(5) ?Failure of a person to request a hearing before a special magistrate to appeal the decision of 
the code enforcement officer to issue the citation or to pay the fine within ten (10) days of the 
issuance of the citation shall constitute a waiver of the person's right to an administrative 
hearing. A waiver of the right to administrative hearing shall be deemed an admission of the 
violation and penalties may be imposed accordingly. 
(6) ?Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the city from enforcing these regulations by any 
other means. 
(e) ?Exceptions . The city, upon the recommendation of the department of environmental regulation or 
upon its own recognizance, shall have the authority to permit a reasonable use of water in any case 
necessary to maintain adequate health and sanitation standards. A letter from the department of 
environmental regulation to the city shall be required to permit such reasonable use of water during a 
water shortage or water shortage emergency situation. 
(f) ?Termination of service for failure to accept provisions . No water service shall be furnished to any 
person or entity in the city unless the person or entity agrees to accept all the provisions contained in 
this section. The acceptance of water service shall be in itself the acceptance of the provisions 
herein. 
(Ord. No. O-90-2, §§ 1—6, 1-17-90; Ord. No. O-90-15, § 8, 10-3-90; Ord. No. O-2001-012, § 2, 
3-21-01; Ord. No. O-2007-016, § 2, 5-16-07; Ord. No. O-2008-037, § 2, 12-3-08) 


Sec. 22-20. - Mandatory water restriction surcharge. 
(a) ?The City of Oakland Park will practice year-round water conservation. As such the following formula 
mandating water restriction surcharges will be in effect for all customers of the city. The pass-through 
of such charges is necessary to i) promote water conservation through an increased pricing 
incentive, which meets the overall interests of the South Florida Water Management District 
(SFWMD) water restrictions; and ii) ensure that the city maintains the financial and revenue 
sufficiency of its utility system. 
(1) ?The amount of surcharge shall be based on the level of declaration of a Phase I, Phase II, 
Phase III, or Phase IV level of water restrictions as mandated by the South Florida Water 
Management District and billed by the City of Fort Lauderdale and the number of gallons 
generated by the user. 
(2) ?If a declaration of any phase level of water restriction is recognized by the City of Fort 
Lauderdale prior to or on the 15th day of the month, the prescribed surcharge for that level of 
water restriction shall appear on the first utility billing processed on or after the 1st day of the 
following month. 
(3) ?If such declaration is recognized by the City of Fort Lauderdale after the 15th of the month, the 
prescribed surcharge shall appear on the first utility billing on or after the 1st day of the month 
following a thirty-day period after the declaration date. 
(4) ?When a declaration of water restrictions is rescinded by the South Florida Water Management 
District and subsequently recognized by the City of Fort Lauderdale, the prescribed surcharges 
shall be rescinded with the adjustment appearing on the first utility billing issued on or after the 
1st day of the month following the date the declaration is rescinded. 
(5) ?All surcharge adjustments, including the initial imposition, any increases and decreases, and 
the rescinding of the surcharge shall be implemented as described in subsections 22-20 (1), (2), 
(3) and (4). 
(b) ?The mandatory water drought surcharge shall be based on the following formula:
